A useful Europe that protects, that recovers and reclaims its social soul, that makes the European pillar of social rights a reality, not just a list of good intentions, and that wants it to land on rules, tools and budget. Why? Because today the European social dimension is not the consequence of integration. Today is the precondition for integration in Europe. We need to cushion and combat inequalities. We have to protect those homeless by globalization and generate economic security and certainty in the job market. It is the only way to protect and care for a fragile European democracy.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, throughout my time here in the Parliament and in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), I’ve championed the Better Regulation Agenda, and this, my friends, is not better regulation.  In a mad rush to conclude legislation at any cost, we’ve abandoned our commitment to the Parliament text on this Directive. We had clear wording to exclude the self—employed from the Directive, but this was watered down to a little recital, not legally binding. How can the EPP support that? How can the S&D support a text which still allows the abuse of pilots in the pay—to—fly for training? Across the political spectrum, we agreed that workers’ rights and workers’ safety should be protected, whether you work for a large company or a small company, whether you work in the public sector or the private sector. But the trilogue text exempts civil servants, it exempts firefighters, emergency services, police authorities, judges and prosecutors, it undermines the political message, and it allows Member States to exempt themselves. This does a real disservice to this Parliament.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done and, at the same time, regret that the Council, once again, has blocked any progress on the rights of European workers. Parliament's mandate guaranteed rights to workers with more precarious conditions and the text that we are going to vote on has left them practically without any type of protection. Emergency services, security forces, civil servants, sea workers, domestic workers under certain conditions and those who have contracts of less than twelve hours a month, among many other workers, have been excluded. As the unions say, these exemptions are discriminatory and a dangerous precedent for the European Union's minimum rights approach which, by definition, must be universal. The opportunity to build a social Europe demanded by the workers has been lost again. But what is put on the table is a much deeper problem, and it is the institutional framework of the European Union, where the Council - the Member States - permanently blocks the decisions of the European Parliament, which is the one voted by the European Parliament. citizens. You are the ones who contribute to increasing citizen disaffection in the institutions and, with it, the advance of the extreme right. When they try to correct their course, they are already too late.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, like some of the other speakers, my group feels that this has been a real missed opportunity to fully modernise the Written Statement Directive. Of course we can welcome measures such as the increased and better information contract at an earlier point, the compensation for cancelled on—demand work, but we do have problems about the definition of ‘worker’ and that the variants with the different Member States means that we’re undermining a certainty there. We also have grave problems in accepting the right of Member States to cover fewer workers in terms of the scope, not least the exemptions as has just been referred to, for example in the public services, emergency services, loopholes round household workers, when at the same time we are also urging Member States to invest in good public services as a key component of social Europe, and I’m not sure how this also works for workers who work multiple jobs, all on short—hours contracts. So we think, as others have said, that Council here could have followed the European Parliament, it could have followed the Commission, on putting in real strong, sound substance to help build social Europe, but what Council has given with one hand it has taken away with another.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ensuring predictable and transparent working conditions, that is to say the stability of the employment contract to best integrate new forms of employment, is a major challenge for all our countries. Businesses, employers and national legislators are faced with extremely rapid and brutal changes in the labor market. New forms of employment, known as "atypical", are multiplying at such a speed that since 2014, 20% of the jobs created correspond to this category. It is our responsibility to take the lead and oversee these new practices. We must also prevent potentially abusive practices in domestic work, in marginal part-time work, sometimes of very short duration, work based on checks and especially work linked to digital platforms. Because legislation is too often behind societal changes. While drafting this text, which is still insufficient, of course, I, on behalf of my ENL Group, made proposals and gave my support to certain concrete proposals of the rapporteur. It is essential that all our fellow citizens be protected in the same way, regardless of the precariousness of their employment. Let us not forget that the generalized pauperization of Europe, to which the policies of the European Union are obviously not unrelated, is at the origin of this myriad of mini-jobs and of the precariousness which results from it. It is the fragility of our businesses that causes instability in employment. While I am opposed to this model that they are trying to impose on us, I also know that more urgent situations have to be addressed. The European Union is now trying to mitigate or repair the consequences of the damage it itself has partly caused. While respecting the sovereignty of each Member State, the objective of our group is to promote secure and more predictable employment, while improving living and working conditions.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President. In November 2017, the Agreement on the European Pillar of Social Rights was announced in Gothenburg and signed by the Heads of State and Government of each country. The legislation we are discussing today will begin to build this pillar. Detailed rules have been put in place in the EU to make the single market work properly. It is time to establish minimum rules on workers' rights. The report deals specifically with people with changing working hours. He emphasizes that competition must not undermine the fundamental rights of workers. Still, today we can experience this in Hungary, for example. The Overtime Act, voted by the governing parties, which the common language simply calls slave law, serves the interests of global companies. This is contrary to the European social model, which is declared to prevent the exploitation of workers in new, more flexible forms of employment.

name: David CASA
text: - Sinjura President, nirringrazzja l-ewwel nett lir-Rapporteur għal dan ix-xogħol illi għandna quddiemna għaliex matul is-snin ix-xogħol inbidel u issa aħna rridu nadattaw għal din ir-reality ġ irluida g nasal u biex reg. -Unjoni Ewropea jridu jkunu aġġornati u modernized. Dan hu pass żgħir, imma pass ieħor biex noħolqu Ewropa soċjali illi ilna naħdmu għaliha, speċjalment f'dawn l-aħħar ħames snin, u hawn irrid nirringrazzja lill-Kummissarju Marianne Thyssen mal jean-kif ukoll members ta 'din il-kamra, speċjalment lill-Kumitat tal-Affarijiet Soċjali, l-Affarijiet tax-Xogħol għamilna ħilitna kollha biex inħallu l-Ewropa iktar soċjali milli hija llum. U din id-Directive li għandna quddiemna, din id-dikjarazzjoni, hija bżonjuża għaliex illum ix-xogħol hu diġitali u għandna types ta 'kuntratti ġodda u anki forom different ta' impjiegi. Ir-reality hi li l-kuntratti "short term", qosra, kuntratti magħrufa bħala "zero hours" u kuntratti "on demand" infirxu kullimkien, u issa din id-Directive qiegħda tagħmel address fuq dan it-tip ta 'kuntratti. U allura aħna għandna issa mod ta 'kif nipproteġu iktar lill-ħaddiema, fuq dawk li qed jaħdmu fuq pjattaformi diġitali. U allura għal darba oħra nirringrazzja lil dawk kollha li kienu involuti biex illum għandna dan id-dokument quddiemna.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President! The EU directive on transparent and predictable working conditions in the European Union is an interesting dossier. Promoting and building safer and more predictable employment, while ensuring the adaptability of the labor market and improving the living and working conditions of all employees, is the foundation of employee subjectivity. The feeling of certainty on the labor market and the security of legal protection of the employee, including employees working on non-standard contracts, is the key to his satisfaction, and a satisfied employee is, in turn, the best showcase and PR of the company, therefore mutual benefits and a perspective for development and satisfaction for both parties. But are these rules enshrined in this document? Well - not really. Therefore, in practice, it should be ensured that these solutions are prudent, rational and proportionate, that they maintain the adaptability and innovation of the labor market and avoid imposing excessive burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises, especially micro-enterprises.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam President, despite the good work of Parliament - and I want to thank the people who have dedicated themselves to this dossier - the Council has diluted key elements of this piece of legislation that is essential for social Europe. We have lost an inclusive and exhaustive definition of what a worker is, and the final text also offers great possibilities for Member States to grant exemptions for all workers who work less than twelve hours a month and also for a long list of professions , as the unions have denounced. In addition, the existence of a written contract is only required from the seventh day, and in practice this means that, for those hiring in black, a worker will only have been there for six days when the labor inspector shows up. Finally, as has been said, the shameful zero-hour contracts suffered by many of our fellow citizens are not prohibited either. The reality is that a growing legion of workers who today work in precarious conditions are not sufficiently protected. Social Europe deserves ambition and conviction, and not the permanent and infuriating dribbling that the Council has accustomed us to, despite repeated requests from the European Parliament.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, a directive to make working conditions known to workers, not just a joke about a so-called social Europe. From the minimum you legitimize the worst. You do not give rights to the employee; you give to employers. As long as they inform, of course, by passing a ravasaki about the conditions of the working jungle. You legitimize the most barbaric forms of work, such as zero-hour contracts, protecting the flexibility of employers — as you say — and excluding thousands of domestic workers, seafarers, etc., even from it. Here is the European social pillar voted by SYRIZA, New Democracy and PASOK. The European Union is only changing for the worse, because the monopolies that set it up are not changing. In the forthcoming European elections, the popular discontent should not be trapped in promises of its improvement, Social Democrats such as SYRIZA and others, nor in the Eurosceptic nationalism for the interests of the exploiters of each state separately. Let the people find their own way, the class one, with the support of those who aim at the heart of the beast, capitalism, its European Union, its monopolies in every state, and with the support of the Communist Party of Greece.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! First of all, congratulations on the consistency with which the European Commission, thanks to Commissioner Thyssen, is introducing further regulations that materialize the European Pillar of Social Rights. The new directive on transparent and predictable working conditions is important for all workers in the European Union, but especially for those who work on the basis of so-called non-standard or atypical contracts. It is an occasional job, on demand, on a contract, in the checking system, via online platforms, etc. Today, a quarter of European Union citizens work in this way, and half of the new jobs created in recent years are atypical or non-standard contracts . These workers are not subject to the existing directive on the obligation to inform employees about employment conditions. That is why the new directive is very important and gives workers additional rights, that is, they are to receive more information, more precise and faster. Above all, however, this directive will cover a very large part of the growing number of employees on these atypical, non-standard contracts. Only those who work less than twelve hours a month will not be subject to this directive. It is a revolution that will be especially beneficial for women, as they are the ones who supply the majority of precariat positions in the labor market. Commissioner, we need an intelligent combination of employment flexibility and job predictability, because only predictability gives workers a sense of some minimal security.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the number of European citizens who are employed in precarious forms of work is also increasing due to the rapid expansion of new sectors of the economy, of digital platforms. Those who suffer the most are, once again, the youngest and the women, often trapped in those so-called atypical, sometimes fraudulent forms of work, including bogus self-employment or zero-hour contracts. The directive we are voting on today clearly improves the European legislation in force, offering workers greater transparency and certainty about their working conditions and new rights that can be enjoyed by over two hundred million workers. However, more needs to be done. My political group, the Socialists and Democrats will continue to call for a framework directive on decent working conditions in all forms of employment. I am also determined to carry on a fundamental battle: to ban unpaid internships across the European Union, as we have managed to do in the European Parliament after three years of battles. Things can and must be changed.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner!Women are mostly affected by part-time work, but mothers are particularly affected.This is a policy that is hostile to the family because it is precisely here in the employment sector that they could have been included.Recognize parenting as work - work that is paid in crèches, kindergartens, children's homes and similar areas;an educational salary based on the minimum wage of the respective Member State;against the pension gap, for which we have not found a solution in the parents' area, especially with mothers, even in this electoral term.Here Hungarians could serve us as a model in a special way when it comes to considering parents.I think that we still have a big task open in the next parliamentary term.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, it is clear that European legislation must respond to changes in the internal market. The labor market is changing and flexible working hours are increasing. Unlike some colleagues, I do not call it precarious work. I do not think that flexible working hours must always lead to the exploitation of employees; on the contrary, some employees also prefer these jobs. Of course, in general, the aim is to make the work certain, predictable, and in this sense I support the proposal for a directive and the agreement that has been presented here. I thank the rapporteur, my colleague Radtke, the Commissioner, for finally reaching an acceptable compromise. In particular, it has already been mentioned here that mothers on parental leave will be able to work flexibly and return to work earlier, combining their work with caring responsibilities. I think that reconciling work and private life is one of the priorities, and the Commissioner has worked hard in this matter as well. So some sectors of the economy are also dependent on flexible working hours today, and we should not confuse the introduction of guarantees for workers with disruptions to certain types of work, such as on-demand work or zero hours. We must go the way of adequate regulation and not prohibition.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! I applaud the improvements we have made. We are strengthening the minimum rights of 200 million employees, because anyone who has a contract can also refer to it. It is, however, shameful that Germany, as an economically leading country, has the largest low-wage sector in Western Europe. It is good that we are giving these precarious workers more rights. The employment contract should be available before the first working day, but no later than after a week. The fact that in future employers, if they do not expire a contract, will have to explain why they are doing so after six months, gives me hope that the dispassionate discussion about the prohibition of unfounded time limits will continue in Germany. Because of the blockade in the Council of the conservative governments in particular, we were not able to achieve any great success. The complete ban on on-demand work would have been important to me. And it's downright absurd that people who work less than 32 hours a month should be excluded from all of the improvements. The Member States remain obliged to do more for European workers.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: - Madam President! It is a bit surreal to stand here, not only because it is one of my last speeches in plenary, but above all because Swedish Social Democrats say that this is not happening. We do not have this debate. The EU is not regulating the Swedish labor market. If the EU does that, then at least it has nothing to do with the social summit and the social pillar. Sweden's Prime Minister, Stefan Löfven, even called it a joke. If I then read the Commission's proposal, it may begin with the fact that this initiative is one of the Commission's most important measures in the follow - up to the social pillar of social rights, which was presented at the Gothenburg Summit in 2017. But - this is not happening. The main message is that in our reality this is absolutely not happening. Sometimes they wake up, Swedish Social Democrats, for example in November last year, when they called the proposal unacceptable, it risks greatly affecting the Swedish model with our laws and our collective agreements. They are right. It is unacceptable, but the incomprehensible thing is that they are voting for it. Now, instead, they seem to once again claim that this is not happening, and that may be why they are not here today participating in the debate. What is happening here is not happening - at least according to the Social Democrats.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! We live in a time of rapidly changing changes in the labor market. Every now and then there are new professions, the need for new skills or new forms of employment. Flexibility on the labor market is extremely important for both the employee and the employer. Flexible forms of employment help employees to combine work and family life, and employers - to adapt to changing market demand. It is our duty to ensure that, regardless of the form of employment, employees are guaranteed at least minimum rights at European level. After difficult work in the Employment Committee and difficult negotiations with the Council, it was possible to work out the shape of the directive, which, on the one hand, increases employee protection, and, on the other hand, does not impose excessive burdens and requirements on employers, while respecting various models of labor law in the Member States. I would like to draw your attention to the introduction in the directive of common requirements for providing employees with information on employment conditions in writing, basic information up to seven days from the start of work and up to thirty days of extended information. Also, a joint maximum trial period of six months will certainly improve the situation of workers in many countries.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, in 2016, the Committee on Petitions (PETI) of this Parliament heard directly from McDonald’s workers from across Europe about their precarious employment contracts and conditions as part of their ‘Unhappy Meal’ campaign. I’ve worked with them and I’ve been inspired by the mostly young workers in the fast food industry, who’ve joined together in their unions to say, ‘Enough is enough, we deserve fair working conditions and decent pay’.  This week we’ll be voting on a step in that direction. The draft rules on transparent and predictable working conditions are not as radical as I would have liked to see. I would have liked an explicit ban on exploitative zero—hours contracts and an explicitly universal coverage for all workers, regardless of public or private, and regardless of how many hours they work. But, as the European TUC have said, these rules give new important rights to precarious workers and shift workers across Europe. These rules must be implemented comprehensively, without loopholes or exceptions. These are minimum rights. Let’s do better. Growing precariousness at work is fuelling economic insecurity on which the far right feed. Let’s stop that feast.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Honorable President, the European Union must continue to be a global leader in ensuring good working conditions.The digital transformation of the economy and society as a whole has opened up a number of new opportunities, but we must not allow this wave of change due to the fourth industrial revolution to take millions of people to the margins of society.New flexible forms of employment make it possible to make the most of the opportunities offered by the digital economy, and during the recovery from the last global crisis they have kept many people above the surface.Better information for workers is necessary for them to exercise all their rights in a dynamic market.I would point out that our task, as legislators, is not to impose patterns on workers and employers but to ensure that there is a balance in their relationship.The rest should be left to them and their associations.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Madam President, how can we have guaranteed and predictable working hours in the European Union, when we deprive millions of employees of their information? We will do this if we vote in favor of the outcome of the tripartite dialogue. We will legalize precarious work, because the text with the Council proposals does not enhance worker protection but only flexibility. Why do they deprive them of the information they need to have about the conditions and salary of their work from the first day of their employment? He is completely unaware that many self-employed people are in fact employed. The Council has not understood anything of the yellow vest uprising in France, it has not understood anything of the precarious voice that is slowly growing throughout Europe. We here have to listen.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: - Sinjura President, il-kondizzjonijiet tax-xogħol huma importanti ħafna għaliex fl-aħħar minn l-aħħar ix-xogħol huwa parti mill-iktar integrali fil-ħajja tagāna. If you do not want to enter into an application, you will be able to pay a minimum amount of guarantees and guarantees that you will not be able to enter the contract.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the lead miners breaking their backs underground in the north Pennine hills in the 1800s had zero job security. The same was also true for the dockworkers of Liverpool in the 1900s. So how is it that in the 21st century, when we can put a man on the moon and send a probe to Mars, we cannot yet give the ordinary man and woman job security? With the rise of zero—hour contracts in the UK, through the emergence of the gig economy, and the transformative way our world is changing through the fourth industrial revolution, we must adapt legislation to ensure that workers are protected in this new ecosystem in the world of work. So with the UK Government still trying to leave the EU, and with the risk that the Conservatives will seek to water down workers’ rights, we must recognise that good regulation for predictable and transparent working conditions, along with collective bargaining for all citizens in all 28 Member States, is the best way for the UK, for the 27, for unions and for workforces.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we are spectators in the same project again. What we are seeing is that, in the end, the European Union is reaffirming its policy, that is, it is practically leaving labor relations in the field of flexibility and informal forms, and in essence it is securing neither permanent employment nor - mainly - arrangements that really the employment of employees themselves. And this is a big deficit of the specific legislative initiative we are discussing. I would also like to point out that the over-exploitation of substitute teachers and substitute teachers must stop. Thousands of teachers are currently being held hostage in Greece and their relations are not being regulated by Directive 1999/70 / EC, ie by securing specific rights and the possibility of appointment. This is a serious matter, which we have discussed in the Committee on Petitions and needs to be addressed.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Madam President, new forms of work, such as work on demand, based on extreme regulatory flexibility, instability and total availability cannot continue to be, as they have been up to now, new forms of cheap and precarious employment that feed on people that are left out of the system. This Directive could have been ambitious and inclusive because its objective was aimed at giving certainty to the labor market. However, by leaving zero-hour contracts out or excluding groups such as the public emergency service, civil servants, researchers or maritime workers from the chapter on minimum requirements, among others, it does not protect the people who most They need it, many of them women, as is the case of domestic workers who carry out domestic and care tasks and who, once again, have been left out of this legislation, something that is not understood, even more after this Chamber approved a report to dignify its conditions. We cannot support this exclusive and unfair regulation with those who need it most.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have already thanked the rapporteur, but let me also thank the shadow rapporteurs and also the Romanian Presidency for their constructive and successful negotiations. Honourable Members of Parliament, with the proposed directive on transparent and predictable working conditions, we focus on what is really necessary for workers in today’s labour market. Flexibility is today inevitable, just like digitalisation. Therefore, we have not sought to prohibit new types of employment, but to support the workers concerned with protection against excessive practices and with the minimum of predictability that everybody needs to organise life. The implementation of this directive will be a common task for Member States, employers and workers, with all the adequate room for social partners to make the rules a success on the ground.  I call on you to support the Directive. It’s a crucial measure of social justice and solidarity for all our citizens. As I said before, Madam President, this directive is also a major achievement to make the European pillar of social rights a reality. We should all be proud of this milestone. Honourable Members, allow me to conclude by making the connection between this directive and our other initiatives – posting of workers, protection against cancelled work, access to social protection for all, the Accessibility Act, the skills agenda, a more European semester and, not to forget, work-life balance. I believe all these initiatives, those decisions, they show what this Commission and this Parliament, together with the Council, have done during our mandate, bringing social Europe back at the centre of the Union’s action. (Applause)

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: speaker. - Madam President, I absolutely respect, and it is the only ones I am going to reply to, those who express reluctance. If it consoles you, which I don't think so, I will tell you that I am also one of those frustrated for not having gone further; but my job as a representative of Parliament was to find a balance point. Basically, what you notice are three "pains", we could say. The first is that it does not include everyone, because three hours a week and twelve hours are required. It is true, and we would have preferred that it encompassed the whole world; but look, anyway, in the advance with what we had before, which asked for two months. In any case, I would remind you that we have asked the Commission to exercise great active vigilance so that, if, for example, contracts of eleven hours a month proliferate, then obviously action will have to be taken. Second, there is also the issue of exclusions. I have not understood them, I do not approve of them, I do not understand those lobbies - for example the sea workers - but there was no way to reach a balance agreement without going through there. I say it calmly. And then I find myself before zero hours. We have made zero hours very difficult and they are also, from now on, unrepeatable. They cannot be renewed. At this point, what I want to say to my colleagues is that they consider what I have considered: is it good, even if it is not perfect, is it good that there is this for the future years of European workers? Is it much better than nothing? My conclusion has been that yes, and I ask you, respecting your ambitions, absolutely respecting your good manhood - or good womanhood - when criticizing the text, to ask yourself if the perfect is not the enemy of the good and if It is not worthwhile, in any case, to strongly support the entire Parliament at this stage in the construction of social Europe.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 16, 2019.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Jeroen Lenaers, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Labor Authority (COM (2018) 0131 - C8-0118 / 2018 - 2018/0064 (COD)) (A8-0391 / 2018).

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, the common European market is built on freedoms: the free movement of persons, the free movement of goods, capital and services. Those four freedoms have brought us a lot: more economic growth, more trade, more prosperity. However, Europe is about more than just market, money and trade. We must ensure that the common market really becomes a fair market: a market where employees receive what they are entitled to and are not exploited, where there is no room for bogus self-employment, social dumping or displacement on the labor market, where companies and citizens are affected. clear conditions to be able to operate cross-border without being the victim of unfair competition from rogue companies. So not just a free market, but above all a fair market. Not just free movement of people and services, but fair movement of people and services. To achieve that, we need two things: strict and clear European rules, but also proper enforcement of those rules. We have worked hard on those rules here in recent years. We have made equal pay for equal work in the same place a reality with the Posting of Workers Directive, we have stepped up the fight against undeclared work, we have better protected workers from working with dangerous substances and we have done a lot through the European Pillar of Social Rights to make a fair and social Europe a reality. However, rules are not worth the paper on which they are printed if they are not enforced sufficiently, properly and efficiently. There is a very big challenge there. More than 17 million Europeans live or work in a country other than where they come from. That number has doubled in the last ten years and will only increase in the near future. At the same time, we see that social and labor inspections in the Member States are still often limited to their own national borders, making cross-border enforcement far from effective. We are putting an end to this today: with the establishment of the European Labor Authority, we are giving cross-border enforcement and control a significant boost. We are showing here today that we also take that challenge very seriously as a Parliament. And we show that the European Parliament can deliver, because the European Commission made the proposal barely a year ago and the European Labor Authority can actually get to work. Better information provision for citizens and companies about their rights and obligations, bringing colleagues from different countries together to jointly realize inspections and enforcement, mediating between member states that disagree about how to enforce European rules, make risk analyzes of our weaknesses and how we can improve them can act: there is more than enough to do for the new labor authority. I'm glad it's an authority because an authority needs teeth. Teeth to prevent abuse. Teeth to ensure that confidence in the internal market is maintained in the future. I would therefore like to express my thanks. Firstly, to Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, without whose initiative, energy and enthusiasm this result would not have been achieved today. Thanks also to the Romanian Presidency, with whom we have had a bizarrely intensive schedule of negotiations. Thanks to that commitment, we have this result today. Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues from the other groups. Some of them I have seen more often than my own wife during the negotiation period. Don't tell my wife, but it was totally worth it. We are here today with a good result, thanks to the pleasant and constructive cooperation between us all. And last but not least, Mr President, a big word of thanks to all employees and advisers who made this possible. Because without them nothing would happen in this Parliament.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am also very happy to be here before the vote on the regulation establishing the European Labour Authority (ELA). I have always considered this regulation to be the final piece of the agenda of this Commission for fair labour mobility in Europe. I presented the proposal in March 2018 and, one year later, we are here to vote on the final regulation. This impressive result in decision-making owes a lot to the constructive approach taken by both co—legislators and to the commitment and hard work of Parliament’s rapporteur and the successive Council Presidencies. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Jeroen Lenaers, for his extraordinary commitment and his extremely efficient handling of the negotiations on behalf of the Parliament. I would of course also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the Council Presidency for their constructive work in bringing the file to a rapid and successful conclusion. The European Labour Authority will be the Union’s first operational agency in the area of labour mobility. Its establishment is much needed. Today, 17 million European citizens are living or working in another Member State than that of their citizenship. The European Labour Authority will be there for them, to ensure that European labour mobility rules are applied in a consistent, thorough and fair manner. The Authority will pursue three objectives, which are equally important. First, it will facilitate access to information and services to companies and citizens. When moving across borders, they need to know what their rights and obligations are. ELA will ensure that Member States comply with their information obligations, for example in the area of posting of workers, and it will manage the day—to—day activities of EURES, the European job mobility portal. Second, the authority will facilitate and support cooperation between national authorities that enforce EU legislation in the areas of labour mobility and social security coordination. The Authority will thus enable Member States in cross—border contexts to fight social fraud, abuse of workers’ rights and undeclared work more efficiently. Building on the examples of Eurojust and Europol, the European Labour Authority will bring national experts together under one roof in order to facilitate information exchange and cooperation. No doubt this will significantly contribute to the creation of a common enforcement culture, to efficient exchanges and mutual trust. The European Labour Authority will also give the necessary support for national inspectorates to cooperate through concerted and joint inspections. Third, the European Labour Authority will provide a forum for mediation between national authorities in case of disputes. By promoting dialogue and out-of-court settlements of issues, we aim to facilitate swift responses to disputes which involve cases of individual citizens or companies. I know that, two years ago, when we started referring to the possible establishment of the European Labour Authority, some had doubts about the added value of another European agency. Our proposal already made clear that we wanted to set up an authority with operational tasks that were not yet exercised at EU level, and this is exactly what this regulation has done. The European Labour Authority will be of great practical value in the day—to—day enforcement of labour mobility rules and, at the same time, it will open opportunities for a fair mobility of labour within the European Union. Once adopted, this Commission is ready to take the first practical steps to make the European Labour Authority operational by autumn 2019. I’m really looking forward to your observations later on.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Madam President, Commissioner Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen! The labor market authority will take care of the effective application and enforcement of European labor mobility law - that is good. In future, she will be the first point of contact for national labor inspectors who carry out cross-border controls to prevent wage and social dumping - that is also good. This also gives honest companies more protection from unfair competition - that's good too. What is not so nice is that we have to wait a little longer until this agency is fully functional. Nevertheless, it is an important milestone. However, we would have liked to see stronger control competencies for the labor authority. It is particularly regrettable that it has not been possible to enforce sanctions against Member States unwilling to cooperate, and I also believe that the poor involvement of social partners in the agency's management is a mistake. To this day I still cannot understand how the conservative-liberal parliamentary groups could neglect that. And we hope that there will be more rationality in the dispute over the seat of this labor authority than was the case last with the seat of agencies.

name: Karima DELLI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - (start of intervention outside the microphone) ... to abuse, the establishment of a European labor authority is more than necessary: ​​it is essential. Social Europe only exists in texts and never in reality, that's enough! Let us give ourselves the means to enforce the law and, once and for all, put an end to social dumping. This authority will help and support not only posted workers, but also people established in another Member State to work there. The European Union must finally take real action for workers' rights within the European Union so that they are respected and that free movement remains a real opportunity. In particular, the European labor authority will be able to coordinate inspections across the country and ensure compliance with the social rules in force. It is very clearly, my dear colleagues, a step forward for social Europe because, in concrete terms, it does exist in the texts, but is still not implemented or respected: it could not last any longer. and this must not last! I hope, my dear colleagues, that all together we will adopt this text by a very large majority.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Speaker JURI. - Madam President, we are once again witnessing an attempt to impose market restrictions through manipulation on the topics of 'social dumping' and 'social rights'. Moreover, we see a proposal to set up an agency which, on the one hand, should not interfere in national regulations and the free movement of workers, but on the other hand, should penalize the Member States. Once again - and for no particular reason - land transport is explicitly mentioned in the report. This means that governments in Western Europe continue to be intimidated by entrepreneurs and workers in the East and lightly decide to introduce more and more new regulations. Job mobility in the Union benefits European citizens, the economies of the Member States and the Member States as a whole. All efforts to regulate economic relations in the Union must be subject to the principle of facilitating entrepreneurship. Should this body still be set up, it would be a great sign for the European Union to finally decide to move its headquarters to a country where there is no European agency. Such is, for example, Bulgaria, which during its presidency of the Council of the European Union has proved that it is worthy to host such an agency.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: LIBE rapporteur. - Madam President, let me greet two friends there from the rostrum. Commissioner, thank you very much for this proposal and for your work over the last year. I congratulate Mr. Boiangiu and I congratulate the rotating presidency of Romania because we managed to complete this negotiation in less than a year. The next European Labor Authority has a very important mission, and the Commissioner has raised some issues that will be achieved thanks to this authority. What do I want? I want this authority to be in Romania and I have arguments. Because at the Romanian level we have this system called ReviSal, through which we offer a transparency that we do not find in other member states. We offer the fastest answers to European requests when it comes to cross-border cooperation and the necessary data on the workers we post, which we send to other Member States. This qualifies us and I think it is a guarantee that, if this authority will have its headquarters in Romania, it will have the same results that the rotating presidency of Romania has in everything that means the field of work.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: rapporteur for the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, the establishment of the European Labour Authority is a step forward in the protection of workers’ rights and the enforcement of labour law provisions for those many EU workers using their right to free movement. However, as rapporteur for the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), I wish that more of the proposals put forward in our Opinion had been taken on board. For instance, the introduction of a clause to ensure gender mainstreaming, the need to carry out a gender impact assessment before the drafting of annual and multiannual programming, the need to liaise with the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE) – not only with Eurostat – when compiling statistic—relevant data, ensuring gender—sensitive reporting and evaluations, including the collection of gender—disaggregated data, and finally, not aiming at, but ensuring, gender balance in the composition of the European Labour Authority’s governing and consultative bodies. Nevertheless, we fully support the report and hope that the Authority will become operational as soon as possible.

name: David CASA
text: for the PPE group. - Sirjura President, nixtieq nibda billi nifraħ lir-Rapporteur Jeroen Lenaers ħar-riżultat eċċellenti li kiseb f'din il-leġiżlazzjoni u li b'hekk ħadna passi importanti biex incomplu niksbu Ewropa żjed soċjali. Iva din hija storja ta 'suċċess oħra fl-implimentazzjoni tal-prinċipji tal-pilastru Ewropew tad-drittijiet soċjali u suċċess ukoll fl-opportunitajiet offruti mis-suq komuni. L-Awtorità Ewropea tax-Xogħol se tkun hemm biex tgħin u tassisti lill-avtoritajiet individwi tal-Istati Membri biex jiġġieldu kontra kwalunkwe abbużi u frodi u jagħmlu din l-istess mobbiltà faċli għaċ. Ser ikun hemm ukoll biex tgħin fil-koperazzjoni bejn il-pajjiżi Ewropej u biex tinforza l-liġijiet li japplikaw. Biex nagħmlu dan, kellna nikkreaw regoli ċari, uusti u li jiġu infurzati kif suppost fuq il-mobilità għax-xogħol. Huwa biss b'sinerġija u kooperazzjoni tajba bejn l-awtoritajiet tal-Istati Membri illi dan huwa possibbli. Mingħajr ma ninsew ir-rwol importanti li l-imsieħba soċjali għandhom f'dan il-proċess. Kif nafu, is-suq komuni huwa ralientrali għall-pjan u l-proġett Ewropew, u l-mobbiltà fl-Unjoni Ewropea hija realtà li naraw u nesperjenzaw kuljum fejn miljuni ta 'ċittadini Ewropej jħudu.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the establishment of a European-level authority called on to play an essential role in ending labour exploitation, ensuring fair worker mobility and tackling undeclared work is a landmark achievement. President Juncker’s call in September 2017 was followed by a Commission proposal as early as March of last year and intensive work by this Parliament, together with the Council, in arriving today at the point of agreement in record time. It is of vital importance to endeavour to make the European pillar of social rights everyday living reality for each and every European citizen, no matter from which Member State he comes. Moreover, it must become the guiding light for achieving superior competitiveness of European businesses on the basis of fully-fledged social partnership, collective bargaining and environmental sustainability. The lure for business to succumb to short-termism and the wages race to the bottom not only entails severe exploitation and abuse of mobile labour but also undermines the very foundations on which citizens base their allegiance to the Union and, what is more, their willingness to engage in highly-productive and efficient work. Let me end by urgently inviting all of us here and all those concerned to turn the launching of the European Labour Authority (ELA) this autumn into a high-profile event, and to recommit to building a truly social union with vigorous welfare states as the only possible way to provide citizens with a life in dignity and security and the Union with a promising future in this ever-more challenging world of ours. In these last few seconds I would just like to join in thanking my colleague Mr Lenaers for the terrific work he organised, the Commission and Ms Thyssen for her commitment, Council and all those who made an input to this success.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, can I thank the rapporteur for his constructive approach, the shadow rapporteurs, our co-legislators in the Council, and Madam Thyssen and the Commission. When I looked at this proposal initially, I did have some questions around its added value and the impact it would have on EURES, the platform for undeclared work, etc. But I believe that the piece of legislation that we have now has, in short, the necessary cooperation and streamlining to give us an efficient and effective ELA. The other question I had at the beginning was: what problems are we trying to solve, and will this piece of legislation actually solve those problems? Free movement of workers is working, but from time to time issues arise that can undermine the trust in the system and that question fairness and compliance. Those issues, I believe, require an independent authority that will strengthen operational coordination and cooperation between Member States, mediate in cross-border disputes and facilitate dispute settlements. I believe that the final piece of legislation addresses many of the identified problems around the day-to-day operational free movement of workers, and by doing so, I believe it facilitates free movement of workers for all EU citizens and a more streamlined system because of cooperation between Member States, and crucially, it will help to restore trust in the system, trust between Member States and trust between citizens. This won’t be my final intervention in Parliament, but it’s one of the last, and I’m especially pleased today to be able to say that I was part of a team that helped to deliver a piece of legislation that will enhance the free movement of workers while at the same time reassuring citizens and Member States that this is a system they can trust and believe in.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Mrs. Chairman! Thanks also to the rapporteur. Every single day across Europe, thousands of people live in unfair working conditions. With low wages, poor working conditions, no contracts and no rights. They often have to have several jobs just to make ends meet. Social dumping is the human backside of the EU's internal market and of free - the unrestrained free - movement. It is the internal market that puts the rights of companies far above the rights of workers. Which puts profit over people. And it is an internal market that moves power far away from the citizens, indeed far away from our elected politicians, and that limits our democratic opportunities. The thousands of people living with the consequences, they obviously demand solutions, they expect us to do something effective to stop social dumping, to ensure orderly wages and orderly working conditions. But what answer do they get here from the EU? They get an answer that is about even more EU: an EU authority that is going to require a lot of resources and a lot of bureaucracy. When the answer really should be less EU and much more power for the citizens, then the answer will once again be even more EU and even more power for the EU. It's deeply nonsensical. Citizens do not need more EU authorities, they need a showdown with the internal market, they need to regain power over their labor market.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I am really glad that we now have one more EU authority: this European labor market supervision, which is a kind of EUROPOL light for the labor market that can help national authorities to prevent both cheating with benefits and social dumping, among other things. using inspections. 14 million Europeans work in an EU country other than their own. They pay taxes, contribute to society and, of course, must be socially insured just like their colleagues if they lose their jobs. People come to work, not to cheat. Yet distrust of both the migrant workforce and employers is flourishing. Among other things, due to horrific cases like the one on the Danish-German border, where 200 Filipino drivers were almost held as slaves. For my Danish party, SF, free movement and good conditions for migrant workers are central, as is the protection of the Danish welfare model. Finally, I would like to remind you that we Greens would like to further strengthen the ELA by giving European citizens the right to complain directly to them. Unfortunately, it was voted down. But regardless of this defeat, it is a good project that we naturally support.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, it takes 13 whole years for the Labor Inspectorate in Greece to inspect all workplaces at least once. The European Union and governments have also broken down these minimal and inadequate state control mechanisms. The goal is for the employer with his hands outstretched to unhinder the employees. In these remnants of labor inspections in each country comes the establishment of the so-called European Labor Authority. The aim of the new Euro-mechanism is to increase worker mobility, because - as the European Union provocatively states - only 700,000 workers move from country to country each year. In other words, you protect and promote the labor galley and the black uninsured work, based on the anti-labor European pillar which was co-signed by SYRIZA, New Democracy and KINAL in Greece. The replacement of collective agreements is promoted, with labor rights even lower, in the nadir, where minimal rules are baptized. Voting criteria also for the workers, with a class organization and a strong KKE everywhere, in order to counterattack and put obstacles in the labor jungle of the European Union.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! Mobility is one of the fundamental rights of citizens of the European Union. We have posted workers, cross-border workers and millions of people who sometimes simply work for years in a country other than their home country. During this term of office, the European Commission, Parliament and Council have repeatedly discussed rights for mobile workers. We talked about the mobility package and the directive on posted workers, the provisions on the coordination of social security systems, we talked, and we even created a platform for cooperation between the Member States to counteract undeclared work. These discussions were often controversial - sometimes very controversial - and we had a lot of doubts because the law is very complicated at times. Therefore, the idea of ​​establishing a labor office that informs, helps, supports, helps to understand and apply this law is obviously very good. This office is very much needed. However, in these debates, there were such ideas to provide this agency with strong control powers. And I would like to make it very clear here that while I support support and information functions, I am opposed to these control functions, because at the stage of introducing a new law, we should help companies understand the law and apply it - this is especially important for small enterprises - and not from implement such control functions immediately.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European creation of the European Labor Authority is a great success of our group in the European Parliament and a first result of the approval of the pillar of social rights. We have been fighting in this direction for years now, demonstrating that our objective of a social and just Europe is not limited to proclamations, but takes concrete action to improve the lives of citizens and to help them find a job. The new Authority will be an important tool to ensure greater protection, equal dignity and rights for workers on the move within the Union, including cross-border ones, to support Member States in the fight against social dumping, undeclared and illegal work, to ensure greater consistency on the issue of posting of workers. I also remind the Commission that it will be imperative for Parliament to participate in the choice of location because, as for the EMA, we share the responsibility for its financing and therefore we also share that for the location. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it's me again.What can we do!I am a drug addict of social policies and social Europe.I just wanted to tell you that this falls directly within the line that the Commissioner put forward at the end of the previous debate, within that great effort that we make at the end of the mandate Commission, Parliament and, more reticently, the Council towards the creation of social Europe, towards its positive evolution.I thank the rapporteur and all shadow rapporteurs for what they have done.Obviously this could have been perfect, but, even so, it is a huge step towards facilitating the mobility of workers, towards monitoring abuses, towards the correct implementation of European minimum rights and, therefore, cannotbe more than welcome and supported by this Parliament.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - (NL) Mr President, unfair competition in the workplace between colleagues at home and abroad is something that people often approach me about. Cross-border social fraud affects our citizens every day. However, we know exactly what to do. The gaps in the legislation are very clear. The problem lies with those Member States who lack the will to effectively do something about the controls. The unfortunate result is that support for the European single market is melting, just as we need the same internal market more than ever. In my region, West Flanders, companies are begging for workers and those willing to work are welcomed with open arms. Labor mobility supports economic growth and thus prosperity. But labor mobility can only be sustainable if it is done in a fair manner. And there the shoe pinches him. Many citizens feel that the cowboys in the various sectors get away with it every time they commit fraud. Those who color outside the lines will not be penalized. This must change with the establishment of the European Labor Authority. Fast and accurate information exchange by Member States is the best remedy to eradicate fraud. At the beginning of this term, we were promised a social triple A. The European Labor Authority is part of the development of a Union in which the social aspect comes back to the fore, not least thanks to Commissioner Thyssen. Concrete steps like these can help to get rid of frustration among our citizens and also boost the credibility of the European project. I hope many more will follow.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this European Labor Authority must be supported, because it is a step forward that must not be overlooked. Nevertheless, we know that we are still too much, today, in the conciliation on these subjects, in particular those of regulation and the fight against fraud. That’s why we will need more steps forward. For my part, I see other steps to take in the future. First of all, a true European labor inspectorate, which will be able in particular to sanction fraudsters not only on the financial level, as already exists in certain Member States, but also on the penal level, because we know that, from this point of view, fear must change sides. The fraudsters who organize social dumping today must know that if they persist on this path, they will personally pay the consequences. Then, the European Commission must put on the table an electronic social security card which will really be a tool for the portability of rights. This is therefore a first step forward, many will still have to be taken to ensure that social dumping becomes a bad memory and is no longer a reality.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! In May last year, we adopted the agreement on the Posting of Workers Directive. It was a great victory for many wage earners and for the trade union movement, that is, equal pay for equal work in the same place. It is now necessary for the Member States to implement this directive properly and for us to follow this up. The European Labor Office is an important piece of the puzzle for that follow-up. The Authority will also contribute to better information sharing between Member States. We know that there is so much cheating with payments to social insurance systems. Without information, it is impossible to deal with this. All workers in Europe must be fully insured. What the EU and the government can really contribute is to ensure that people do not fall between the cracks when moving between countries. There must be order and fairness in the labor market. At the same time, I am very pleased that we reached a compromise that respects national competence and the role of the central parties. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the Commissioner for his cooperation during this parliamentary term. It's been fun… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking and congratulating the Commissioner and also our rapporteur, my colleague Lenaers, because I think they have reached a good agreement.I am not in favor of the creation of new agencies, but I want to say that this body has some potential to address the internal market problems we are facing and to enforce European law where it has not yet been enforced.For example, I am counting on protection against the protectionist measures that some states are putting in place.I don't think I even have to name loi Macron, MiLoG and more.I think that implementation will need to be monitored so that there is no real overlap with the activities of other agencies and bodies.It will be necessary to ensure that the participation of inspectors is genuinely voluntary and that Member States respect the status that inspectors are supposed to have in that State.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Distinguished Chairperson, I am a strong advocate of ensuring a high level of workers' rights and creating a social climate in which it will be normal for these rights to be respected.In part of Europe, this is still not the case, despite the fact that there is a good legal framework and all the force of bureaucracy that is constantly supplementing and enforcing it.You will wonder how this is possible?Very simple: administrative bodies are not a guarantee of respect for workers' rights or the provision of good working conditions.I would say that it is just the opposite: the more laws and bureaucracy, the worse the protection of workers in practice.I cannot support the establishment of a European Labor Supervisory Authority because it would mean an increase in bureaucracy and a new struggle for competences with already inefficient national authorities.Someone has to pay for this bureaucratic circus, and it is precisely the workers who do not need an additional burden from which they will not benefit too much.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Madam President, European Labor Authority; this title sounds very nice. But what do we say to so many thousands of workers who work unpaid, without social security, often and without occupational risk insurance? Citizens are falling victim to thousands of modern-day slave traders in the European Union, and they do not need our kind words; they need the right measures. When will a new Labor Authority have value? When it will not only deal with the control and recording of violations, but will really protect employees from employers looking for their victims in cross-border employment. In other words, a European Labor Authority, which will also be present in the courts on the side of the workers, in order to become their European support.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! The tasks of the new agency give it great potential to influence the reality of mobility in the European Union. Some of them were highlighted by the Commissioner: the emphasis on informing about mobility rights and obligations, collecting data, carrying out analyzes, assessing the situation in the internal market, supporting cooperation between the control authorities of the Member States. These are only part of the tasks of the new agency, which have a chance to fight the wrong perception of mobility in Europe or the desire to apply protectionism. Whether this potential will be used depends on the people who will run it and work in it. This will depend on the actions of both the Executive Director and the Management Board and the broad representativeness of the stakeholder group. I expect that the nationality of people who hold the highest positions will also be important. We will observe both the seat selection process and the method of selecting candidates for the highest positions. It is in the interest of the entire Union that they are not questioned and do not lead to a feeling of consenting to protectionism or other constraints on the internal market. This stage of creating the agency itself is therefore crucial for the image of Europe and the future of mobility of the development engine of the entire European Union ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the European Union, instead of supporting the effort to create a European minimum wage, instead of instituting a European minimum unemployment benefit, instead of tackling breaches of labor law in the Member States — in the classic case of breach of Directive 1999/70 / EC, which concerns informal labor relations, instead of stopping the hostage-taking of thousands of teachers, substitute teachers and professors in Greece, is improving the situation and telling us that a European Labor Authority must be created. This is a new bureaucratic mechanism; an attempt to usurp the powers of the Member States. Let the European Union look at the violations that happen every day and give its own energy there.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as I said before, our proposal for setting up the European Labour Authority has been the final piece of the legislative reform that we launched towards ensuring fair labour mobility. When I received my portfolio on employment, social affairs, skills and labour mobility, I knew that labour mobility would not be the easiest area. I am therefore very happy that, after the division of the Posting of Workers Directive, you are now asked to vote on this regulation, which is another milestone for ensuring fair labour mobility in Europe. It realises the principle of the pillar of social rights in a cross-border context.  Unfortunately, it has not yet been possible for the co-legislators to agree on the proposed modernisation of the social security coordination rules. I am confident, however, that the position that you adopt Thursday in first reading will laid the grounds for a fruitful and, hopefully, swift adoption after the European Parliament’s elections.  The millions of citizens for whom labour mobility is a daily reality, an opportunity, or sometimes a bare necessity, merit to benefit from updated rules as soon as possible. Free movement has always been a founding principle for our European Union and it has remained so even more today. The economies and labour markets of our Member States have become deeply intertwined. Free movement also feeds the connection between our citizens and peoples.  Facilitating free movement while at the same time ensuring that the European rules are applied in a fair way, these have been the guiding principles in my proposals on labour mobility. These guiding principles allowed us to obtain legislative reforms, supported by east and west and north and south, and these principles also underpin the regulation establishing the European Labour Authority. I just call on you to support this regulation.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, it says something about the importance of the European Labour Authority (ELA) that so many colleagues have entered the Chamber to make sure not to miss the end of this debate. Thank you all for your attention. For those of you who weren’t here at the beginning, let me tell you that today is a very good day. By establishing the European Labour Authority we are taking a crucial step towards realising a truly fair and a truly social European labour market, where we move from the free movement of workers only to ensuring fair labour mobility – a market where workers’ rights are guaranteed and protected, where there is no room for bogus self—employment, social dumping or unfair competition. In order to achieve all this we need better enforcement of the European rules in the area of labour mobility, and that is exactly what the European Labour Authority is going to do and it will start doing it very soon. This is a landmark achievement and it shows that the European Union can deliver in an area of citizens’ concern and that it can deliver fast. So, once again, a big thank you to the European Commission, Commissioner Thyssen, to the Romanian Presidency and to all our colleagues who worked together in a very good, a very constructive and a very efficient manner to get this done. I count on all of you to keep this commitment going, because we all need to work together to ensure ELA’s success in the future. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 16, 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written.- The EU Labor Authority is coming.And that is a huge success for the employees in Europe.The posting directive is to be controlled throughout Europe with the EU labor authority.This is how we can really ensure that the same wages are paid for the same work in the same place.Because the best laws against wage and social dumping are of no use if they are not properly controlled across borders.The EU Labor Authority is coming because we Social Democrats and trade unionists in the European Parliament have not given up.We stuck to it, although the conservatives and many member states - above all the Austrian government - wanted to keep the authority as small as possible.I am still committed to Austria as the location of the EU labor authority - because we are all too familiar with the problems of the European wage gap.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Today we are discussing a report that is very important to the majority of the population of the European Union, because it concerns workers and those who will work in the future. The emerging European Employment Service should help Member States to ensure the effective application of Union law in the fields of labor mobility and social security coordination. In order to carry out its functions, this body must assist the Member States and not take decisions. It is the Member States that know best the needs and problems of their labor markets. The Authority should help citizens to increase social justice in the countries and promote the free movement of workers and services in the single market, while respecting the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity. To this end, the Agency should assist Member States and the Commission in all Member States, through the EDA website, to increase workers 'and employers' access to relevant new information on their rights and obligations in cross-border labor mobility and services and to promote cooperation between Member States. The Agency should also encourage the promotion of cooperation between Member States to ensure the effective application of European Union law in these areas, as well as mediate and assist in the resolution of cross-border disputes in the field of employment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Your Honors, before voting time begins, allow me a few words to welcome Greta Thunberg. Today we have with us a special guest in the visitors' gallery, a person who would seem that she does not need to be introduced. She is a young citizen of the European Union, from Sweden, who with her personal history, her courage, her ideas and her clarity has become a symbol of the fight against climate change, given the urgency and ambition that this requires. (Prolonged applause) Greta Thunberg urges us, legislators, but also businesses and citizens to redouble our efforts in the face of the climate crisis. The track record of the European Parliament throughout this term has shown that we largely share the urgency and ambition of this young European. We can remember this legislature knowing that the European Union has embarked on an irreversible path with respect to the climate and the protection of the environment. Whether you look at emissions from the transport sector or the reform of the emissions trading scheme, it has been Parliament that has always set the highest bar in the interests of sustainability, not to mention timely ratification. record of the Paris Agreement, which we promoted and celebrated in this Chamber in the presence of the then Secretary General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon. But we also know that this is not enough, that we must all do more at individual, local, national, European and international level if we want to avoid global warming above 1.5 ° C and the devastation that this implies. The next legislature is going to be key in this regard. She will speak in an exchange of views in the ENVI Committee at two in the afternoon, in a session open to all deputies. We gave him a round of applause before; I think it would not be bad to repeat that welcome to Greta Thunberg. Welcome, Greta! (Applause)

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr. President, dear colleagues, yesterday it was with heavy hearts that Catholics, Parisians and French people discovered the image of Notre-Dame de Paris, nine centuries old, in flames. It is also with a heavy heart that I wish to express here, on behalf of the French delegation, but also, I am sure, on behalf of all of you, our deep sadness at this catastrophic event. Yesterday, it is a treasure of French heritage that was partially destroyed. Yesterday a part of the European cultural heritage caught fire. Yesterday, seeing Our Lady in flames, a little part of us was on fire with her. Honor to the firefighters who valiantly fought the flames all night long to keep this beautiful cathedral standing. I tell you, dear colleagues, France and the French will be resilient in this ordeal. What the cathedral builders erected yesterday, we will rebuild tomorrow. I would like to thank you here, dear colleagues, for your support for France. When a treasure of our heritage is touched, all of Europe is at its bedside. As Victor Hugo said in Notre-Dame de Paris, each flow of time, each individual brings their own stone. We too will bring our own to the reconstruction of this symbol.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: - Mr President, I wanted to add something which will take fifteen seconds. In 1163, when construction began, there was a skilled stone and timber workforce that came not only from France, but from across Europe. We found Germans, Spaniards, Italians and even people from Central and Northern Europe, to come and contribute their contribution to this monument of civilization which remains our civilization today, the great European project. But that's not what I meant. Mr President, you have appointed me chairman of the ethics committee for this term, alongside Mrs Delvaux, Mr Karim and Mr Maštálka. During this mandate, we have been subjected to a lot of pressure from the lobbies which have settled in our institutions. I would like to remind you, Mr President, that during the vote on the “copyright” directive, to mention only that one, not to mention those to come tomorrow and the day after tomorrow, the lobbies also acted to evil way. They settled in our institutions and, as far as the European Parliament is concerned, even in the interinstitutional phase, where they had nothing to do. I therefore ask that you be able to leave to the next Parliament, in legation of our conception of the righteousness of a deputy and of our Parliament, the obligation to strengthen the rules to block lobbies, as soon as the texts arrive in plenary, once and for all.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: We now turn to voting time.(For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission supports the recommendation to the European Parliament to give its consent to the accession of the European Union to the Geneva Act. On the substance, however, the Commission’s position differs from the one taken by the Council and the European Parliament as regards the possibility for all Member States to join the Geneva Act in view of the European Union’s exclusive competence in this case. The Commission would, very exceptionally, have been ready to agree that in this particular case, the seven Member States that have been parties to the Lisbon Agreement for a long time could have been authorised to accede to the Geneva Act in the interest of the European Union. In this respect, I would like to refer to the Commission’s statement on this issue, which has been submitted to the Council and to the European Parliament.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Speaker. - Thank you President, I would like to underline the importance of this recommendation because the production of olive oil is an important sector for the economies of Mediterranean Europe - among these Italy - and is a product of excellence of European exports, hard hit , for example I am thinking of olive growing in Salento, hit by frosts and hit by the detachment. I am in favor of Parliament giving a favorable opinion on the conclusion of the agreement, to ensure that the European Union continues to actively contribute to international cooperation on olive oil and table olives. However, I cannot help but regret the delay in the transmission of this agreement to the European Parliament and the lack of timely information from other institutions during the negotiations. International agreements relating to the commercial policy of the European Union are subject to the consent of the Parliament. For this reason, I urge the Council and the Commission to inform Parliament adequately, in particular about any decision that may be taken in relation to Article 4 of the Council Decision.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I know how much we hate the speeches by rapporteurs which disturb the smooth flow of votes, but unfortunately, today I’m obliged to explain the dilemmas we are facing. We all know the old Israeli joke – how many times the policemen laughs when you tell him a joke – but during this mandate we have had eight appointments to the European Court of Auditors (ECA) and, with the outstanding exception of the Republic of Ireland, all of them have been political appointments – and, I must underline, increasingly so by the new or eastern-European Member States including, Estonia, Finland, and Hungary. I am not going to say that we, the politicians, are unsuited or incapable to carry out other professional work. On the contrary, our colleague Ms Maletić has very good credentials to become an auditor again. Yet the procedure for how the Member States pick up the candidates is far from transparent and fair. I hereby call on the Member States to listen finally to the calls of this Parliament and propose always two candidates to achieve a gender balance and follow the Irish example – that means having fair, public competition to select those people, in the spirit of Article 255 in our European Treaties.
