Dear colleagues, we must reconsider whether we really need an ECA member from all the Member States simultaneously. Is there really so much to be audited? Why can’t we manage this institution by taking turns: 14 auditors for one period and 14 for another? If we fail, there will be more disgruntled and unhappy people around, ready to destroy Bastilles all over Europe. So please vote this time as the rapporteur has suggested, but keep in mind the fact that a process taken by the Romanian and Croatian governments has not met the high standards and ideals of the European Union. And indeed, the policeman only laughs once when you tell him a joke.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Mr President, I would just like to remind my colleague that today we are voting on the usual procedure and we shouldn’t be listening to this highly ideological speech in this Parliament. Please decide on it on its merit.

name: Wolf KLINZ
text: Rapporteur.- Mr President, ladies and gentlemen!After almost fifteen years, I will be leaving this House at the end of the parliamentary term.That is why I have two reports here today, which will be my last as rapporteurs.Working on them has shown me that this House is capable of finding consensus and building bridges across party-political boundaries, in contrast to many national parliaments, which tend to dig trenches.Many of you will stand for election again and join the next parliament.I would like to appeal to all of you not to let up in the fight for the European idea.For more than 60 years, the European Union has given us peace, freedom, democracy, the rule of law and relative prosperity.We owe it to our children and grandchildren that the European project does not fail and that Europe stays together.Europe is the future of all of us.We don't have any other.(Applause)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ..(inaudible) do the same as Mr Klinz. Thank you all from me for a fantastic 15 years: fantastic friends all over the borders, from political borders and national borders. I would like to underline that here lies an opportunity to make Europe stronger: a free society open for all individuals, strong in a global environment that needs cooperation. The European Union is a fascinating thing. We might sometimes have different views, but the good thing is that we have a common task and a common aim. So thanks to all of you for a fantastic 15 years. Those are my last two reports, and I hope they will contribute to a more stable Europe. (Applause)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: rapporteur.- Mr President, I thought I was waiting for the vote on the third report but, like my colleagues Wolf Klinz and Gunnar Hökmark, after 25 years with you, this is my last report.I would like to thank you all: those I fought, those with whom I had complicity, all with whom we ended up finding a European position.Also thank the interpreters, all the officials of this house and tell you that I am leaving a European Parliament which has changed profoundly.We too have changed.Europe has changed.But this Parliament has become the real Parliament of the citizens.It is always said that he is too attentive to lobbies, but he is also in harmony, in tune with this rising wave of Europeans who believe that Europe is their best future.This Parliament is a modern, original, democratic Parliament: it is that of the citizens.Keep it that way!(Applause)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Mr President, in accordance with Rule 59 (3) of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to request a procedural vote with a roll call vote to vote on the amendments first, before provisional agreement.These amendments eliminate discriminatory exceptions in the application of the Directive and in this way we will achieve protection for all workers, especially those who are in a particularly precarious situation such as domestic workers and sailors.Therefore, I request a vote in favor of this procedural vote.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: speaker.- Mr President, respecting the most excellent intentions, and probably sharing the opinions that are behind this request - since there are also exclusions that I have not been able to avoid and that I do not share - for the sake of parliamentary work, for the sake of a piecethat it has much more than that, I beg, please, to respect the difficult balance that has been achieved in the negotiations, that this request is not accepted and that we vote on the text without weakening it.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: speaker.- Mr President, taking advantage of the fact that this is the last text of this mandate - because I promise you that I will return - I want to thank absolutely all of Parliament, all those who have been against or in favor.I want to thank my entire team, the Romanian Presidency and Mrs. Thyssen for having marked this milestone in the history of the construction of social Europe because, with all honor, I take this last text with me as the best memory of my passage through this magnificentinstitution.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker.- Mr President, simply to say that there have been three years of work, hundreds of meetings, two attempts to reform this Regulation in the last sixteen years, a single agreement that includes thirty different regulations, and, therefore, ask for a favorable vote toan agreement that has been a fragile agreement but that has reached a great consensus.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - (NL) Mr President, I am relying on Rule 59 (3) of the Rules of Procedure, because I think it is imperative that we go back to the Commission proposal, Annex V, Part E. And I do that in the clothes of Dutch fishermen.Because if we are going to accept the trialogue proposal, we will kill these kinds of families.These families work with pulse fishing.That future is being turned away for these children and grandchildren - those children and grandchildren have just been discussed.That is why we must first vote separately on the amendments.I urge colleagues who support that to stand up now.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: You are well supplied.The boat is missing.(The president counts the raised hands).Perfect.Reassure yourself.Yes, indeed, more than thirty-eight deputies.Well, we are going to put Mr van Dalen's proposal to the vote, by show of hands.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, it is nevertheless extraordinary, this vote is one of those which has the greatest impact on European public opinion!It was a vote for ecosystems, for artisanal fishermen, against the lobbies of money and industrial fishing, and this vote was extremely important!We have talked about it in all your countries.So I ask this Parliament to keep its mandate and keep its promise for ecosystems and for artisanal fishermen across Europe, against the industrialization of fishing and against financial fishing!(Applause)

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker.- Mr President, simply to show my position against Mr van Dalen's request.For one simple reason.Because what he intends with his amendment is to nullify the tremendous majority agreement of this House to finish banning electric fishing.That is the mandate that we have and it is the mandate that I ask that you vote on, and therefore vote against Mr van Dalen's position at this time.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to stress the importance of the regulation we just adopted today. I say ‘vital’ importance because it serves in preventing terror attacks being carried out with the use of homemade bombs, and hundreds of lives of our citizens, compatriots, our Europeans would have been spared over the last five years if we had had stronger restrictions on explosive precursors.  It was a difficult but urgent task to regulate the online sales of precursors, but we did it, and the proof for that is 100% approval of the document in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) vote, which is a manifestation of general support for this result. Again and again, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their spirit of good cooperation and their support in trilogue negotiations and all the colleagues for their cooperation.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Speaker.- Thank you President, with the adoption of this regulation we are putting a further step in the policy of managing the migration phenomenon.I thank the shadow rapporteurs who supported me in this process and, with a great sense of responsibility, allowed the rapid adoption of the regulation and I hope to return for the next term in this European Parliament, in order to continue the work I have done in this mandate withgreat sense of responsibility, thank you.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! I'm not saying goodbye. I'm not saying goodbye. I am still fighting for a very strong European Union. That is why I would like to ask you to vote for this regulation that we have before us, because it will help to save thousands of Europeans from death in road accidents. It will save thousands more people from serious injuries. Thanks to these new systems - thank you very much for your support - that we have negotiated and will be installed in newly produced vehicles, our European roads will be safer, not only for drivers and passengers, but above all for all vulnerable road users. I am thinking of pedestrians, cyclists, etc. And finally, the last sentence. Road safety is just one of many examples of how the European Union contributes to saving our lives, to better common safety on our roads in a very specific way, to the safety of Europeans in our daily lives. And those who want to leave the European Union will understand this only after the damage. We speak loudly and proudly about everything that we achieve. (Applause)

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: With this we conclude the voting time.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! We are very proud of having an internal market, so that we, all with 500 million consumers, can become richer and hopefully also safer. But it does not create growth and security if not all countries manage to implement the rules in the same way, but instead speculate in making the rules so that it just benefits the individual company itself. I have several times been a rapporteur in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs on precisely the reporting on how our Member States are able to implement the rules we make. And it is - despite the fact that most people should have learned the rules in the Union by now - to see how some countries are constantly pulling and pulling it, even outright obstructing the implementation of the rules that should actually secure the internal market. It is not enough that we have to follow the same rules if we are to have the same prosperity and the collegiality, the camaraderie that the Union demands in the internal market.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I have decided to support a directive that has an important goal, which is to protect those who have learned of EU infringements and will draw attention to them.They therefore decided to report this breach.It is in the public interest and it is therefore appropriate to also protect these persons concerned from falling victim to retaliation.However, this public interest could conflict with other legitimate interests of employers, and I therefore consider it right for employers to set up internal processes by which employees can discreetly report this breach.At the same time, this directive remembers small and medium-sized enterprises, which do not complicate their lives.I also agree that employees must first use these internal regulations.I believe that the directive will serve its purpose.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!I would not be speaking today if it were not for yesterday's debate.Two situations in particular worried me.The first is the disregard of this directive, of this proposal, by the extreme forces which, in short, want to put many actors in public life into a situation where, in short, there will be impunity.But the second element was even more important.Well, I am paying attention not only to the need to protect whistleblowers, but also to fight against those who are false whistleblowers.It seems to me that we must pay attention to the fact that among whistleblowers there are those who unjustifiably, I emphasize, often unjustifiably attack economic entities or natural persons, leading to their destruction, either financially or mentally.I draw your attention to the necessity of this balance sheet, the right balance sheet.Otherwise, the damage may be more than good.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: - Mr President, we have come a long way. The European Parliament had drafted a very protective text for whistleblowers, but the Council had maneuvered to empty its substance and it took the very legitimate excitement of the European populations for these maneuvers to fail. Whistleblowers will therefore not be required to notify their superiors before disclosing information. In addition, those close to them, as well as those who have contributed to the manifestation of the truth, will also be protected. A controversial point remained, and that was the ban on disclosing classified information relating to the protection of defense secrets. We understand the prejudices that led to this limitation, but we can only have in mind the situation and the revelations of Julian Assange, whom I am thinking particularly today, or of a Chelsea Manning, who by violating these principles have enlightened international public opinion on criminal acts, which had been perpetrated for example during the Iraq war. So the basics are there. The text is good, the whistleblowers are protected and we have done our job.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, breaches of Union law are one of the elements that anti-Europeanists use to fuel people’s frustration with the institutions. Numerous right-wing politicians have tried to capitalise on the fact that Union law is not perfectly designed, but no law is exempt from weaknesses. We must give our citizens major freedom and protection while reporting such weaknesses.  If we want people in the EU to be more engaged and participative in European politics, we must give them the instruments. So it’s us, the partisans of a strong and integrated Europe, who must take the lead in this fight.  Maladministration can manifest itself in multiple forums, starting from word—based relations, in the management of EU funds. In every possible case the reporting person must be covered by guarantees. That is why, colleagues, I voted in favour.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, there comes a moment when you realise you’re one of the longest-serving Members in this Chamber. I’m old enough to remember the Tillack affair, when a German journalist was arrested, had his notebooks, his private papers rifled through, because he had been exposing fraud in the anti-fraud authorities. Nobody, by the way, rifled through the private papers of the alleged fraudsters. I’m old enough to remember the Marta Andreasen affair, when an accountant was brought in to clean up the Commission’s accounts, discovered that in some cases they weren’t even using double-entry bookkeeping, and the reaction in the Commission was to fire her. Why does this happen? Well of course, all organisations become interested in protecting their own position. That’s human nature; it’s not exclusive to Brussels institutions. But I think it is exacerbated by the intimidating fervour, the almost religious belief that people have in the European project, that makes them think that the ends justify the means and that critics can be legitimately silenced. Tackle that and you’d solve a great many problems.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - (FI) Mr President, the reporting of irregularities, such as misuse of funds and other property, tax evasion and other thefts and crimes, is a precondition for tackling the problems that exist. If those who detect abuse can rely on the proper handling of reports, they are more likely to report as well. In this case, criminal activity, which may cause even large financial losses to society as a whole and to the public interest or to an individual company, will be investigated in a timely manner. I consider it important that whistleblowers can report either within the organization or directly to the authorities. In both cases, they are protected from possible retaliatory measures, such as dismissal or reassignment. I am very pleased that we have the protection of irregularities advertisers finally received the whole of the EU minimum rules on ta. In many countries, there is no legislation at all so far, which is why I hope that the directive will be implemented as soon as possible in all Member States.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I too would like to welcome this legislation, which finally unifies this protection at European level, because indeed many countries did not have this protection enshrined in their legal systems, and we should be primarily interested in protecting the use of European funds. Fraud is really real. We have experience in the Czech Republic with the misuse of European funds. I think that whistleblower protection is really important. We must give them the tools to fulfill their mission, of course, to ensure direct contact with the institutions and the confidentiality of such negotiations. I would also like to point out that the other party, who is possibly accused of these frauds, should also be protected, because the possibility of abuse is very shabby, very thin. The line of exceeding a fair interest in this information and the possibility of unjustified accusation is indeed very thin. I would like us to think of the other side as well, in the case where someone is setting up criminal investigation authorities in this way.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would like to say here that the cross-border distribution of collective investment funds has a clear pro-European reason for the legislation. We sometimes vote here on legislation which, I think, is not entirely in line with what the European treaties say, that it can be regulated at European level. But here the cross-border element in the distribution of collective investment funds is unquestionable. We have approved amendments here, which establish a level playing field for collective investment undertakings, and, of course, remove obstacles to the free movement of units and shares of a collective investment fund. The aim is to create more uniform investor protection, while there are still obstacles that prevent the managers of these funds from enjoying this free movement. So I am glad that we have made this progress, it is a barrier-free Europe that I support, and I am glad that we have succeeded in this task during this parliamentary term.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! More and more people are saving up for their old age in pension schemes, and more and more people are undertaking to invest the money in the shares that they, for either financial or moral or other reasons, find is what the future should be built on. Both their personal finances and society as a whole. It is basically good that more people are taking personal responsibility and can also do so through mutual funds, where you gather the funds and thus have a greater financial muscle to invest. But it also creates some challenges, and we have seen this in the free movement of capital. Especially in relation to private individuals who venture out into the large jungle market, where you invest yourself. That is why we need some very clear rules for transparency and transparency and for consumer protection, so that people have some fundamental guarantees when they put the economy into the investment funds. This directive lives up to part of it, but not enough, and that is why we refrained from supporting it.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! When I ask for the floor in this debate, it is because of the very general problem we have with the Basel Committee. It is, after all, fundamentally good that the countries of Western Europe have come together in a council where we can jointly make some rules for the free economy and the rules for the free movement of capital, etc. But there is a tendency, especially here in Europe. Parliament - in the EU - is far, far too submissive, far too responsive to everything that comes from the Basel Committee. The Americans, for example, can well understand and manage to say no when the demands that the Basel Committee puts forward for negotiation do not fit into the American model. We in Denmark, for example, must repeatedly fight for what is the very core of our economic system, our housing market, etc., namely the mortgage system, simply because it does not fit into the way people think in the Basel Committee. There I could well call for the next parliament here in Strasbourg and Brussels to have a little more will and power to say no when the demands coming from Basel do not fit into our European or our Danish system.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, in the case of this report, I voted in favor, I would like to justify my vote here.We also addressed the consequences of the financial crisis of 2007-2008, which did not solve all the problems associated with the stabilization of the European banking system or the reduction of risks in the financial sector in general.We addressed the issue of counterparty credit risk, leverage and net stable funding.Of course, I agree with the amendments approved by the European Parliament.It is about making information and reporting available to entities operating in the financial sector.I would like to emphasize the scope of the leverage effect that this legislation brings.It is mainly based on not having the effect of excessive leverage during the rise, which I think is a very positive measure, which is why I supported this report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the capital requirements regulation and directive to propose revisions and address continuing challenges to financial stability. The risk reduction measures proposed will improve conditions for investment in goods and services and strengthen the resilience of EU banks. The revision of requirements for smaller banks will positively impact small and medium enterprises (SMEs). I am supportive of more flexible lending conditions for small and medium enterprises, supporting their growth by treating smaller banks in a proportionate way. I support the focus placed here on risk sensitivity. It is a highly important factor in building stability and ensuring a robust and strong European economy post—crisis. There is a good balance struck here between reducing risks while continuing to encourage funding and investment. Mr Simon and his colleagues have done a good job.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, bonds secured by a state guarantee are a mechanism that cannot fix the problems that exist in the functioning of the euro area. There should be, first of all, the institutionalization of Eurobonds and beyond that there should be changes in the way quantitative easing works. Mr. Draghi has illegally excluded Greek government bonds from the regulation of quantitative easing. In the same way, it has also excluded the bonds of Greek companies from the quantitative easing, as a result of which there is no increased liquidity in the Greek economy itself. An economy that was dismantled by the troika. At the same time, there should be other regulations so that countries that have problems — such as Greece — can breathe. That is why our movement, "Greece - The other way", proposes a special relationship between Greece within the European Union and the eurozone.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I support these amendments to the Solvency II Directive. The introduction of more refined tools in this area is to be welcomed. Establishing notification and collaboration platforms will facilitate information exchange between national and supervisory authorities. This is just one of the proposed tools for encouraging convergence and cooperation in the insurance field. I’m in favour of this consumer-focused approach to supervision. Improved communication between Member States, balanced by the supervision of data reporting service providers, will protect consumer interests. I support the strengthening of the single market for insurance as part of a broader, continued European integration in financial supervision while preserving a balance in the competences of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority and of national authorities. It’s a good balance here. Well done to Mr Karas and Ms Berès.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, well done to my colleague, Markus Ferber. The revision of rules concerning investment firms is good. The risks involved in the business model of investment firms must be addressed, particularly where the scale of these firms means that their failure poses a systemic risk to the economy. Because investment firms are exposed to much less credit risk than banks, they may act with more impunity. It makes sense that where a firm acts on a scale that could present a risk to the economy, it is subjected to the same rules as are applied to banks. The introduction of more tailored rules for smaller, non-systemic investment firms will also improve transparency and level the playing field.  Of course we have to remember that the flow of investment and saving across the EU is facilitated by investment firms. This is why the adoption of enhanced and tailored supervisory rules to better accommodate the business model of investment firms is important.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I am glad that this directive has finally passed a large number of votes.Of course, predictable and transparent working conditions are very important for employees, but also for employers, to be sure what and what information they have to provide to their potential employees and existing employees in what time frame.The trialogue agreement is therefore, I think, relatively balanced for both employees and employers, which is why I ultimately supported it.In particular, employees will be informed about their rights earlier and should also have easier access to stable employment.The final wording respects national legislation, which can take better account of the national specificities of the labor market, and should also not lead to a disproportionate bureaucratic burden on employers, which I consider to be very important.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!I have often stressed the strong delay of the parliamentary bureaucracy, but also of the Commission, when it comes to the issues raised.This time it gets even stronger.You have to remember that we are referring to the directive from 1991. It is a very long waiting time to react to the changing labor market.But on this occasion, speaking of work, I want to thank two groups.First, I want to thank the translators.It was not an easy term for them.I regard their work with appreciation and with great respect.Thank you very much.And the second group, this is the group you represent today, that is photojournalists.They work in the same conditions, all the time, with artificial light.They are a group that is noticed but too often underestimated.I would also like to thank the group of photojournalists.Photoservice, thank you very much.Good job.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I am delighted to support this report. Labour MEPs, alongside our Socialist and Democrat colleagues, have fought tooth and nail for these new rules that will improve conditions and give new rights to millions of workers on insecure zero—hours contracts and working in the gig economy. I am sick and tired of hearing from people who work hard, but don’t know from one week to the next, whether they will be able to afford to pay the bills. But the fight back has begun. An end to work cancelled at the last minute without compensation. Workers given enough to notice about new shifts. No more paying for your own training. Europe is changing because we are voting to make it better. A fair deal at work for the many, not the few.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, fair working conditions in the European Union presuppose the application of European Union law itself. Directive 1999/70 / EC is well known, which creates conditions for the protection of those who work in informal forms of work, those who work under fixed-term contracts. This 1999 directive insists that fixed-term contracts - insofar as they serve permanent and ongoing needs - should be converted into indefinite-term contracts. A classic case like this is the case of the "hostage" of the thousands of Greek teachers who work with the system of deputies and are - as I said - in "hostage". The Greek state must finally implement the 1999 directive and appoint teachers and substitute teachers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I welcome this directive establishing minimum rights that apply to every worker in the Union and I am glad to see that it contains a very detailed list of criteria that governs the relations between the employer and the employee. High working standards is one of the flagship achievements of the EU, but in some cases it can also become a factor of discrimination that creates first class and second class workers, which is unacceptable, by the way. Our citizens need greater predictability in employment contracts and we must finally stops the shameful practice of unlimited probationary periods. In addition to that, the European Parliament has taken a good step recently in abolishing unpaid traineeships but it’s the turn of the private sector to become fair and good.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I’m happy to support this report as an important first step in recognising the problem of zero—hours employment, and a first step to ensuring that those employment practices are brought under control. It is not unreasonable to ask for equal treatment of people at work regardless of the contract that they have. We know that the flexible economy is here to stay and it’s a reality, and therefore it’s essential that we regard framing the rights of those individuals as a trans-European problem because if it isn’t at the moment, it will be eventually. It is not asking too much to expect predictable employment hours and income from a job, it is not unreasonable to expect to be able to plan your budget. It is unreasonable to want exclusivity from people in that position of taking flexible work and it is unreasonable to insist that they pay for their own training. This nonsense simply has to end.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the demographic changes in recent years have led to greater diversification of the working population. Digitization has facilitated the creation of new forms of subordinate work, configuring new and more flexible working relationships. Today, one in four employment contracts corresponds to an atypical form of employment. The Transparency of Working Conditions Directive allows all workers to be informed of their rights and obligations from the very beginning of the employment relationship. Workers will have the right to agree with the employer the periods in which they are available and the methods of notice. On-call workers can no longer be fired if they turn down a job on very short notice, and employers can no longer prevent workers on a zero-hour contract from accepting an additional job from another employer. Today, therefore, we are putting on another brick of the social pillar, a step forward for a Europe at the service of the most vulnerable.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I finally supported this regulation establishing a new body for labor.Although I am not in favor of the creation of new bodies, I supported this proposal because there is a need to monitor the implementation of European law in the internal market in matters of posting of workers, compliance with employment legislation, and so on.I consider it important that this body, which has remained called the body, even though it is more of an agency, does not overlap with the other competences of other agencies.The implementation and oversight of the European Parliament will be important here.I would very much like the seat of this new agency to be in a new Member State, preferably in Slovakia.I think that would be a very affordable and good solution.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, for too many people the economy under this Conservative government is simply not working. I see this every day across the East Midlands: insecure jobs; zero—hours contracts; levels of in—work poverty going up faster than employment; demand at food banks increasing. There are parties who in the coming weeks will have nothing useful, if anything at all, to say about these issues, but I’m proud to have voted in this Parliament for measures to tackle insecure employment, to tackle low pay and exploitation, and to ban zero—hours contracts. So when people vote in a few weeks’ time, elect MEPs – Labour MEPs – who are committed to contributing positively and constructively in this place, committed to working here in the European Parliament to tackle unfairness and inequality, and who will ensure people in all our communities – whether they voted remain or voted leave – have hard—working, serious representation in this Parliament.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! On the occasion of the European Labor Office, we talked about increased mobility. This mobility has almost doubled in our term of office. It sounds like a compliment, but it is not a compliment, because it is associated with a huge number of problems that have built up over the course of this term of office and we, in short, have not been able to deal with them. I bring this to your attention. But I would like to take this opportunity to thank my PPE political group for their cooperation during these five years. It was not only easy cooperation, but it was a source of satisfaction. And I would like to thank my colleagues, both those in Brussels: Ms Justyna Szczepańska and Kamil Maj for a very good job, as well as those who worked in Wrocław: Agata Marzanowicz, Bartek, also Janusz Dzikowski, Ania Mądry. I want it to be heard in this House because they have really done a job that has helped me fulfill this mandate properly.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, instead of launching a European Labor Office, the European Union should consider - in particular with the Commission - the implementation of existing legislation and bring to justice those countries that violate European Union law. I return to the implementation of Council Directive 1999/70 / EC for the umpteenth time and call for its implementation, as I said in my previous speeches. I call for the implementation of this directive in the case of substitute teachers. Of the 80,000 teachers, 20,000 are deputies, are being held hostage, are being exploited by the Greek State and must finally be appointed. These people can not be under pressure to achieve their re-employment next year. There must be a final settlement in this case.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the European Labour Authority is a long—awaited measure that we need to complete our social pillar. We must guarantee the freedom of movement of workers and their equal rights across the whole European Union. However, it is not acceptable that this European Labour Authority acts as a simple information point. Currently, it’s designed to provide information sources and services on labour mobility, but it’s still unable to help our citizens resolve their problems related to work. In my opinion, the European Labour Authority must be able to enforce the measures to guarantee social cohesion and make sure that no unemployment arises from the new legislation at EU level. I am speaking particularly about the Central and Eastern European countries that still have inadequate social protection systems in case of unemployment. It must be one of the tasks of this new Authority to implement the social pillar and to guarantee that the new, high working standards do not lead to the first closure of enterprises and, as a result, the loss of jobs.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, social policy is still a crucial domain for national governments as well as social systems.I therefore did not support this text, not least because I do not agree with the creation of any other new European agencies or institutions.I also did not support this text because I am afraid that such an agency would try to interfere in the national labor law of individual states and also affect social systems.This is something that, in my opinion, would go beyond European law, because it does not really belong to the European Union.We have twenty-eight, soon twenty-seven economies, that are different, we have states that are relatively rich and relatively poor, and it is not possible to try to iron them in this way into one legal framework.That is why I could not support this text.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the statements by the Council and the Commission on the post-cyclone situation in Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe (2019/2684 (RSP)).The Council Presidency is a little late because it is still on hold in the committee meeting.That's why we're taking the liberty of changing the order a bit today.Commissioner, you have the floor!

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like first of all to express my personal condolences to the families and friends of the hundreds of victims in Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe. Definitely our thoughts are with the millions of people affected by this devastating disaster.  I have said it many times in this room: Europe is about solidarity. Europe is about solidarity not only inside Europe, but also outside Europe. So we stood by the side of all three countries, with emergency funding, with in—kind assistance, and with experts on the ground.  Allow me to summarise our response, our European response, to this catastrophe. First, funding. Just a few hours after the landfall of the cyclone, we released an immediate package of assistance of EUR 3.5 million, to support access with air services to cut-off areas and hard-to-reach communities and for immediate shelter, water and sanitation. On 9 April, we mobilised an additional EUR 12 million in humanitarian assistance for the three countries to provide shelter, water and sanitation, food, health and psychosocial support. This brings the total EU humanitarian assistance to over EUR 15 million. Second, in—kind assistance. With separate funding of EUR 4 million we helped to deploy through our excellent instrument – the EU Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM) – relief items and in—kind assistance offered by nine EU Member States: Portugal, Spain, France, Austria, UK, Luxembourg, Germany, Italy, and Denmark. I am really grateful to these countries. In parallel, we produced and shared 57 Copernicus satellite maps upon the request of Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi. Third point, on expert teams. We immediately deployed eight EU humanitarian, epidemiology and hydrology experts to the ground, to conduct assessments and support the response in the three countries, including to the recent cholera outbreak, unfortunately. In addition, a civil protection team of 13 people was deployed on 23 March via the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, and of course we also helped to deploy expert teams from our Member States. All of them are still in Mozambique as we speak and are helping to save lives on the ground.  Allow me to make a nominal reference to these teams because I strongly believe we have to show to our people that our teams can do excellent work on the ground. As I said, they are still in Mozambique because they are real heroes on the ground. Portugal sent one search and rescue and one medical team. Luxembourg sent a satellite communication team to help with connectivity in affected areas. Germany and Denmark sent a team to help with water purification – very important especially because of the cholera outbreak. Italy, Spain and Germany sent emergency medical teams and equipment, also very important because of the problem of cholera and maybe other diseases. So it is thanks to rescEU, our new system to fight against natural disasters, that we can help decisively the Member States to deploy assistance inside and outside the European Union. And of course help save more lives as our campaign inside Europe.  Since day one, my team and I are monitoring the situation in the three affected countries around the clock, 24/7. Through our Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC) – you will know about this – in Brussels and of course through our experts on the ground. We will continue to lead the international support efforts to the three countries, and you can rest assured that the European Union will do its best, our best, to support the longer-term reconstruction needs in the three affected countries.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Many Thanks!I can see that our colleagues from the Environment Committee have finally let go of the presidency.If you allow, we will wait a few seconds for Mrs Ciot to be here to tell us what she wants to say on behalf of the Council.

name: Melania Gabriela Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for giving me the time to present our points. I would like to thank the honourable Members for inviting me to address this important topic today. Disasters call for solidarity, for acting together in support of those in need. Disasters teach us valuable lessons. We should translate them into life lessons of strength and resilience. The tropical cyclone Idai and the subsequent flooding we witnessed in recent weeks have brought enormous destruction and human losses to southern Africa. Nearly three million people have been affected in Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe, and almost 1 000 people have lost their lives. Many are still missing.  In Mozambique alone, 240 000 houses have been destroyed, damaged or flooded, more than 160 000 people have been internally displaced, and over 4 000 cholera cases have been have been reported. Malaria is on the rise. In Malawi, the cyclone and the floods have destroyed many fields of recently planted crops. The potential loss of harvest will have a severe impact on the livelihoods of small—scale farmers who depend on agricultural production. Women and children are heavily affected. In Zimbabwe, the floods aggravated an existing severe humanitarian crisis caused by drought and a poor harvest. Food insecurity and malnutrition, which were already at alarming levels, risk worsening further. In all three countries, the humanitarian needs are enormous. They include food, drinking water, shelter, health and nutrition, as well as education, protection and logistics. The Mozambique Humanitarian Response Plan and the Zimbabwe Flash Appeal are asking for a total of USD 342 million. Currently only 23% has been funded so more efforts will be needed. As you know, the EU and the Member States mobilised quickly in response to these natural disasters. Humanitarian and civil protection assistance has been offered by the Commission and the Member States in support of the affected countries. In support of the EU response to this disaster, the Presidency of the Council took the necessary actions to raise awareness on the humanitarian and funding needs by opening a monitoring page on the EU’s Integrated Political Crisis Response arrangements (IPCR) web platform. In this respect, we moved the IPCR into monitoring mode. This has facilitated a constant exchange of information between the Member States, the Commission, the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the relevant EU agency on the evolving situation, the humanitarian needs and the EU response. We included the disaster caused by the tropical cyclone Idai on the agenda of the relevant Council working parties to facilitate in—depth discussions among Member States and the Commission. We welcome the fact that Parliament’s Committee on Development (DEVE) is also interested in discussing the situation. Our intensive exchanges through various channels have shown that the EU and its Member States were quick to react in response to this disaster. Member States have contributed extensively by providing humanitarian – and that means more than EUR 60 million – and civil protection assistance in kind, including shelters, food and power generators, as well as the deployment of water purification, satellite communication, medical emergency teams, flood rescue and relief modules, experts all provided through the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. A European civil protection team led by a Romanian expert has been deployed to Mozambique since 23 March 2019 in order to assess the needs and ensure coordination and distribution of the aid provided by Member States. There is very good cooperation and coordination on the ground. A number of Member States also made available military assets, such as ships, helicopters and aircraft for logistics and transport. Member States have allocated substantial amounts of funding to the humanitarian response. Thus, the necessary services are currently being contracted and implemented. We welcome the fact that the Commission has also allocated more than EUR 50 million euros for humanitarian support.  This brings us to the importance of implementation. Our close consultations with Member States and the Commission have shown that protection must be at the heart of our emergency response. Many families have been separated. Women and children are disproportionately affected by displacement, and women and girls are particularly vulnerable to gender—based violence and sexual exploitation. We also need to ensure that education can resume as soon as possible for thousands of children affected by the crisis. Lastly, we should consider using cash assistance wherever the circumstances allow for it. This is our analysis of the immediate needs and the emergency response. A post-disaster needs assessment will indicate the necessary action to address the long-term recovery needs. I now look forward to hearing your views and the information that the Commission will provide.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, my first word goes, of course, to the victims of this Cyclone Idai disaster in Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe and, made this statement, to populations that were already living very badly, in great misery and in great suffering, naturally that this is a tragedy that has consequences, I would say, very, very serious for all these families, for all these populations. I would like to leave three notes: the first, to say that, contrary to what has been said here, the European Union's reaction was late. The European Union was slow to react and is unacceptable. I would not do it with other countries, but, as we are talking about Africa and underdeveloped Africa, the European Union had a reaction that was slow at first. He should have done more, he offered little in the beginning, he is now responding well, but he failed in his initial response. Secondly, I would like to say that, finally, the PSD proposal, which incidentally scheduled this debate for the European civil protection mechanism, shows that it was necessary, that we still have to reinforce it and that it is now working good. Finally, I hope that this is not just an episode and that in recovery the European Union will be able to respond more readily and more consistently than the one it gave in the early days, in the early days, when it was weak, fragile and she was shy, and if it weren't for the Portuguese, she would have been even slower.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank the Commission, yourself and the countries that have responded, perhaps slowly but with effort, to this great climate disaster. The same disaster has affected three countries that together have the same size as France, Spain and Italy together. Is further reflection needed to understand that we are facing a phenomenon - global warming - that affects everyone and to which we must respond globally? The countries that are involved in this natural disaster, however, have another condition. They are poor countries. And the same climate disaster destroys those who have the least the most. Destroy schools, destroy homes and destroy health systems. In what may be my last speech as permanent rapporteur for humanitarian aid in this Parliament, I want to demand that in the next legislature progress be made in regulating the figure of the climate refugee. More and more people will have to flee from hunger and destruction as a result of natural disasters. And we have to give them hope that we can serve them by recognizing their rights, because those who have lost everything except their dignity cannot finally lose hope in us.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the aid mobilized by the European Union to deal with the catastrophe caused by Cyclone Idai and the subsequent floods in Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi is a drop of water in the ocean of needs that these countries and their populations are facing. The needs in terms of health care, food, housing and accommodation, communications, transport, logistics and various infrastructures, civil protection, among others, are immense. In the face of them, the 15 million euros and the team of eleven, only eleven, experts mobilized by the European Union fall far short of what is possible and what is necessary. They are a drop of water in the European Union's ocean of possibilities that fall far short of what several countries in the international community have already mobilized. In addition to the emergency aid, which must be increased without delay, it is necessary to think about the subsequent phases, the necessary reinforcement and possible reprogramming of the European Development Fund's appropriations, various sectoral supports, and measures such as more than just cancellation of debt.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! We have just listened to Greta Thunberg and heard what we need to do here in Europe to reduce our emissions. However, I think we need to talk about what we should do for all those affected by the consequences of our emissions - those in other parts of the world. For the extreme weather is becoming more and more violent and common, and it is others who are affected the most. It is great that we are providing humanitarian aid, but we must also prevent it. Then it is a matter of large amounts of resources that must go in to prevent, adapt poor countries to the new conditions. This is nothing new in Mozambique, for example. In 2000, there was a huge flood in Mozambique. In 2013, I was there after another major flood. I visited the Gaza province and aid projects where people have been moved further up so that they no longer live in the low-lying areas. However, so much more is needed. And now we have this huge flood in 2019. We must also work long-term. Mozambique has large gas deposits. It can give the country a wealth. But all that gas can only be turned against them in the end. So what should we do to get a long-term solution?

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Madam President, first of all, a word for the victims' families, a word of friendship also for all affected populations and above all for the Mozambican people. In good time we reinforced the new civil protection mechanism, but it is clear that additional reinforcement is still needed. The European Union is in solidarity internally and externally, but it is a solidarity that must always be reinforced, not least because climate change and its effects will be increasingly serious. And at this moment, despite the help that has been given, it is necessary to reinforce that aid, more means on the ground. There are more than a million children who are in a dramatic and emergency situation, which means that quick action is needed. And, after all this, it is still necessary to remember the reconstruction. Here, too, the European Union has to say, and it has to reinforce, for example, through the development aid of the European Development Fund, the amounts for the affected territories, and in particular for Mozambique.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Madam President, on the night of March 14, 2019, tropical cyclone Idai had its first impact in Mozambique, with torrential rains and strong winds, then headed for Zimbabwe and causing massive flooding in Malawi. The cyclone left a trail of devastation in its path. In addition to thousands of displaced people, it destroyed infrastructure and left several regions of Mozambique completely vulnerable and dependent on international aid. There were more than a thousand deaths in the three countries, 60% of which were in Mozambique, and many thousands were injured. Cholera problems have now started to cause new casualties, mainly in Mozambique. There is an unknown number missing. The European Union, as the Commissioner said, has already secured financial aid of EUR 15 million. At the request of Mozambique, the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism was also activated. The offers received came mainly from Portugal, but also from Austria, Germany, Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom. It is necessary to continue to help the affected populations and to take the consequences of what happened for the future. This is very important, drawing consequences for the future. International cooperation in disaster response and prevention is essential. Climate change is a reality that does not address GDP, geography, degree of development, wealth or attitude. They are a cross-cutting scourge that needs to be tackled with effective measures that will make it possible to comply with the Paris Agreement and preserve what is still possible on our planet. My sincere condolences and my total association with the Mozambican families in Malawi and Zimbabwe.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, a word to the victims of this cyclone Idai. A month after Cyclone Idai devastated parts of Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe, causing hundreds of deaths, thousands of people who have seen their homes and crops destroyed remain in overcrowded camps without access to essential health services. water, sanitation and health and are now subject to cholera, typhus and malaria epidemics. The affected population includes one million six hundred thousand children, who, in addition to the threat of these outbreaks, are now also vulnerable to exploitation and labor and sexual abuse. The European Union, which, in addition to activating its civil protection mechanism, although late, has already made available more than 15 million euros in humanitarian aid to respond to this catastrophe, must now also have the political will to make this solidarity compatible with implementation of the so-called Marshall plan for Africa, which also bets on an ecological transition model that makes it possible to convert the violence of these extreme natural phenomena into an exception, not the rule. European solidarity must be faster and more comprehensive. It is not enough to create mechanisms that later do not serve the purposes for which they were created.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Solidarity with the victims of Cyclone Idai in Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe yes, but in Mozambique it is necessary to understand that mismanagement and a spiral of corruption are at all levels, including at the highest political level, the worst enemy of the people trying to recover of the devastation and disease left by Idai. They are the enemy that the European Union and all donor countries must help to fight so that the people of Mozambique are no longer harmed, despite solidarity and emergency aid that was not, and should not have been, haggled. Corruption and impunity explain why the Mozambican authorities, including, incredibly, the PGR, have so far not accepted offers of help from the police and PGR from Portugal to locate the Portuguese businessman Américo Sebastião, kidnapped by government forces almost three years ago years in Sofala province. Corruption and impunity explain the murder of the French constitutionalist Gilles Cistac and the murders, torture, kidnappings and attacks on journalists and other courageous Mozambicans who dare to expose and criticize the hidden and ostensible debts that sink Mozambique. We will not help the people of Mozambique if we turn a blind eye to the corruption and impunity that ruled this sister country and hinder recovery for its sacrificed people from climate disasters such as Cyclone Idai and other disasters.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you so much again for this opportunity and this discussion. It is helpful to all of us and I am grateful for your sensitivity on this issue. We should not allow these disasters to be forgotten. The people in these countries – Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe – need our help, and I totally agree with my dear colleague José Manuel Fernandes and others about their proposal that we need to continue our support through development aid and to see real funding for reconstruction.  As I said, the European Union stands ready to continue its support towards the people affected by this cyclone through our humanitarian and civil protection and development tools. Cyclones, floods and disease outbreaks will continue to affect the southern Africa and Indian Ocean region. Climate change is here. It is not fake news, as I have said time and again. I totally agree with my dear colleague here from the Greens and my dear friend Enrique Guerrero Salom: yes, we have to deal with this problem and I am really proud because the European Union is leading by example in this field, especially because we are the most important factor to implement the Paris Agreement. Sorry, dear colleague, but I totally disagree with you: the European Union started its support to Mozambique from the beginning of the cyclone. We can go to our emergency centre in order to see the programme about our support. I am very proud of this centre, because when we had the request we started immediately. All UN agencies, all local NGOs and international organisations had already recognised European support to Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe. So thank you so much for this important debate. The facts speak for themselves.

name: Melania Gabriela Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this discussion on this urgent topic. The EU and its Member States are at the forefront of this international emergency response. The recovery and reconstruction phase will last far beyond our Presidency. When our Foreign Minister spoke to the Committee on Development in January, he explained that disaster risk reduction and the nexus between humanitarian and development assistance are the two key priorities of the Romanian Presidency in the field of humanitarian aid.  The scale of the disaster we are witnessing in southern Africa is a painful reminder that there is much work to be done in both of these fields. We need to ensure that our emergency response is complemented by our development cooperation efforts in southern Africa. When the emergency phase is over we will need to help the affected countries build back better and improve their resilience and preparedness for future shocks. As much as we would wish otherwise, the scale of climate—related hazard is only set to increase in the future. Let us all work together to ensure that the damage and loss of lives this could cause may nevertheless get smaller and smaller.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.Written Statements (Rule 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We are delighted that this debate is taking place, which only sins late. The aid mobilized by the EU to deal with the catastrophe caused by Cyclone Idai and the subsequent floods in Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi, is a drop in the ocean of needs that these countries and their populations are facing. The needs in terms of health care, food, accommodation, communications, transport, logistics, among others, are immense and, in the face of them, the 15 million euros and the team of eleven (only eleven!) Experts sent by the EU, fall far short of what is possible and necessary. They fall short of what several countries in the international community have already mobilized. Only Cuba, for example, with immeasurably less resources than the EU (but immeasurably greater in attitude and example), sent more than 40 doctors, in addition to the 372 health professionals it already had on the ground. The United Nations, through UNICEF, has already warned in particular about the particularly worrying situation of children. In addition to the emergency aid, which must be increased without delay, it is necessary to think about the subsequent phases, the necessary reinforcement and the possible reprogramming of the European Development Fund appropriations, of various sectoral supports, and measures such as, more than fair, debt cancellation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya (2019/2693 (RSP)).The High Representative is not here yet, neither is Mr Preda, nor Mrs Valenciano.Mr Tannock, first of all you will have the floor for the ECR.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, at a time when the two sides in Libya were supposed to be sitting down to discuss a road map towards elections under a UN-mediated settlement, we are instead witnessing General Haftar’s LNA troops battling militarily for control of Tripoli. The British Government has warned that any LNA advance on Tripoli would be very damaging for the political and diplomatic solutions on offer and risk a descent into more widespread violence and chaos.  Prime Minister al-Sarraj of the UN-supported Government of National Accord in Tripoli has given further warnings that the advance on Tripoli risks sparking a fresh migration crisis in the Mediterranean if the situation worsens. With reports suggesting that many refugees are being forced to join the various militias operating throughout Libya, these warnings should not go unheeded.  Given the complexity of the situation and the multitude of actors involved, the way ahead is fraught with hazards. However, the UN-mediated talks are the only peaceful options still on the table. The EU and EU Member States must therefore do all they can to support these talks with one united voice.  To those who see in General Haftar a potential strong man who could consolidate power and bring order to that chaotic country, I would urge them to pay attention to the various reports in the public domain that question such simple assertions. Significant military and political opposition remains in his way and there is little evidence to suggest that he could easily hold the country together in the longer term.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you very much, Mr Tannock.I see the High Representative is arriving.And I know that in this last week of plenary sessions that we are having in the European Parliament, everything is going haywire.We notice that back and forth, also in my schedule.I am delighted, Mrs Mogherini, to be able to give you the floor.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the recent escalation in Libya started at a moment just when the possibility for peace was becoming real. The LNA, led by General Haftar, attacked Tripoli at the very time when UN Secretary-General Guterres was visiting the country and on the eve of the National Conference, a conference that still has the potential to represent a new beginning for Libya.  The European Union has worked for almost one year together – very closely together – with the United Nations and the Special Envoy to prepare the ground for a Libyan-led and Libyan-owned National Conference that would prepare the ground for elections under the appropriate legal and constitutional conditions, and we have seen day by day the aspiration, the readiness, the desire of all the Libyan people, the citizens of Libya, to move their country forward, to turn the page, to unite and build unity and peace for a country that has potentially an enormous capacity to move forward, a lot of resources and a lot of potential.  The National Conference still represents the hope of an entire country. And just a few days before that military escalation took place, I was myself, together with Guterres, with the Secretary General of the League of Arab States, with the Chairperson of the African Union and with Ghassan Salamé, the UN Special Envoy, in Tunis at the margins of the League of Arab States summit, reaffirming the unity of the international community to support this Libyan-led, Libyan-owned political process that would have helped in turning the page and uniting the country in peace.  The offensive against Tripoli has been, is still, an attack against hope, an attack against the concrete perspective of achieving peace in Libya, and we have seen this happen before. When peace becomes a real possibility – concrete, possible – it is then also that we see that the resistance against peace gets stronger and more evident.  Now we are facing a protracted conflict with victims in high numbers, including civilians, and a stalemate on the ground. A situation that is blocked on the ground in terms of the line of the conflict, but still very active in terms of clashes, with the use of arms that we shouldn’t be seeing used in Libya.  This confirms what we have always known in Europe and in the international community, at least in recent years – the reason there cannot be any military solution to the Libyan conflict. If the war continues, it will only lead to greater suffering and if someone continues to seek military victory everybody will lose. The only scenario where the whole country, where all Libyans, in an inclusive and unified manner, move forward, is a negotiated political solution.  If the Libyan parties will not seek a win-win solution that the international community, starting with the European Union, would be ready to accompany and support – and the Libyan parties will not seek, I would say, a win-win solution – then all the people of Libya will continue to suffer and the entire region will continue to suffer.  I just spoke again today with the UN Special Envoy, Ghassan Salamé. Our work is joint and the European Union supports his work on a daily basis. Our support for his work, I would say, is even stronger today than it has ever been in the past, along three main lines on which the European Union and our Member States have acted united in these last weeks. First, to affirm the need to open humanitarian corridors as a matter of urgency and fully respect humanitarian international law. Second, to establish an immediate ceasefire, that I am sure the UN is ready to negotiate. Third, to go back to the political track with the holding of the National Conference as soon as possible to give Libyans, the Libyan people, men and women of all generations, of all cities and in the countryside of the country, the chance to outline their common way forward.  These are the three elements on which I am sure – for sure the European Union, for sure the United Nations – but I’m sure also the rest of the international community would be ready to support and accompany the Libyan people.  Let me add that it is not only Libyans, not only the region, that are suffering. Refugees and migrants trapped in detention centres are also at risk. We are working with the IOM and with UNHCR to evacuate them outside Libya or to move them to safer places inside Libya. The most recent flights that brought dozens of migrants back home safely and voluntarily left Tripoli just a few days ago. Our work with the UN agencies continues but obviously conditions on the ground are more and more difficult by the day and this is also why we call on all parties to allow the swift and unconditional evacuation of detention centres on the front line, as also requested by High Commissioner Grandi last week.  The work we have done together within the UN agencies, with the help of the African Union on the ground, with the help of the Libyan authorities on the ground, has brought in this last year enormous results with tens of thousands of migrants voluntarily and safely repatriated through the work of the IOM and those in need of international protection protected through the UNHCR channels.  The conflict in Libya, the escalation from the military perspective – I know that some in Europe perceive it as a growing threat of growing flows, but it also represents first and foremost a threat to the lives of those migrants and refugees that are trapped in Libya and whose lives are more at risk than others, and for which we have been trying with the UN agencies to work to try and save lives and to try and empty the detention centres. The military offensive is also making this work more difficult.  To conclude, let me restate very clearly, a swift return to the negotiating table is essential, it is still possible. We believe more than ever that the UN track and the National Conference are the only real opportunity for a peaceful resolution. The multiplication or the proliferation of different initiatives may lead to destruction that would definitely not be helpful at this moment. Humanitarian corridors and respect for international humanitarian law, ceasefire negotiated by the UN and a return to the negotiating table and the holding of a National Conference as soon as possible, with the full participation of the Libyan people.  I would like to add that when I say Libyan people, I refer to Libyan men and women. Let me take a moment to praise the Libyan women that have been sometimes in the shadow trying to accompany the political process, so far, in difficult conditions and I believe that the European Union, together with the United Nations, has an interest, as in every conflict we face, in promoting the role of women at the negotiating table and in the reconciliation process on the ground.  This is what we are trying to contribute to achieving, supporting the UN work, trying to unite the Europeans, and I can say that if in the past we have seen different approaches, I believe today that all European Union Member States understand that our common work is required to avoid Libyans turning in different directions and disaggregating the potential of unity through a political dialogue that is in their hands.  We stated clearly last time, last week, the European Union’s united position along these lines in the name of all the 28 Member States, and I would now appeal to all the regional players and the international players to unite in support of the United Nations’ work, in support of the political perspective for dialogue and unity in Libya, to avoid the Libyan stakeholders themselves finding external reasons for disuniting even further. On the European side, I can say that today they find a common, united front in support of the United Nations’ efforts to bring the parties around the table and define a common perspective for Libya in peace and security.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Madam High Representative, the situation observed over the past week in Libya is all the more regrettable as in February, a few weeks ago, an agreement was reached between the head of government, Mr. al-Sarraj, and General Haftar. This agreement provided, among other things, for the organization of general elections. Yet two weeks ago General Haftar abandoned this scenario. He decided to plunge the country back into a situation of chaos, thus endangering the civilian population. It effectively jeopardizes the prospects for a future for Libyans. It is clear that the ties with Russia and its support outside are much more important than the support it has at home, with the exception, of course, of military forces. I fully support what you have said: there are only negotiated solutions. We must exclude the military route and we need to put pressure on Haftar to give up the military route.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, there is really little to add to what the High Representative in this House has said, which is the only reasonable position for the European Union. It is true that some time has been lost and some Member States have been slow to understand that their support for Haftar was dangerous support, because ultimately Haftar will always propose a military solution. It is also clear that only dialogue among Libyans can begin to build a Libya with a certain stability and without war. It is also true that Libya is so close to us that it is our main obligation to keep the Member States united, speaking with one voice, supporting the United Nations special envoy, the United Nations, the European Union, the Union. African, to try to build a certain scenario of trust so that a political agreement is possible. And it is also true that we must not stop looking at the situation of refugees, which we had also started to manage in a positive way and which will probably become a new source of risk in the coming months. So, on the part of the Socialist Group, all our support for the work and efforts of the high representative once again.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, given that the war in Libya will not be resolved peacefully, I ask the Vice-President to speak clearly about the migrants trapped in the camps so that they do not come to us, evacuation is very limited, says the UNHCR.So I ask this: that the Sofia operation return immediately to equip us with ships to prevent shipwrecks.The Mediterranean is the only escape route, blocking it is a crime against humanity.May the Commission recommend the immediate cessation of returns to an increasingly insecure country, that evacuation be facilitated by humanitarian corridors in war zones, that water and food reach the detained migrants.Cochetel, from UNHCR, said on April 9 that in the Mediterranean there is no longer search and rescue, but search and return, and that the Union by giving Libya ships and technologies is complicit in torture, rape and slavery.I would like to know how you respond to this accusation.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! It was right that the EU has supported the UN-led mediation efforts for years. Nevertheless, this commitment to a peace process was unsuccessful. But anyone who now sees hope that one party to the conflict would win and that the escalation of violence would lead to more stability in the country is making a grave error. The EU Member States must not take one side or the other in this conflict. Instead, it must be made unmistakably clear to the conflicting parties that a solution can only be reached at the negotiating table. The ongoing fighting in Libya poses another threat to the refugees there. It is shameful that, through its cooperation with the Libyan Coast Guard, the EU is still helping to ensure that refugees are returned to camps in Libya where they are threatened with cruel abuse. The EU's attempts to improve the situation in these camps have had little to no effect. Now, in the current escalation of violence, everything must be done to save the lives of the people in these camps and get them away from there.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a proxy war is now being fought in Libya, and it is clear to everyone, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Russia, Turkey and Qatar have clear political agendas. Much more serious, however, is that this lethal game is also carried out by Member States, ignoring the position of the European Union and the United Nations, which are painstakingly trying to fuel and keep alive a peace process between the parties. The French declaration of extraneousness to Haftar's actions seems a clear case of excusatio non petita, accusatio manifesta. And some journalistic scoops in recent days are disturbing, which would testify the French opposition to a first version of the European declaration, considered too anti-Haftar, as well as the presence of French military advisers on the ground. And so, dear colleagues, I ask you: what game are we playing at? After the Aachen agreement, Macron's hypocritical Europeanism denies and debases European foreign policy for the second time. I categorically refuse to think that these eight years of Libyan nightmare have only served to replace one dictator with another more complacent. I denounce this hypocrisy, I ask that President Macron come to answer these questions in this Parliament, otherwise he will throw the mask once and for all.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the reports of the Italian services and also Sarraj's explicit declarations speak of an impressive number of refugees and in any case immigrants who are currently in Libya, hundreds of thousands ready to leave for the Italian coasts. It is a very serious problem, but it seems to me that the commitment presented by the High Representative does not give us much concrete hope on what the effective influence of the European Union and the Member States can be for a short-term solution and above all for to prevent Libya from plunging into chaos immediately or in the near future. The impasse in the fighting between General Haftar's army and the militias defending Prime Minister Sarraj could indicate a turning point, in fact it could again leave wide margins for politics and negotiation. Haftar did not break through the front, did not penetrate the heart of the capital and in all likelihood the defection of some militias from Tripoli on which he counted did not occur. So there is still a modest ten-day budget and defining the ongoing civil war in Tripoli is certainly an excess, perhaps wanted by environments that can't wait to exploit this pretext to maybe reopen the Italian ports to new waves of illegal immigrants. I believe that at this point it must be said that the failure of military options raises the prices and importance of a key country like Italy, whose government seems to me to have what it takes to be co-protagonist of a process of rebalancing and reorganization of a very important area for Europe, extremely dangerous if we think of the presence of jihadists, of Allah's warriors.
