But then I would say because in addition to having excellent relations with both rival leaders, we do not exploit the position of Italy, which has kept its embassy open and confirms itself as a country ready to play a preponderant role, a very important role that I think is much superior. to the absolutely non-existent one of this European Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the developments of recent weeks in Libya once again highlight the mistakes of the European Union's foreign policy in that country. The member states of the Union, which in cooperation with the United States overthrew Gaddafi in 2011, failed to help the country. They left her at the mercy of ISIS, resulting in a long and dangerous crisis. After five years of fighting, General Haftar's forces managed to occupy the last stronghold of ISIS in the city of Sabha at the end of January 2019. However, peace was not achieved, because on April 4, Haftar attacked Tripoli to seize it. Once again, the international community and the European Union seem powerless to intervene decisively in the whole situation. Libya is the country in Africa with the largest oil reserves and with them as a prize will continue the civil war, which will perpetuate the crisis, affect neighboring countries and fill the European Union with immigrants and terrorists.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Madam Vice-President, colleagues! This shows that we have had no Western and European strategy since the end of Gaddafi. We made a lot of efforts, but we never got it under control. You can't blame one person for that either, we're all to blame for that. But we see that this is a country that has traditionally always been divided into at least two areas: the eastern area, which Haftar represents today and which now wants to take over the other part - there are good historical reasons for that - and that is on the on the other hand, the legitimate government that was installed with the help of the United Nations and with our help, and which, despite all its promises, never managed to bring things together. I would also listen to the possibility - maybe my colleagues there can shut up, sorry - that we have to realize that maybe it is also good if European countries have different contacts so that both sides can be brought to the negotiating table. And when I look at the situation of the migrants there, then there are other groups that are not controlled by Tripoli or Haftar. And so the catastrophic situation of migrants is given. Ms. Mogherini, you can fix it, under these circumstances and hopefully under better circumstances, that Sophia and others will not only be used to save people, but that action will be taken against the human traffickers, who are the worst of all! I think we have to be more active again.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Madam President, once again regretting that there is an armed conflict in Libya, there are deaths again, and this time with a military threat. Perhaps, however, listening to Mr Brok and earlier to other colleagues, if we had focused more on Libya and the Libyan population and less on making Libya a theater of our European quarrels, we would surely have been much more effective. Hence, I especially support all the work that the High Representative is doing precisely to propose a truce solution, a conference solution, a multilateral solution that goes beyond European complaints. And of course, it would be very negative for Libyans and Libyans, for the victims that there have already been and their families, and also for the most destitute, which are immigrants, if we were to bring down our debates about Libya before the European elections. . I believe that the European Union must now be more united than ever, precisely after the proposals of the High Representative and the United Nations High Commissioner. And of course, let's stop, please, electoralism and above all about the lives of Libyans and Libyans.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, the crisis in Libya is escalating quickly, and we may face yet another proxy war in the making. I call for the immediate cessation of hostilities and a return to the negotiation table, and also an end to General Haftar’s aggression. If Tripoli falls, we may have to cope with yet another wave of migration – a really big one this time. We support the UN-led peace process, the efforts of UN special envoys, and also your efforts, Madame Vice-President/High Representative.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, the army of Marshal Haftar, the strongman of East Libya, has launched an offensive on Tripoli. The government of national unity, recognized by the United Nations, resists him at the cost of heavy fighting. The situation is worrying, as this destabilization of Libya risks having serious consequences for the whole region and beyond for Europe. It is therefore right that the European states call on the belligerents for a ceasefire. The UN mission, UNSMIL, unfortunately failed to bring about a truce. As for the UN Security Council, it is blocked by the rivalry between the United States and Russia. The United States wants to encourage him to call on Haftar to stop his offensive, while Russia would rather encourage him to call on the two belligerents to cease hostilities. The Libyan conflict is in fact the expression of a struggle for influence between these two great powers, but not only between them. Like Russia, President Macron's France supports Haftar, which Italy blames. Europe is divided and therefore does not seem able to influence events. I particularly regret that France is not up to the role it should have. She was the one who destabilized Libya in 2011 over President Sarkozy's reckless decision to overthrow Colonel Gaddafi. It is this that is compromising the search for a solution today. However, we would have to move forward together, as Haftar's offensive risks triggering a new wave of migration to Italy. An Italian intelligence report says at least 6,000 foreign refugees in Libya are already ready to embark for Italy. Ultimately, 800,000 migrants could surge into Europe, according to estimates by the Italian Prime Minister. Let us not ruin the efforts of the Italian government, which have reduced the number of migrants from Libya by 90% in one year. Let us move forward united!

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, after the fall of the regime of Colonel Gaddafi, Libya has experienced a situation of great instability that has clearly translated into a situation out of control in which the militias fight for control of the territory. Obviously, this has resulted in two governments, one in Tripoli and the other in Tobruk, and this offensive by Marshal Haftar has logically created further instability. What can the European Union do in this situation? As the high representative has pointed out, he must try to remain calm, that there is a cessation of hostilities, that at the same time the arms embargo is respected for both parties, that a humanitarian crisis such as the one is supported and avoided that is coming - even greater - that the emergency of the thousands of refugees, who are in a terrible situation, be addressed, and at the same time, that the European Union supports these efforts in favor of stability, in favor of order and of the Rule of Law through a dialogue among Libyans themselves, as the Secretary General of the United Nations, António Guterres, has pointed out on the ground very recently. We understand that all these efforts are vital efforts, Madam President, not only for the country but also for the region and for all the interests of the European Union, which has to act - as other colleagues have pointed out - in a united way, jointly, under the guidance and under the representation of the high representative and vice president.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Of course, we stand behind what the High Representative has told us: all military options must be stopped immediately, humanitarian ceasefires must be respected, and the parties must resume political dialogue and participate in the UN-led process. There can only be - correctly - a political solution; we agree on that. We can only seriously lead this debate if we make it clear to ourselves that it is our duty to make a very active contribution to improving the situation in Libya. Because we are partly to blame for the situation in this country. It turns out to be irresponsible to push dictators out of office without giving much thought to what will happen afterwards. Libya is an example of how the so-called West cannot act. But, Mr Epitideios, it was not the EU that wreaked havoc, it was individual member states and other allies who wreaked havoc. And it is the EU and the High Representative and the External Action Service that have tried again and again to make something of this situation. If we try together, we have a chance. If we just keep pretending we're doing it together, we won't have them.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - (NL) Mr President, European diplomatic unanimity is a requirement for a European position on the complex Libyan battlefield.Sadly, that is lacking.Paris and Rome have separate interests in Libya, a failed state, completely torn by two governments and countless militias.And if I may believe the Frankfurter Allgemeine that I opened this morning, even within the Italian government - it is a pity that Mr Castaldo has already left - there is a deep division over the Libyan dossier.Already within one EU member state. The great danger to the EU from the raging Libyan fire is formed by the jihadist groups, which, among others, are provided with weapons on a large scale by Turkey.This requires an urgent European containment policy.I therefore submit that to the High Representative, in all modesty.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, of course, Ms Ayala Sender, Mr Brok, Mr Castaldo and others have correctly described the situation of intervention which has brought us to this situation, but the Vice—President is here to talk about coping with this immediate situation now. The External Action Service came before our committee recently to talk about those coping strategies, and I really want to ask her – along with my colleague, Ms Spinelli – how we are going to do this now with the extension of Operation Sophia without the support of naval assets and other issues. Is there any scope here for flexibility? Are we going to change our views if this situation does worsen? And, of course – I mentioned Ms Ayala Sender – we saw Tariq al Seka detention camp ourselves, we know what you are also dealing with. This is not an issue of blaming anyone; this is an issue of working together. But the risk of thousands of refugees and migrants who remain trapped in detention in the Qasr bin Ghashir detention centre, and the communications we are all receiving having visited Libya, indicates that this is a crisis which will only get greater during this very politically tense period. So I ask you again: is there any flexibility in the approach? And please tell us about the Operation Sophia situation.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen,In the case of the Libyan tragedy, we are dealing with the next installment of this great drama that began in our immediate vicinity with the Arab Spring.This is a great tragic lesson for the next European Commission and for people who will also take responsibility in this Parliament.Our attitude towards partners in the world outside Europe should be judged on the basis of factual criteria, comparing their policies that can be proposed as an alternative, but not on the basis of our wishes or our ideology.We see this tragedy in Syria.Now we see it even stronger, escalating in Libya - the struggle for democracy to the last Syrian or Libyan.It's time to really think in terms of responsibility for people.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the time for divisions. The hell of Libya reminds us all of our responsibilities: European institutions, international bodies and national governments. The most urgent need is that of a ceasefire, but we must also all contribute to the search for a lasting political solution, a solution that has the long-term perspective of pacification, stabilization and reconstruction of the country. The toll in terms of human lives is very heavy. Schools, hospitals, refugee camps, still vulnerable people, many of them imprisoned in a situation of grave danger, were targeted, adding to the number of women, men and children who we cannot leave without international protection. Yet, in Libya's hell, there are still those who consider it a safe landing country. There are still those who speculate on people's lives in search of easy electoral consensus. Now more than ever, European governments must show responsibility and we must return to Operation Sophia. I ask the High Representative: is Libya considered a safe country? We need an answer and thank you for your work.

name: Alfred SANT
text: - Sinjura President, L-Ewropej għandhom id-dmir li juru kif l-akbar interess tagħhom fil-Libja hu l-ġid tal-poplu Libjan. Mhux iż-żejt. Mhux min se jikkontrolla d-daħla lejn ir-riżorsi minerali tal-Afrika entral. These are essentially described as essential substances. For the European Union, the country of origin has been identified as Libya. Sadanittant, li għandu bżonn il-poplu Libjan hi l-istabbiltà. Minnha, xi labor, tard jew kmieni, forsi se jinbtu l-paċi u d-democracy. Ming lajr l-istabbiltà, xejn minn dan ma jista 'jiġri. M'għandniex naħdmu biex fil-Libya, malajr kemm jista 'jkun, jitwaqqaf regime li jogħġobna, għal raġuni jew oħra. L-indħil barrani fit-tmexxija tal-Libja wassal għall-qagħda ta 'anarchija li teżisti bħalissa. F'dan, l-Ewropej iġorru responsabbiltà kbira. Għandna ngħinu, iva, f'kull sforz ta 'rieda tajba, li jsir biex il-forzi kollha fil-Libya, li jirrappreżentaw interessi ġenwini, ikunu mismugħa u mogħtija saħħa. Imma f'dal-proċess, ma nistgħux nibqgħu naqblu mal-paraliżi eżistenti f'kif il-poplu Libjan jista 'jipproċedi biex iwaqqaf istituzzjonijiet nazzjonali. For the purposes of this Agreement, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the Republic of Iraq, b'mod normal.

name: Kati PIRI
text: - (NL) Mr President, 147 people killed, 614 injured and 8 000 displaced. That is the toll of the latest fighting in Libya. Last month, Prime Minister al-Serraj and General Haftar almost reached an agreement to normalize the situation by holding elections. Despite this, Haftar began a deadly advance in the densely populated south of Tripoli on April 4. He has only one goal: to increase the pressure on al-Serraj. This is how Haftar thinks he will strengthen his position at the negotiating table. We must not tolerate this. Haftar's strategy disdains the UN peace process, leads to large numbers of civilian casualties, increases the number of migrants fleeing Libya and expands the playing field for terrorist groups. I therefore ask the High Representative to immediately call for a ceasefire and the withdrawal of Haftar's forces. Negotiations led by the EU and the UN must be given a fair chance. Only then will lasting peace be within reach.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, the recent military escalation in Libya, coupled with the social tensions in Algeria and Morocco, has had serious economic, humanitarian and security consequences for Europe, potentiating a new migratory exodus on the way to ours. continent and destroys the arguments of those who claim that Libya is a safe country for the return of immigrants rescued in the Mediterranean. The European Union, which this month announced a € 6 million humanitarian aid to Libya, cannot allow the powerful economic interests of some of its Member States in that country to prevent a joint position that calls on the warring parties in Tobruk and Tripoli the immediate cessation of armed conflicts, the respect for the humanitarian truce in the capital and the return to negotiation that will allow the establishment of a true executive of national unity that can guarantee peace and stability for all Libyans. Basically, as the High Representative has already said, giving Libyans a chance so that they can collectively decide their future.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, the situation in Libya is of the greatest concern: at least 150 people have already been killed, 614 have been injured and 18,000 have been displaced since Marshal Haftar's offensive. This is the third civil war since the overthrow of Colonel Gaddafi in 2011. The UN's peace efforts are being challenged by this offensive. It is certain that the division between the Member States of the European Union has prevented a solution to this conflict from being found, although some of them are nevertheless directly responsible for this situation - I am thinking of France and Italy . The population's dissatisfaction with the militia disorder and the constant security threat plays in Marshal Haftar's favor, but terrorist groups in Libya continue to exist and this new period of war represents a boon for these Islamist militias and for Daesh. This situation risks causing a new wave of migrants and further destabilizing the region - I am thinking in particular of Tunisia, which is only 150 kilometers from Tripoli. The situation is explosive and the European Union must take the initiative to return to the negotiating table to find a peaceful solution, in accordance with the reality on the ground, in order to avoid another bloodbath.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, Libya and the whole Arab Spring situation is a salutary lesson in Western intervention into nations that we don’t understand and places where we cause more harm than good. Look at what happens: chaos, refugees, deaths. And who gains from it? Despots rise; terrorist groups draw power. We need to understand that, in future, going in with bombs and military into places like this is not going to be the solution. Nine times out of ten, it will make it worse. We need to be there to talk to people, to help, to have diplomacy and to trade, but certainly, we must understand that the days of muscular liberalism and intervening in these places must be behind us. The only way forward is trade and talk.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I listened very carefully to the High Commissioner, as did the whole debate. We agree on the description of the situation, we agree that we are looking for a political solution that the campaign now being carried out by General Haftar can further destabilize the whole situation. But unfortunately, I feel that we do not have a clearer strategy, as some colleagues have said here, and that we lack concrete steps. So what do we do in this difficult situation, what do we try to do? Because I know that the situation is not at all easy for a political solution to this conflict to win. That is a question for you, Mrs Mogherini. I know that the situation is not easy and that it cannot be resolved in one negotiation, but I am afraid that if we only talk about it in the European Parliament and try not to do something actively for a peaceful solution, then the result will be what my colleagues said - another destabilization and the possible march of hundreds of thousands of refugees to Europe. And that's something we should address in some way.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! I would like to start by appreciating the efforts of the High Representative and the United Nations representatives. I believe that the sites representing this civilized world are doing everything possible. However, I want to remind myself of one thing: for knowledge, for better, more precise knowledge. Unfortunately, as a result of the lack of information, we are surprised and sometimes disappointed. We also incur financial losses from time to time. We are just more helpless in most cases. It seems to me that the services created at the moment should use knowledge of better quality, first of all so that we can operate in the long term, be more consistent, in short, more effective. I have spoken many times on many issues concerning precisely foreign policy, conflicts in Africa and the Middle East, and what is unacceptable to me is this element of surprise, part of this negative surprise, this great drama. Hence my postulate: let us acquire better, more precise knowledge.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Madam Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first of all I’m sorry that some of the colleagues that asked questions then left the room. I would have loved to answer these questions; maybe I will do that anyway.  Let me also say it is somehow sad that as we discuss something so serious on which there is no surprise – unfortunately for years now we have been struggling and working, not only the European Union, but also the United Nations and some of our partners in the region like the African Union or the Arab League, we have been struggling with the situation – it is somehow sad for me to see that in what is the last part-session of this mandate in Parliament there are more spectators at these debates than Members of the Parliament.  Sorry to say this, but I think this issue deserves a little bit more attention from your colleagues. But this is praise for those of you who are in the room. I would also like to thank you for the support for the work we have done in these recent weeks. It has not been easy in these recent years to build a common European position on this. You know that the starting points were not necessarily always converging but today we do have a converging European policy and action to stabilise the country, giving the Libyans, the citizens, the stakeholders, the different interlocutors, the different institutions, as fragile as they are, as conflictual as they are, the possibility to find their own way to unite in the country.  I want to thank this Parliament for its support for this work and I think that we have managed to achieve some good work even in these very difficult circumstances. I think we can be proud of at least two things. One is the support we have consistently given to the UN and the UN Special Envoys over time. They have always very much counted and relied upon the European Union support – politically, financially, diplomatically, and on the ground.  I was also very proud of the fact that our personnel went back to Tripoli before the personnel of most of our Member States. Recently this has changed, but I’m looking forward to having them back in Tripoli as soon as possible. I myself visited the premises of our offices in Tripoli, reinaugurating them after a long period of absence from the city, and I’m very much looking forward to this situation going back to sort of normal – probably it’s never fully normal in Libya and for sure not in these times – but I think that the Libyans know that the Europeans, and the European Union as an institution, have always been trying to help in a constructive, honest manner, again, both financially, politically and diplomatically. This has been also thanks to the support of this Parliament. The second thing I’m proud of in this difficult environment is the work that we’ve managed to finally start, and that we need to consolidate, on the detention centres, aiming to empty them and close them together with the UN agencies. I would have dreamt of a debate in this Hemicycle today on Libya and Libyans and not always on Libya and migration, because if the situation is deteriorating on the ground in the military escalation in Libya, let me tell you very frankly my first concern is for the human losses, for the deterioration of the perspectives for the political dialogue.  Obviously there is a risk of migration for the European Union but there is first and foremost a risk for the migrants themselves, for their lives, and I thank those of you that have raised this, because I think we have to take into consideration first and foremost the fact that every person we are referring to is a human being, and secondly that there is work we need to do with Libya and with Libyans for the sake of Libya and Libyans themselves. It’s not only a transit country: it is a neighbouring country, and it’s a country, that deserves to be treated as a partner from our side.  But having said that, yes, in recent years we have started to work with the UN agencies the IOM and UNHCR, and with the African Union, to empty detention centres, to combat the trafficking and smuggling of human beings, and in one year or so, we have managed to help the IOM and UNHCR, and in particular the IOM, to evacuate some 40 000 stranded migrants and refugees from the detention centres back to either the UNHCR centres from where they are then protected further, and/or to their countries of origin, also with the cooperation of the African Union and its Member States.  Obviously all of this work, as I was signalling, in a situation that is militarily escalating and is less secure on the ground, becomes more difficult. This is why I supported, and I reiterate this again, the call that Filippo Grandi made last week for all the parties to guarantee access to the personnel, the staff of the UNHCR and the IOM, to the detention centres and this work to be continued because it is extremely important and vital for their own sake.  Some of you asked me specific questions that relate more to our work on migration than to Libya. I’m happy to be very clear on that. I’m on the record already on these issues, I’ve been very clear. No, the European Union does not consider Libya as a safe country. This is something that not only I, but also other colleagues from the Commission, have repeatedly stated. This position has not changed, and it seems quite self-evident given the current circumstances.  Some of the Members of this European Parliament asked me about Operation Sophia. As you know, because this has not been a secret, my suggestion to the Member States was not that of withdrawing the naval assets. I’ve always argued in favour of the naval assets remaining in the international waters because they have proven to be a very effective deterrent for the smugglers and the traffickers. If arrivals from Libya to Italy have gone down by more than 80% in the last couple of years it is thanks to the presence of Operation Sophia at sea; among other things, but mainly that. Obviously you see the contradiction in terms of having a naval operation without naval assets.  Unfortunately, the decision of Member States has been in another direction. I still hope that they can reconsider their decision and decide to redeploy naval assets in the international waters. I think that in these particular circumstances it would make a lot of sense, not only to deter the activities of the smugglers and the traffickers of human beings across the Mediterranean, but also to fulfil the duties, the responsibilities, we have taken of implementing the UN Security Council Resolutions when it comes to the arms and the oil embargo control which obviously can be much more effectively carried out with a naval presence at sea.  I believe – and again I have no problem in saying this in this Hemicycle, I’ve said it publicly already, very openly – that without the naval assets Operation Sophia is not able to fulfil its full mandate in an effective manner, so I hope the Member States will reconsider this decision. It’s their responsibility, it’s their choice, and I hope they will come to different conclusions in the coming weeks.  I would like to conclude by saying that I would like to thank again all of you from the different political groups for the support for this strong call and strong work that we’re doing on the ground, not since yesterday but for years, together with the UN, for at this moment going back to a Libyan-owned and a Libyan-led political process that can be the only hope for the country to get out of this endless transition, out of the conflict, to de-escalate the military tensions and attacks, and to find a way to create strong inclusive institutions and peace in the country.  I believe that we can clearly say that, apart from a few voices, I have seen here broad support for this strong call, first of all for the open humanitarian corridors for delivery of urgent humanitarian aid, an immediate ceasefire, and a return to the political track and the convening of a National Conference under the auspices of the UN that we have prepared together, supported together, and that I believe still represents the hope for Libyans to have a proper country and a proper present and future.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The EU cannot excuse itself on what Libya became. Lack of Europe, absence of the EU, played into the hands of the Member States, entering in new and old rivalries for oil, arms and influence, after the fall of Gaddafi. Likewise UN, the EU neglected the need for SSR/DDR to ensure that any Libyan governance would be controlling a national chain armed command. PM Ali Zeidan came to beg us that help in 2013, as he also begged NATO, to no avail. Instead, EU MS, led by Italy, choose to fabricate a fake ‘Libyan Coast Guard’ which is no more than a militia torturing migrants and refugees to keep the human trafficking supply flourishing. No wonder that Haftar, backed by Egypt, the UAE, Saudi Arabia but also France just dared to disrupt the UN-organised National Conference in Ghadames leading to so much bloodshed and suffering in Tripoli. No wonder that, under Haftar, ISIS, Al-Qaeda, the Makdali and other terrorist groups will gain ground for sanctuary in Libya. They will come to haunt us, as much as they already haunt the people of Libya. Then, we all will deeply regret that there was no EU to act and help Libya.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the US decision to recognize the Golan Heights as part of Israel and the possible annexation of West Bank settlements to Israel (2019/2702 (RSP))

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, today we discuss with this debate two separate issues. Both originate from the war of 1967, but they are separate ones – on the one hand, the decision by the US administration to recognise the Golan Heights as Israeli territory, and on the other, the Israeli Government’s settlement policy in the West Bank. So let me tackle the two issues separately during this debate.  First, the US recognition of the Golan Heights. The European Union has a very simple and clear position that I’ve had the possibility to reiterate and restate in a very clear manner over time. More recently, the European Union does not recognise Israeli sovereignty over any of the territories occupied by Israel since June 1967, in line with international law and with UN Security Council resolutions 242 and 497 – and this also applies to the Golan Heights. On 27 March, I issued a declaration on behalf of all the 28 Member States, clarifying that this is the position of the European Union on the status of the Golan Heights. It has always been our position and it has not changed.  In parallel, the five European Union Member States who currently sit in the UN Security Council, which are the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Belgium and Poland, expressed this common position in New York in a joint stakeout. So we always ask for the European Union, as Member States, to speak with one voice. This was effectively done in this case, and this is not the only one. I have to say, I want to thank the five Member States that are currently sitting in the UN Security Council, because the practice of coordinating positions – they’re expressing these positions together, including with public press statements done jointly by the five of them, including meetings with myself to coordinate positions of the EU Member States in the Security Council – is more and more often. I think this is also fulfilling the responsibility that we, as Europeans, have to support the multilateral system and the rules-based international order in these times more, in general.  Coming back to our points on the agenda today, the second issue to discuss is the Israeli Government’s settlement policy. I will not comment on the potential policies of a future government that is not even established yet. What I can say is what we are seeing in recent times: over the past months, the Israeli settlement’s construction has continued. Only last week, plans for more than 4600 new housing units were advanced by the Israeli authorities. Right after the announcement, we issued a statement to repeat that we consider all settlement activity illegal under international law, and that settlements erode the viability of the two-state solution. In fact, the two-state solution is not only fading away; it is being dismantled piece by piece. I think it is important for us, the European Union – again, united in this – to say clearly that abandoning the two-state solution would bring greater chaos not only to the Holy Land, but also to the entire Middle East, which is already facing a very difficult situation due to the proliferation of crises we have seen in the region in the last years.  The next escalation of violence in Israel and Palestine could easily spiral out of control, and it would have tragic consequences in a region as unstable as today’s Middle East, not to mention the importance that the two-state solution and the creation of a Palestinian state consequently has for the entire public opinion in the Arab world – again, in a region that has known relevant turmoil in the last years. Our first duty, then, is to keep the two—state perspective alive and to preserve the possibility of new negotiations towards peace to take place. In order to be realistic and successful, any future plan for Israel and Palestine will have to start from the internationally agreed parameters, recognise them, and this includes the 1967 lines with mutually agreed swaps and the status of Jerusalem as the future capital of the two states. On this as well, the European Union has been united and very clear over the years and we will continue to do so.  The European Union will recognise changes to the pre-1967 borders only if and when agreed by the parties, including with regard to Jerusalem. This is a principled position, but it is also based on a realistic assessment of the situation on the ground, because the two-state solution is, first and foremost, essential for peace, but is also essential for security, starting from the security of Israel. It is essential for democracy, both in Israel and in Palestine and it is essential to guarantee a truly sustainable economic growth for both Israelis and Palestinians. And let me add – most importantly, even – it is essential for peace, security and economic growth for the entire region, starting from the neighbouring countries.  If the situation does not improve, it will get worse. That is the reality we have seen in these years, and in these difficult times I believe that keeping this perspective alive is the most courageous and the most fruitful contribution we can do and the best service to peace and stability and security in the region. This is what the European Union will continue to do in the coming months, with all those who are ready to engage towards a just and lasting and sustainable peace.  Starting from our Arab partners, let me say that in the last few months we’ve had the chance of meeting with the leadership of the Arab League countries both in the first-ever European Union League of Arab States summit in Egypt, and, with my participation, the third in a row to the summit of the League of Arab States just a few weeks ago. I can tell you that this position of the European Union on the two-state solution, but also on the Golan Heights, has been probably one of the main elements of discussion and is probably one of the main elements that brings together the Europeans and the Arabs in this difficult moment in our common difficult region. So I’m very much looking forward to continue working together with them on this specific issue that is so important for security and peace in the Mediterranean.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Madam High Representative, my group is opposed to this debate. The position of the European Union on the Golan Heights is very clear: in accordance with Security Council Resolutions 242 and 497, Israel's sovereignty over that territory is not recognized. You yourself recalled this, Madam High Representative, on March 27 in your statements. The Trump administration’s decision will not change the situation on the ground in any way, and the April 6 West Bank statement was made in the context of the Israeli elections. So see no reason to support the far-left electoral strategy of our Parliament. Our debate will only damage the credibility of the European Union as an actor in the peace process. But if we discuss it, we must also admit that the collapse of the Syrian state has created an even more volatile situation around the Golan Heights. If we want to have a balanced approach, we must also take into account Israel’s security in the face of the proliferation in the area of ​​Shiite, Syrian and Iranian-backed militias, such as Hezbollah.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, the truth is that what is happening between Israel and Palestine, the path that the Trump Administration has taken, taking Mr. Netanyahu by the hand, is nothing new. It is crystal clear what they are doing, although Mr. Preda is surprised. The problem is what we do. Why are we still so timid in denouncing what is, obviously, a transgression of international law. What we consent to to the Government of Israel and what we consent to in this case to the US Administration is outside international law. And we cannot require some of them to comply with international law and allow others not to comply with it. I get the impression that we are too shy because we do not know how to deal with a North American Administration that is clearly hostile to the European Union. I think one of my first speeches in this plenary was on the conflict between Israel and Palestine. And this is my penultimate intervention in plenary, and it is also about a conflict that is receding in its possibilities of becoming a path of peace, a situation that we are unable to manage, that produces enormous injustices and that will make the solution impossible of the two states in physical terms. We are going to continue claiming the two States in political terms, but in physical terms we will not be able to do the two States. And I think it's about time we raised our voices a little more.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, anyone who has visited the Golan knows how crucial this territory is for the security of Israel and its citizens. Anyone who has visited the Golan knows that nearby, on Syrian territory, Iran and Hezbollah have a military presence. Anyone who takes Iran and Hezbollah seriously knows that the Islamic Republic and its Lebanese terrorist ally are seeking the complete destruction of the Jewish state. Anyone who really takes this in is following the American example of recognizing the Golan as Israeli territory. And whoever does that contributes to the escalation in the region. Because the Israeli abandonment of the Golan really will not bring peace to the Syrian reign of terror. Those who recognize the Golan as Israeli territory also have a historical understanding of the Golan's centuries of biblical ties with the Jewish people. An appeal, Madam President, EU, including my own country, the Netherlands: Stop a selective interpretation of international law and recognize the Golan as Israeli […], like our ally - our ally, Ms Valenciano - the United States, that is doing. Those are allies.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Madam President, Madam High Representative, I am very concerned. I am concerned about the situation in Israel. Because I think we are receiving more and more signals that Israel is leaving the two-state solution behind. Prime Minister Netanyahu actually wants to expand Israel's sovereignty and annex the West Bank. We are, I think, really at a very critical point. I feel that the peace process is being unilaterally scaled back. And where in the past you could say that the United States of America helped build the international solution, I now have the feeling that they are increasingly accepting or perhaps even committing violations of international law. Hence, Madam High Representative, I would ask you to make our position heard more clearly, even louder, even more. We have voted on many resolutions here. It is very clear: we are opting for the two-state solution with the borders established in 1967, allowing Israel and Palestine to live peacefully side by side. Actually, we are now waiting for a position from the Trump administration, which we think will come up with a new plan. Yesterday, 37 heads of state and government addressed an open letter to you. I think this is an important signal. A very important signal from Europe, where we ask you very clearly: make our voice louder. Let us as Europe say even more clearly that there is only one solution. There is only one solution to get out of the conflict and that is that two-state solution. I ask you to heed this open letter.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, it is true that none of these situations is new, but it is also true that we have seen an escalation that is increasingly undermining the peace process in the Middle East. It is true that the annexation of Palestinian territories is already taking place, but it is true that it is now declared by the Israeli Prime Minister. And the question is very simple. I have no doubts about your position, Ms. Mogherini, but we have other instruments and, having the problem recognized as it exists, what are we going to do? What are the consequences? Because we have other instruments at our disposal, there are association agreements. Do we suspend or not suspend association agreements? The defense of the borders of 67, the peace agreement, is it to be just words and paper, or is it to take it more seriously? That is the question. We are decimating a people and agreeing, although that is not the official position of the European Union. And with this I want to end. Mr. Preda, on the day human rights are invoked as an electoral reason, we will be in very bad shape. I don't know how you sleep with a clear conscience. I do not sleep and I think it is our duty to defend human rights, whether they vote or not. Yes, you do have an electoral agenda. My agenda is the defense of human rights.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: There is no point in shouting to the other side of the hall here.Blue cards can be requested here, but since no one has asked for one, I will then move on to the floor.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank High Representative Mogherini for her words and for keeping the EU together and being clear in language.  But, up to now, it has cost Israel nothing to continue its old and illegal occupation – and you know that. We must go now from words to some kind of acts. I would remind you also about the letter – just mentioned yesterday – from former foreign ministers and prime ministers, saying that now something must happen. They refer to UN Resolution 2334 on now taking differentiation. That’s much more than labelling. Still peaceful and legal means, but we cut all connections with illegal settlements – that’s business, education, that’s everything. We now also want the list published of all the businesses working at the settlements. I’m sure that, if there is a price, we will help all our very important friends in Israel, as well as in Palestine, so that they don’t give up hope on the two states and they can still count on us, because words no longer help. You know that as well as I do.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, it is true that European foreign policy has never been so far removed from American policy as it is today. This is the case with the Middle East, but not only. For example, the United States has disassociated itself from the Iranian agreement that you supported, it has also disassociated itself from COP 21, and when it comes to Israel, of course, the United States supports the party. the most extreme of the Israeli government, particularly in deciding to change its embassy to Jerusalem considering it to be the capital. And now, with the United States' recognition of Israel’s sovereignty over the Golan Heights, the White House is sending international law and United Nations resolutions rolling. However, the Commission, supported by the Council, yesterday confirmed its willingness to continue its trade negotiations with the United States, which I consider to be a rogue state which thus flouts any current multilateralism. So what to do? You, Madam High Representative, have used everything that was in your hands, politics, diplomacy. But I think there are two tools that have not been activated: they are the trade agreements and they are the association agreements. It is only through sanctions that these countries, these states, will be able to react tomorrow to finally meet your wish, which is the two-state solution. This solution is farther and farther away today, far from the Israeli policy which speaks of annexation, but also far from the Palestinians who have lost all hope. I believe that Europe must take up the torch and be able to defend this two-state solution. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: question "blue card".- Dear Maria, you just said that the United States is a "rogue state".Don't you think that such statements are deeply damaging to the relationship between Europe and the United States?Do you not consider that the left wing of the Socialist Party and the far left, which insisted on this debate, are also responsible for the deterioration of our understanding and good working conditions with the United States?How far will you go to anger the Americans, dear Maria?

name: Maria ARENA
text: "blue card" response.- Frankly, dear Mr. Preda, dear Dan, the United States did not wait for the European left to flout international law.When Mr. Trump decides to put aluminum tariffs to ban the export of aluminum to the United States for security reasons, international law is violated, agreements violated.When the United States recognizes the Golan as being under Israeli sovereignty, agreements are flouted.So we cannot come and say that it is the European left that is fueling the bad understanding between the United States and the Europeans.Excuse me, but if you want to flatten yourself in front of Mr. Trump, this is your choice, not the choice of the European left!

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, you can be a friend of Israel, but that does not mean that every time the President of the United States has a new idea, the European Union has to run to change its positions.And that is true, Madam President, for the statute on Jerusalem and Resolution 478 of the United Nations Security Council, that also applies to sovereignty over the Golan Heights - Resolutions 242 and 497 - and that also applies to annexation.of settlements in the West Bank.All these unilateral decisions do is fragment and break the international consensus, hamper the already very complex peace process in the Middle East and make the doctrine of two states defended by the European Union, of two viable states thatcoexist peacefully and in the conditions of security to which both Israel and the Palestinian people aspire.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Madam President, dear High Representative! I am grateful to the High Representative and I agree with her that Europe must not follow the mistakes of US President Trump in breaking international law and recognizing the Golan Heights. With a Netanyahu election victory, it is unfortunately difficult to imagine progress in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. The incumbent Prime Minister is fueling the conflict with his announcement that he will continue the annexation of parts of the West Bank and insist on the claim to the Golan Heights, after he had already further divided the country during the election campaign. In these scenarios, the European Union must closely scrutinize its foreign and trade policy towards the Israeli government. Europe must not be available for permanent occupation or annexation. During Trump's presidency, the EU unfortunately lost the USA as a partner for a committed peace process with a two-state solution. I would now ask you to be clear on the question that the European Union must adhere to the international legal status quo of the embassies as well. Europe must not move its embassies to Jerusalem, as the US did. Here I also ask the current Council Presidency to stand by the side of the High Representative and Parliament.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President! The whole biblical history of Israel is based on the homeland of the Jewish people - "God's blessing for the people of Israel". Now, when we talk about the Golan Heights and the West Bank, we can only do that by taking Israel's security situation into account. But Europe made Iran strong. Iran invades Syria and increases Israel's overall risk in the Golan. The protection of Medina and Mecca is a matter of course, but when it comes to Israel, we suddenly speak a completely different language. As European partners, we must aim for a balance of powers and pave the way for peace - and only peace for the region - and the three central monotheistic religions around the world. And so, due to the overall situation, there is only one reliable partner in the Middle East: That is the people of the Jews in Israel, the only constitutional state there that has adhered to a legal system for thousands of years that comes very close to ours and as regards the security situation here and there - must serve as a very good example for us. UN resolutions against Israel have no basis whatsoever: the EU has done nothing similar against the expulsion of Jews from the eight hundred times larger Arab countries.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, even in this last plenary session we find ourselves discussing the American administration's overt support for a violation of international law by the Netanyahu government. Israel's claim to annexation of the Golan Heights, a disputed territory inhabited by 25,000 Arab Druze and 20,000 Israeli settlers dates back to post-1967 and the recognition of part of the international community of this claim and the construction of other colonies in the West Bank worry us. It is as if it had been decided that the "two peoples, two states" solution is now a chimera for intellectuals and not, instead, the only viable solution to stop a conflict that is now without end. My delegation stands for respect for international law, for respect for pre-1967 borders and for the recognition of the State of Palestine. I saw with my own eyes, in February 2016, how entire generations of men and women live and grow up with despair in their eyes, driven from their homes and trampled on their fundamental rights. We thank those Israelis who oppose this authoritarian and illegitimate drift, which crushes and humiliates the Palestinian brothers in the so-called only democracy in the Middle East. Resist, please, for you, for Palestine, but for the whole world.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - Madam President, therefore, the peace process has been in crisis for some time.The concept of two countries or two nations in two countries is also becoming less and less probable, and I can say that Israel's position in this context has changed considerably: the United States, the US military has left the region, Iran is increasingly aggressive, Israel is not recognized by politicians.key factors such as Hamas, and so on.However, I would like to appeal to the European Union to play a more proactive role in this process.By no means should we allow the United States to support Israel on the one hand, and the European Union to stand by Palestine alone.The European Union must be a key factor or one of the key factors, including the negotiator, and by no means just the payer.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, this House has the responsibility to keep a balanced approach, especially when we are preparing to enter an electoral campaign. It is a very good thing that we are talking about the Golan Heights this evening, but a debate about the Golan Heights must also refer to the grave security risk Israel confronts in the north. I should name Iranian entrenchment in Syria, Shia militias in Syria and the Hezbollah terror organisation. The EU, in order to keep a balanced approach, must also show commitment to Israel’s security.  Colleagues, correct me if I’m wrong, but I would say that this debate does not serve any purpose, as the situation on the ground is unchanged and the position of the European Union is well known.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, today we are hearing a number of accusations against the State of Israel and we have heard from our colleagues and a number of statements about the dire consequences that Israeli measures are having on the civilian population. I consider such statements to be ideologically manipulated. But let me say two fundamental questions about the whole thing. Israel has the right as a legitimate state, the right to defend itself. He cannot relinquish aerial and ground control of the Jordan Valley and the Golan Heights. Whoever you have been there, you know that this is a neuralgic point from which various hostile armies can easily attack the state of Israel, and it would be difficult to defend from there. We know from the recent past about the presence of Iranian Shiite militias in Syria and about Hezbollah terrorist operations. It is morally unacceptable for Israel to ignore these threats and take no steps to ensure its security and peace for its citizens. I will say so much about the debate on the territory of Judea and Samaria. The numbers speak better in favor of the Israeli presence than politics. Israeli companies employ more than 15,000 Arabs with an average salary 200% higher than that offered by the Palestinian Authority to its employees.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, following the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and the relocation of the US embassy there, the recognition of the occupied Golan Heights, which Israel snatched from Syria in 1967, is a major challenge. interests in the Middle East and Syria and support for Israel's criminal policy towards its rivals, primarily Russia, to control the markets for wealth at the expense of the peoples of the wider region. The responsibilities of the SYRIZA-ANEL government are also enormous, which, with the tolerance of the other bourgeois parties in Greece, washes the United States, NATO and the European Union and provocatively rejects the implementation of the Greek Parliament's decision to recognize the Palestinian state, upgrading —As the European Union— Israel's political, economic and military relations as if nothing were going on. Let the Israeli occupation of the Golan be stopped now, and let solidarity with the Palestinian people be strengthened for the immediate recognition of an independent Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital on the border in '67.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me restate clearly what I think I’ve already stated several times in this Hemicycle. The European Union sees Israel and the Israelis as partners and friends, it sees the Palestinians and the Palestinian Authority as our partners and friends, and we also continue to see our American friends in the United States as our partners and friends. This doesn’t mean that our positions or our policies are determined elsewhere. Our positions are determined on the basis of the conviction of what we believe is in the best interest of peace and stability in the region – which is also our European region – and on respect for international principles and international laws, and this doesn’t change.  Reaffirming clearly and in a united manner, as you mentioned, our position doesn’t mean being hostile to interlocutors or partners that, in the meantime, might change their position. It means being self-confident about the fact that we’ve always believed – and we continue to believe – that, first, ‘might makes right’ is not a good principle on which to base foreign policy. The idea that you can change borders with the use of military force is a dangerous one – in Europe, in the Middle East and elsewhere. This is why our position on the Golan Heights has been so clear, because we believe that international rules, international law and international standards must be upheld, and that this is a principle that it is in the interest of everybody to uphold in a very consistent and coherent manner.  If you think of the situation in the Middle East, but also if you think of the situation in Europe or elsewhere, international law affirms it very clearly: borders cannot be changed by military force and this is a principle behind which the European Union will continue to firmly stand in a united manner.  I think this unity and this clarity together have made us relevant in upholding a principle and a situation in very difficult circumstances. The image I have in my mind at this moment when I think of the Middle East, where you actually do not have a process at all – it’s not that the process is stuck, you do not have a peace process currently – the image I have in my mind is that of – I don’t know if this is an English expression, but in Italian we say ‘put your foot in the door to avoid it banging’. It doesn’t mean opening the door wide and it doesn’t mean being able to restart a peace process.  To tell you the truth, to start a peace process that is consistent today we would need to have an international and regional consensus on the parameters – on the need to have a two-state solution – and you would need to have political will on the two sides and also in Washington. On the European side, it’s full and it’s clear.  What we have to avoid today, together with our partners in the region, starting with the Arab countries – and I think in particular of Egypt that has such an important role both in the Arab League but also on Gaza, and of Jordan that has such an important role on the holy places – what we have to avoid is that this trend continues, consolidates and becomes irreversible to a point where, as Elena Valenciano mentioned, the two—state solution becomes impossible, and avoid that the dismantling of the two—state solution gets to the impossibility of achieving it whenever the political will is there.  I know that this is a minimal approach, but you have to be pragmatic and realistic when dealing with foreign policy. I remember that very well. When I started my mandate, my first visit was to Israel and Palestine. I said back then – almost five years ago, four—and-a—half years ago – that it is possible to solve this conflict, and it is true. I still believe it because the international parameters are clear, but without the political will of the parties and without international consensus – which we don’t have at the moment – on those international parameters, I do not see this process producing an outcome in terms of a two-state solution. We Europeans know very well that if it’s not going to be a two-state solution, it’s not going to be a solution. I believe that the Israelis know that perfectly well, the Palestinians know it perfectly well and the region knows it perfectly well. So I believe that, as friends of Israel, as friends of Palestine, and as friends of the region – let me also refer to the Arab Peace Initiative that I still consider a good basis for negotiations – the European Union is convinced, and will continue to be united and clear on this conviction, that it is in the interest of the Israelis, the Palestinians and the region to continue to have in mind a two—state objective and a two—state solution. That is also vital. I would like to say this very clearly for those in the Hemicycle who have raised this. It is also vital for the security of Israelis and of Israel as such.  I think I will stop here on this point. I am looking forward to the continuation of our debates on the next points.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. "This debate doesn't make much sense today." At most, it can be “used” by those who are interested in it to further fuel the anti-Israel sentiment. As the political and military situation has not changed, the EU's position on Israeli-Palestinian relations and the Golan is well known. We also know that Donald Trump recognized Israel’s supremacy over the Golan primarily because he wanted to help Netanyahu’s election campaign. However, this did not help the situation in Israel much. At the same time, we all know that the Golan cannot be debated without taking into account Israel’s legitimate expectations of its own security. It is the primary duty of every country, every nation, to ensure the security of its citizens. This is also the case for Israel, whose northern borders are particularly vulnerable. Iran’s presence in Syria, the terrorist attacks of Hezbollah, to name just a few. If we do not take these aspects into account, we will only have a one-sided sham. Just as the hypocrisy that leads nowhere is the claim that a precondition for peace is a return to pre-1967 borders. Debates like this one today are only good for not having to face political realities, not having to look for innovative new solutions. All this does not mean that there should be no democratic solution to the Palestinian problem. But it is not such meaningless debates that lead to a solution.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, on the situation in Sudan (2019/2703 (RSP))

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the people of Sudan are asking for change. For four months now they have demonstrated, not only against the dramatic increase in the price of essential goods, but mainly and also for freedom, peace and justice. The image of a Sudanese student – a girl standing in a white dress on the roof of a car, speaking to the crowd – has already become a symbol. She’s now called the Sudanese Statue of Liberty, and we Europeans want to support this aspiration to liberty. The Europeans want the people of Sudan to succeed. We want their call for liberty to be heard and to translate into real change for a country that has already suffered too much. Last week the Sudanese military took over power and put Omar al-Bashir under house arrest. As you all know, al-Bashir has been indicted by the International Criminal Court, and we have repeatedly asked to execute the arrest warrant. The military leaders initially announced a two-year transition to be led by a transitional military council, composed of different strands of the security forces. This announcement was quickly rejected by both the protesters and the opposition parties. They asked for a concrete guarantee of a much quicker civilian transition. We have supported this request, indicating that a military council would not provide the right answers to the people’s demands and requesting a swift handover to a civilian transitional government. Over the last few days, the military establishment has tried to bridge the gap with a certain show of goodwill. The head of the transitional military council was changed; the head of National Intelligence and Security Service resigned; and some political detainees were freed. These steps have signalled that there may be space for a negotiation. It is clear that, without a true transition, the crisis in Sudan is likely to continue. To prevent such a scenario, there has to be a swift handover to a civilian transitional government with real decision-making authority. This would open the way for a peaceful, credible and inclusive political process to finally address the Sudanese people’s demand for political and economic reforms. Our first priority must be to prevent further violence. We welcome the lifting of the curfew established on the day of the coup, and we call on all parties to refrain from the use of force and any form of provocation. We also expect further confidence-building measures to be taken by the transitional military council, such as the liberation of all remaining political detainees and the reform of the security sector. Security forces must be held accountable for the deaths and the abuses that have occurred in recent weeks and months. These measures would help create the right environment for meaningful political negotiations, so that all parties – including a transitional military council, the Sudanese Professionals Association and other political actors – can cooperate in good faith. It is also important that the opposition remains united at this critical moment. Let me conclude by referring to the fact that in our statement, in our positions last week, we referred to the position taken by the chairperson of the African Union Commission, Moussa Faki. Today, I can only subscribe to the position taken yesterday by the African Union’s Peace and Security Council. The African Union has demanded the immediate handover of power to a civilian-led transitional authority, which should happen in the next 15 days, and this transitional authority, once installed, should ensure an inclusive and consultative process to agree on the exact modalities of the transition towards free, fair and transparent elections. And, just like our African brothers and sisters, we want the transition to be managed by civilians. So we fully support the African Union demand and position on this issue, as on many others. As long as this is not the case, as long as the transition is not managed by civilians, the European Union will not recognise the legitimacy of the transitional military council. But as soon as a civilian transition takes place, the European Union will be ready to accompany it, both politically and also economically.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! Africa is in motion again. In Algeria and Sudan, people in peaceful protests and with great courage achieved what previously seemed almost impossible: They forced two dictators to resign. But people want more: they want a free society based on democratic principles. Everyone knows how difficult it is to achieve that in your own country after decades of tyranny and crimes against humanity. And the situation in Sudan is still very fragile. Nobody knows whether the ruling military structures in the country will open the way to a civilian government. The EU is challenged to learn from the past. We need a unified, coherent stance from all Member States, chaired by the High Representative on Sudan, in order to work with the African Union to support the civilian forces in Sudan so that Sudan does not become a second Libya. First of all, the political prisoners are to be released, and in addition, the previously oppressed minorities are to be granted autonomy rights.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, High Representative, we are facing an expectation of change. Change widely demanded by the population of Sudan, mainly led by women and by some sectors of society that represent the ability of that country to progress. But this situation of thirty years of authoritarian government is superimposed on a situation of humanitarian crisis of the first dimension. Around seven million people are at risk of severe hunger in the country. There are about two million internally displaced people and there are more than one million refugees from neighboring countries. All this in a context where Eritrea, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Somalia and Djibouti make up probably the most important humanitarian crisis in the world. A group of around twenty million people in dire need. And it is to this population that we have to respond through humanitarian aid, but above all by supporting the achievement of a stable regime and the achievement of peace. Therefore, I support from my group the position expressed by the Commission - or by the High Representative - to support a civil transition, not to recognize a military government, to continue pushing Bashir to the International Criminal Court and to call for the end of the repression of doctors, doctors and fundamental elements to fight against the humanitarian crisis.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the youth of Sudan is the population of Sudan, with an average age of 19 years old, and the youth raise their voices, with a clear role for female leaders like Alaa Salah, whose image you referenced. They managed what the international community did not see through: the ousting of Omar al—Bashir, a dictator sought by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity – crimes against the Sudanese people. Let the events in Sudan be reminders of: one, the fact that repression cannot outlast calls for liberty and an end to corruption and injustice; two, that dealing with dictators in the EU’s short—term self—interest for, for example, managing migration, is a bad gamble against the young people of North Africa and the African continent; and three, that transitions are both very hopeful but also very hard. With institutions, democratic movements, civil society and other efforts crushed, state resources systematically robbed at the cost of education to sustain the security apparatus. So to avoid a repetition of the so—called Libya scenario, we should invest in democracy and peace and prevent the militia but also the military from taking the space left open and recruiting desperate youngsters. As one of the demonstrators, Salma Ali, said to The New York Times: we’ve cut off the head but the body is still alive. As this is my last debate with you, Madam High Representative, I wanted to thank you for everything you’ve done. I think we need a stronger Europe in the world more today than we did five years ago, and I wish you all the best.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I hesitated a lot before knowing what I could, what I had to say in this debate that the European United Left has asked to support the Sudanese people and express our solidarity, in particular vis-à-vis these thousands of Sudanese women who have been demonstrating peacefully, without respite since December 19, despite the repression, dozens of deaths, hundreds of injured and thousands of arrests. I have often had the opportunity, as you know, Madam High Representative, to denounce here the relations of the European Union with the dictatorship of Omar al-Bashir. But it is no longer time to judge the past, or it is too early to do so. It must be a question of the future and for this the European Union must, beyond the demand for a civilian government, put all its weight, like the African Union and the troika, to move towards a new transitional government. No, the current military government cannot be recognized - only Russia, the Saudis and the Emiratis have. His number one is and has been in charge of the Sudanese forces in Yemen, and number two is that of the Rapid Forces, the former Janjaweed. They must be tried like Omar al-Bashir and all those responsible for crimes against humanity in this country. We can, you can help them. You can help the Sudanese people in their demand for real regime change, so that it does not remain a palace revolution. Stability in the region is really at stake.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, High Representative, we’ve heard already Sudan has experienced massive changes in the last weeks: Al-Bashir ousted after 30 years; temporary military leader installed and no free media; food prices beyond the reach of many; political opposition blocked for years; and to top it all, the second-highest inflation in the world. However, the people, and especially the women, of Sudan are resilient and have aspirations and are hankering after real change. They rightly have reservations about the military regime and want to have a transition towards proper civilian government, following free, fair and transparent elections. The EU and this House should show solidarity with peaceful demonstrations, and we should have concerns about two years’ length of transitional military council and need to work quickly to ensure that impartial media are set up and restrictions on internet are lifted. High Representative, I welcome your statement that only credible and inclusive political process can meet the aspirations of Sudanese and lead to political and economic reforms the country needs. But my questions to you are: what mechanisms and alliances are you proposing to move democracy on in the short term, and also, will the EEAS examine closely the financial flows towards Sudan, as the US did when it fined the French-backed BNP Paribas USD 9 billion for violating US sanctions against Sudan? And can you confirm that the arms exports towards Sudan from the EU are still prohibited and this prohibition is fully respected?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we have repeatedly discussed Sudan. Recently, everyone has denounced al-Bashir's policy and called on the European Union to take action to end this situation, to stop the oppression of human rights and to grant freedom to Sudan. In the end, as always, the people themselves provided the solution. Thus, with the demonstrations, he first managed to overthrow al-Bashir. However, the regime forces and others remain in power, as martial law has been imposed. This military government is a given that it cannot go through the democratic transition and it certainly cannot stay. That is why I believe that maximum pressure must be exerted by the European Union in order to hold democratic elections, to be able to solve the great political problems in Sudan and, consequently, the huge social problems in the country, but also the wider humanitarian crisis problems in the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after thirty years Sudan is about to turn the page, the impossible is finally possible. Omar al-Bashir, the dictator president wanted for years for the genocide in Darfur was finally dismissed on April 11, but the fall of the general at the hands of the army did not stop the popular mobilization. Too strong the sense of mockery of the demonstrators in front of the formation of a military executive, albeit provisional. The fear of falling back under the clutches of a despotic regime like that of al-Bashir is too great. The protests continue and will not stop until the more than legitimate demands of the opposition are met: immediate transition to a civilian government, justice for the demonstrators killed by the police and above all the surrender and trial of all the leaders of the former regime for complete eradication of Bashir's "deep state". In light of these events, I therefore applaud the High Representative's approach. Only a credible and inclusive process can meet the aspirations of the Sudanese people and carry out those reforms the country needs, but to trigger this process an immediate transfer of power to a civilian government is necessary. Europe must ensure that this transition takes place peacefully, with all our political and economic weight. We cannot allow a military government to be recognized. We cannot allow even more innocent blood to be shed.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: - Mister President!I think the most important thing in Sudan is that we take care of the Sustainable Development Goals, particularly Goal 2 - Safe and Sustainable Food - and Goal 6 - Clean Water and Wastewater.We could fight many diseases by developing strategies here and applying InvestEU as quickly as possible and of course target number 7, namely renewable energy.If we combine that in rural areas with small and medium-sized enterprises, then we would have achieved a lot, and I believe that this could give a future that could also enable Sudan to be stable as in Europe.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank all colleagues for their very clear support for the position we have taken in the work we are doing. I would maybe answer a specific question that was raised about what kind of strategy and what kind of alliances we plan to put in place. We are already building to try and achieve this transition towards a civilian government and free, fair and democratic elections. As I said in my opening remarks, as always whenever our positions converge – which happens often – our first interlocutor here is the African Union. I refer to the very clear position that the African Union has taken in these days, which I believe has been extremely important, also considering what some other colleagues were mentioning: the fact that these changes in Sudan are part of a bigger shift, that is a mix of hope and challenges in the broader region around the Horn of Africa, with some winds of change that are blowing also in other countries. By that, I mean the opportunities that the opening of talks between Ethiopia and Eritrea is bringing, but also the very severe challenges both from a security perspective and from a humanitarian perspective that the region is still facing.  Our role, I think, with the full support of this House – and I know I can speak here for the Commission but also for the Council – is that of accompanying this democratic transition, bringing it hopefully to a civilian outcome, and working hand—in—hand with the African Union and the countries in the region to try and make sure that this happens and that, in particular, the women and the young people of Sudan find their aspirations met in this transition. But, as with all transitions, it is difficult; there are some opportunities, but also some risks and some challenges.
