I would like to thank and congratulate all my fellow rapporteurs, thank the Commissioner and the Romanian Presidency for their excellent work in record time, and, as rapporteur for the ENVI Committee, I am honored that the proposal in our committee's report to prioritize cancer research and innovation has also been approved at Council level. I also emphasize that 35% of the total budget of the 120 billion program will be aimed at combating climate change, a recommendation also from the ENVI Commission. I also welcome the support of colleagues to increase the budget for health, from 7.7 to 9.12 billion euros, which will allow us to address the enormous health challenges more effectively. In particular, innovative solutions in the field of oncology are vital for future generations, given that every year 35,000 new cases of cancer are registered among young Europeans.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Mr President, I would also like to thank all the negotiators on behalf of the Committee on Transport for an excellent report. From the point of view of the Committee on Transport, there are three particularly important issues here. The first of these, of course, is that we need to increase European research and development funding at the level of all Member States. But increasing the Horizon program by 50% to EUR 120 billion is also an important priority for the Committee on Transport: in order for our industry to remain competitive in the future and to be able to meet major global challenges, we need to invest more in research and development. Secondly, the Committee on Transport is very much in favor of emphasizing climate objectives in the future research program. From a transport perspective, carbon sequestration and digitalisation in particular are key areas for investment in European research. Thirdly, we consider it a very good solution not to have a separate cluster for transport, but to try to operate as cross-administratively as possible and to make use of energy, climate, transport and digitalisation and industry funding. It is important that basic research and innovation are in this good balance in the future as well.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Policy. - (NL) Madam President, rapporteurs, a breakthrough: after 15 years of working, both in the Committee on Regional Development and in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, we can now also use the regional funds more flexibly for the scaling up of Horizon projects, without including a state aid assessment per Member State. to fill. I see Horizon 2020 as the latest Airbus, top class worldwide. And the regional funds can be that landing strip for the necessary upscaling. Synergy in practice. At least five percent, but it could be more. It's about billions. Then invisibility. The United Kingdom - the number one research country - has shown that we do not reach the citizen, the voter, at all. The EU must operate differently. Of course, researchers from the ivory tower, communicate differently, let patrons speak. Let the stars shine. By giving the floor to Horizon users and benefactors locally and internationally. What is being accomplished? Finally, it was my pleasure to be able to work on this. Results such as the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, the European Innovation Council and the Widening projects invested with money: that is a great result. I enjoyed working on it. Thank you.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. - Mr President, the European Horizon program, if successful, will be crucial to the EU's competitiveness. We really need a bold program to make European science and innovation do well in international competition with, for example, the United States and China. As rapporteur for the Committee on Agriculture, I specifically emphasize the importance of agriculture, food, natural resources and the EUR 10 billion in research funding allocated to them. More needs to be done in research on the seas and inland waters, forests and agriculture, also in order to break free from fossil society. The EU must take care of its own food security, both globally and globally, and take responsibility for ending the famine, including worldwide. However, the most important thing is still inappropriate, namely the budget. As the trilogue negotiations continue next autumn as part of the multiannual financial package, it must be ensured that the 10 billion earmark proposed by the Commission remains at least at this level.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Media and Sport. - Mr President, the Horizon Europe program will be the fundamental instrument in creating jobs and economic growth, in strengthening the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises and in encouraging partnerships between universities, both in the Union and in third countries, and this will, in some way, attract new talents and young researchers, thereby strengthening the European Research Area and in this way we will also avoid brain drain. However, in terms of scientific and technological development between the various regions, a more balanced geographical inclusion will be needed, particularly with regard to the outermost and less developed regions. I insist again that the distribution of resources, including for science, within the Union, must be more just. The priority will be based on the creation and diffusion of knowledge, both in terms of technology and skills with basic solutions in fundamental and applied research, but also considering the social and human sciences and the arts as noble forms of knowledge, under penalty of making the sterile human genius. Those countries that, with their political leadership, believe in science and place it at the service of an enlightened and critical society will also be more successful.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Indeed, the Commissioner is right. We talked about implementing this program as ambitiously as possible and also quickly. But why is it important? This speed. We want money, for example for social innovations, care for the elderly, telemedicine, etc., to flow to our universities, our industry, small and medium-sized enterprises as quickly as possible. In this framework program, missions were introduced. This is a very new and good approach. Congratulations to the Commissioner. Because thanks to this, people will understand more easily what it means to be a zero-emission city, to fight cancer. All these ideas are understandable to people, and that's what we meant. It is important that the European Innovation Council that is introducing this program should be as successful in the future as the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. Because we do not forget about old solutions that we should continue. Finally, it is important that we extend this program as much as possible through special funding to countries that today do not benefit greatly from this program, such as Poland. It is important to use the full potential of the European Union. So I congratulate the Commissioner, the Romanian Presidency and my colleagues from the European Parliament. Really great job ladies and gentlemen.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in my opinion, Horizon Europe was born with the necessary ambition to face the social and economic challenges of the European Union: based on excellent science, improving competitiveness, but with an inclusive nature. For this reason, it introduces, at the request of Parliament, the need to measure social and not just economic impact. Science has to solve inequalities and challenges and not generate new inequalities. Strengthen gender: Europe needs all its talent and we cannot do without women. Therefore, it is an operational objective, it has a specific budget line and also reconciliation measures. It also reduces the gap between the regions; aligns social challenges with priority budget lines and with clusters; reinforces health, the fight against climate change, the social and human sciences, the digital world, the creative industry, the blue economy, food security or scientific diplomacy. But I do not want to stop highlighting the role that has been given to SMEs, 99% of the non-financial business sector in the European Union, key to improving the competitiveness of the European Union by reducing the innovation gap. Therefore, I have only to congratulate the entire team of the Commission and the European Parliament that has made this great project possible for the European Union.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, Dan Nic and Christian Ehler, for their tremendous commitment and excellent cooperation with us, the shadow rapporteurs. Thank you very much and I really appreciate it. Between 2021 and 2027, Horizon Europe will be a key tool for supporting science and research and contributing to the deepening of cooperation between the Member States of the European Union, and not only in this area. I am very glad that even though we had little time, we came to a balanced conclusion. I am equally pleased that my colleagues have accepted as my proposal to include support for research in the so-called coal regions. I consider this necessary to manage the regulations and objectives that we have decided on in the field of energy in the European Union. Thanks to Horizon, it will also be easier to support the sharing of experiences with economic and social changes associated with the decline in coal mining. I also consider the area of ​​the so-called widening countries to be very important. In the future, we must focus on a more balanced use and remuneration of researchers across the European Union. Only in this way will we make full use of their potential and prevent them from leaving for other science centers around the world.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Mr President, we have already discussed the ninth framework program in detail. A crucial vote is scheduled for tomorrow. If we approve the first reading of Horizon Europe, we will ensure continuity for scientists and innovative entrepreneurs in Europe. I would like to take the opportunity to say how unique this mood is. Together with the Council and the Commission, we have brought about the unimaginable in Parliament and found an agreement in the trialogue. Whereas eighteen months were negotiated for Horizon 2020, we only needed four months for Horizon Europe. I attribute this to the constructive cooperation and understanding that existed between the three institutions. I would therefore like to express my special thanks to Commissioner Carlos Moedas and his entire team for assisting us in these negotiations. I would also like to thank the negotiators of the Romanian Presidency. The Romanian Presidency is a strong example of how the smaller states play an important role in Europe. In the interest of the European citizen, in the interests of the future of research and innovation, I want to continue to argue for EUR 120 billion in the next parliamentary term. But in the meantime, I call on you all to endorse this important agreement.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I also want to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for their unbelievable work and the way in which they have integrated the proposals of the different parliamentary groups, the Commission and the Council for the way they negotiated this dossier to reach the agreement we have here today. I believe in an inclusive science, that is egalitarian and cooperative between researchers and that promotes innovation. But I also know that there is no innovation without basic knowledge, there is no innovation without social sciences and humanities. We reached a compromise, which is a compromise, that is, it is not perfect, each and every one of us fought for what we thought was essential to integrate in this collective commitment. I talked a lot about the social sciences and humanities, about the rights of scholarship holders who do research in European projects, about greater equality of access to funds, I supported these proposals with a proposal to have a goal with regard to research dedicated to combating changes climate change. What is relevant - and with this I end - is that I believe that this program represents the best that the European Union has at this moment and, for those who know me, you know the meaning of this statement. The last, last word is to say that most of those responsible and those responsible for the success of this negotiation are hidden in the back row, but we know who they are.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: for the Verts / ALE Group.- Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen!Fifty years ago, Neil Armstrong set foot on the moon.The moon landing in 1969 was not only a great step for humanity but also the result of a visionary and courageous research policy behind which the whole of society gathered.The equivalent of our generation is to contribute to solving the climate issue with the help of research.Tomorrow we will vote on Horizon Europe, the EU's research and innovation program.There have been long and intense negotiations, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues and the Commission for their good cooperation.The investments that Horizon Europe entails make us better equipped to meet the global climate challenges we face.If the budget negotiations go our way, Horizon Europe guarantees that at least SEK 420 billion is invested in renewable energy, sustainable mobility and green industries.It is now that the green paradigm shift begins.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as shadow rapporteur of both legislative files, I am satisfied, because we have brought the right balance between research and innovation activities, because we have pushed for a particular focus on climate change, we have supported transversality and inclusion of social sciences and humanities in all program activities and, moreover, we have guaranteed adequate support not only to universities and research centers, to startups, but also to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises through a tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, in fact. However, we are disappointed not to have allowed free access to data which is still severely limited by the defense of private commercial interests and we are dissatisfied with the marginal importance attributed to incremental research. As regards the structure of the decision, the areas of intervention identified in the pillar global challenges and European industrial competitiveness make it possible to act on health, culture, safety, including natural disasters, but also on industry, climate, energy and mobility, on food, natural resources, agriculture and the environment in order to improve the well-being of European citizens. The work on Horizon Europe will have to be completed in the next legislature, but what has been done so far brings together the fundamental elements for supporting the cornerstones necessary to build and improve our future, namely research and innovation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am delighted to see after a tough negotiation our rapporteurs were able to get an agreement on the Horizon Europe programme and I congratulate colleagues Ehler and Nica. And also congratulations to Commissioner Moedas who, in his exuberance I thought was going to congratulate everybody in Parliament, but congratulations, Commissioner, to you for your good work. This is a hugely important programme for the next multiannual financial framework (MFF). It will build on the achievements of some of our recent programmes, such as Horizon 2020 and FP7 and help us to reach our targets and create jobs, particularly in the areas of renewable energy, food production, digital etc. This is the most ambitious research programme ever and will strengthen the EU’s science and technology capacity and, indeed, leadership in a number of areas. I particularly welcome the significant budget that has been allocated to agriculture and food production. Producing sufficient sustainable and sufficiently healthy food for all, now and in the future, in Europe and globally, while facing extreme weather, resource scarcity, changing markets and demanding consumers will require innovation and technological development. Horizon Europe will ensure that our future food production will be more sustainable and competitive, protecting the environment and catering to various needs. Also I welcome the strong support being given to climate action and also research into cancer. This is a fantastic result for this Parliament. I look forward to voting for it tomorrow and seeing Europe further driving leadership in this area border—wide.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement on Horizon Europe is certainly good news for European citizens. We will have a richer, more effective and simpler, we hope, and more transparent research agenda in the future. Certainly more attentive to the economic and social repercussions, as has been pointed out, and attentive to innovation, and I think that Commissioner Moedas must certainly be given credit for opening up this chapter of innovation. Thanks also to colleagues Nica and Ehler and to colleague Cabezón, shadow rapporteur, for their commitment. I think that research on research is one of the most successful programs of the European Union's activity and in no other field like this can we say that unity is strength, it gives us the ability to tackle very complex issues that every single country couldn't even cope. So, I am personally satisfied with the support given in the new program to small and medium-sized enterprises, an essential part of the European and Italian economies. And the instrument for SMEs should also be included in Horizon Europe for the future, because it has given good results. One more word on the priorities mentioned: those of health, an essential element for the life of citizens, and those of the climate. Today we listened to Greta and I think that the best way to guarantee the future of young people is precisely to commit the most substantial resources possible to tackle climate change and the new challenges this poses to us.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! I congratulate the rapporteur on reaching an agreement on the Horizon program. It is all the more congratulatory that the positions of Parliament and the Council were so distant initially. However, I must admit that I liked Parliament's text much more. The rapporteur, Mr Nica, has quite rightly underlined the importance of closing the research and innovation gap in Europe. And I have the impression that the proposed widening activities, extending the forms of cooperation and within the framework of the Advancing Europe package are not sufficient. I am concerned that in fact it will not translate directly into participation in cooperation projects, missions and partnerships due to the lack of a bridge between the viewing and horizontal activities. Therefore, forward thinking is essential. It is about a plan for countries to leave this widening package. Well, such a solution would be to enter the percentage political target in the budget of the Horizon Europe programs intended for those countries that take part in this expansion program. This is the case for SMEs in many programs. This solution would guarantee that in the process of program implementation, the European Commission would have to launch mechanisms leading to the achievement of this goal.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to thank my colleagues for the results achieved. We are quite satisfied with 35% of the activities dedicated to the climate, the attention to SMEs, cultural heritage, social and human priorities. But today, at the end of the legislature, I would like to launch an appeal, leave a political reflection for a few seconds. Human civilization has always been intersected with technological innovation, starting from the first arrows, from the plow, man has used the technique to improve their living conditions. Yet, on the other hand, innovation hasn't always brought about just improvements. The Sumerians discovered that their wonderful irrigation system increased the salinity of the land, making it less fertile. The industrial revolution, with coal, brought about great development, but made the cities unhealthy. And again the mobility of mass, when a simple calculation of geometry could predict the congestion of cities. Today progress is driven by digital innovation, making real what a few years ago was just science fiction. But even here, there are already important side effects. The algorithms that impact the markets in high-frequency transactions, the pervasive control of the life and emotions of individuals, as is already the case in China. And what will be possible, for better or for worse, with robotics and artificial intelligence, even perhaps with the manifestation of singularity. So prevention is better than cure, because then reversing becomes more difficult. The nuclear threat, climate change, proves this. We need greater wisdom in researchers, among stakeholders, each at their own level, so that man, his dignity, his psychological and physical health, the stability of ecosystems are always at the center of every future technological choice, industrial and legislative. Science must be implemented, it is always important with a grain of salt. We never forget what nature has endowed us with, a natural intelligence in an analog body. We work for our future for a healthy mens in corpore sano. Life itself, on a safe planet.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: - Mr Chairman! In today's difficult times, it is science that must have a strong voice. It must build bridges against divisions, stand on the side of a solid, cohesive and wise Europe. A Europe that builds its strength on knowledge, not on stereotypes and populism. I believe that Horizon Europe gives us such strength. In the EU's research programs to date, the crack on the map of Europe has been very deep. The so-called old member states obtained 90% of the budget, the new EU "thirteen" - less than 5%. Horizon Europe offers a historic opportunity to bridge this gap. No, we do not have to be stuck with a Europe of many innovative speeds. In the new program, we triple the budget for promoting scientific excellence in countries and regions where this excellence is lacking. We are creating new instruments that will help support the most talented scientists, regardless of their country of origin. We are offering fairer wages, but above all we are giving a political signal that European science is only strong if all of Europe works together. This is a big step. When we participated in the 7th Framework Program, the postulate to open up to talent from Central and Eastern Europe was new and incomprehensible. While working on Horizon 2020, the idea of ​​spreading excellence was developed, but with a budget below 1%, not much was achieved. Only "Horizon Europe" gives real chances that the best scientists from Central and Eastern Europe will not have to leave their countries. Finally, we have the tools to stop this drain. For that, I thank the Commissioner and the rapporteurs of both projects and the Romanian Presidency. But nothing happens by itself. I am addressing the politicians and representatives of the new EU "Thirteen": do not wait with reforms, modernize universities, use these two years to prepare well for competing for European grants in the new perspective, do not let Europe escape you! You are needed in it!

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The key to a successful future is investment in research and innovation. First of all, I would like to say thank you very much: It was really a mammoth task, a great achievement by our rapporteurs, above all you, dear Mr Nica and Mr Ehler, with all our fellow shadow rapporteurs. Mr Moedas, Mr Council representative, it is great that in the short space of time we really want to get 120 billion off the ground here to invest in research and innovation. Mr Moedas rightly referred to the groundbreaking photo of a black hole. On Sunday I was with me at the world's largest construction machinery fair in Munich and there I experienced what research and innovation is possible in the field of construction machinery alone in order to work in an environmentally friendly and climate-friendly manner - innovative, smart solutions. It was impressive. It is therefore right that we are strengthening our industrial base in Europe with this program, that we are strengthening our scientists, and that we also think of the people in our country and also tackle the major widespread diseases, namely Alzheimer's and cancer. So I'm really happy - great performance! If we will pass this program tomorrow, hopefully with a large majority, then we will have sent the right signal for the next few years in Europe: investments in research, innovations, in our excellent minds, which we in all Member States - I emphasize: in all of them - to have. That is exactly the way to go. Thank you to everyone who was so committed to this program!

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this is my last speech in plenary as a Member, and I am grateful for being able to do so in relation to the approval of the new Horizon Europe program, because it synthesizes an idea of ​​Europe and its future that has governed my actions in this mandate. The new Horizon defines three major key priorities to guarantee a better future for the next generations: the fight against climate change, the digital economy and health. Today we listened precisely to the emotional words of Greta Thunberg at the ENVI Commission meeting, and we have repeated it in this chamber many times: acting against climate change is urgent and necessary, it is not an option. We must continue leading this fight from the Union, moving from words to actions. From word to action. And, in this sense, from here we have proposed that 35% of the program's funds be allocated to activities related to the fight against climate change, even going beyond the initial approach of the Commission. Secondly, the digital economy, so that the Union continues to be a center of attraction for science and knowledge worldwide. For this reason, Horizon will be the world's largest program dedicated to research and development. To guarantee our independence, we cannot and do not want to be left behind or in the hands of other powers such as the Asian giants or the United States. Finally, health. We need more research in health, and we will dedicate a significant part of the funds to the fight against cancer - including childhood cancer - but without leaving behind research on rare diseases and mental health, which affect thousands and millions of Europeans. Muito obrigado, Comissário, I have worked for five years.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I would just like to briefly emphasize two points again: Much has been said about climate protection, I can underline all of that. But in this program we are also very specifically addressing the issue of CO2-free industrial production. I find it important. If we talk about climate protection, we have to talk about Europe. But we also need to talk about how we can be role models for the world. The Chinese and Indians will not follow us if we have no more emissions, but also no more industrial production. That's why I've been working with Christian Ehler and others for some time on how we can build the first CO2-free steel mill in Europe, for example. And this program also helps in very specific ways. The second point is the topic of cancer - a very personal topic for each of us, including Manfred Weber, our top candidate, who spoke in Helsinki when he was nominated that his brother had died of cancer. Manfred, Christian Ehler and I have long talked about the question of how we can spare other families this fate. We are taking very concrete steps by putting a mission on the subject of cancer forward and by addressing the subject of cancer in children even more clearly in this program. Fortunately, children are less likely to get cancer, but when it does, it's particularly bad. And only European cooperation can help us tackle this problem. Therefore: Many thanks to everyone who helped, especially to our rapporteur from the EPP, Christian Ehler.

name: Michał BONI
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Rapporteur! Congratulations on this program. Thanks to the scale of "Horizon Europe", for the first time science can play the role of a real factor in building European competitive advantages. The activities of the program must be used to strengthen the EU's scientific and technological base, meet global challenges, increase the modern strength of European industry, ensuring a combination of EU funds with private business funds. Mainstreaming the less successful Member States into the program should be a priority. It is not only cohesion policy that makes it possible to avoid the two-speed division between Europe. Knowledge convergence is fundamental to sustainable development. The key is to be more open. It is essential to increase cross-sectoral, interdisciplinary, cross-border cooperation and the creation of new research and innovation networks. Such conditions may increase the expenditure on the scientific potential of countries that are currently separated from the innovative leaders of Europe by a factor of six. There will be no innovative Europe without impetus in research on health, environmental protection, safety, food quality, energy efficiency, and support for the development of artificial intelligence serving humans. All activities of "Horizon Europe" should be in synergy with other funds - the European Regional Development Fund, Cohesion Policy, the European Social Fund Plus - in line with regional strategies for smart specialization of research. Poland wants to act like that. This will multiply the effect and then "Horizon Europe" will become a development lever for everyone on an unprecedented scale.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Mr President, as the shadow rapporteur for the Committee on Development for the opinion on Horizon Europe, I already emphasised the importance of Horizon Europe for the developing countries. The same goes for European citizens. The Horizon Europe programme must create opportunities to finance, establish and maintain local, inclusive societies. We can boost local inventors and entrepreneurs and help them to realise their dreams. We must encourage them to stay and develop these inventions close to their proximity in order for the local society to benefit from their achievement. The perfect illustration for this is the success story of Croatian entrepreneur Mate Rimac. Thanks to recent European financial support, this amazing, successful young businessman managed to create electronic hybrid cars that not only gained world fame for its astonishing products but also boosted the Croatian economy by the creation of hundreds of jobs. Let this ‘Rimac effect’ be an inspiration for the future of Horizon Europe to foster EU competitiveness by focusing on increased deployment of research, development and innovation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Carlos Moedas, however desirable, we have seen that innovation does not always translate into proportional benefits. Although technological leaps are based on innovation, it still takes time until all potential risks are improved and assessed and mitigated. We cannot, therefore, accept that in the areas of financing through Horizon Europe, the principle of innovation overrides the principle of precaution, not least because I understand that not everything is valid in the field of innovation, especially, Commissioner, in areas where we need a paradigm shift, such as smoking, the use of fossil fuels and certain chemicals in industrial and agricultural areas. We cannot protect with the principle of innovation what is no longer politically defensible. But do not think that this caution will delay innovation because whenever it is a matter of privileging the public interest, as in the case of health, there are already mechanisms that allow the accelerated access to the market of these innovative products. The precautionary principle is to maintain, first because it is founded on scientific reserves and a serious assessment of the benefit / risk and cost / benefit ratios, second, because it is also an impulse source for research and development to find solutions that are proven to be safe and not harmful to health or the environment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, 'better late than never', says a proverb. The European Union has been slow to realize that competitiveness in the European economy must be based on innovation and new technologies and not, of course, on wage cuts, in a recipe imposed in Greece and in many countries in the European South. So now we have to invest, because only with investment in technology can international competition be tackled. At the same time, technology must be at the service of man: to have interventions in health matters and to have - of course - a reorganization of the steel industry itself, so that we can look ahead. But technology cannot be an alibi for mass layoffs. The famous Deutsche Telekom is preparing 7,000 redundancies in Greece; its subsidiary, that is, the Greek OTE — in this case, the German OTE. This can not be the case, Commissioner, in the name of the so-called development of technology to make mass redundancies, which are denounced by the workers themselves in Greece. Watch this issue.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, this Parliament is right to approve the programs that establish and implement Horizonte Europa in conjunction with Europa Digital which will also be voted on in this session. And much will be gained. First, the convergence that combines competitiveness and cohesion and defines that the progress of each country or territory benefits the European Union as a whole. Second, the inclusion and reduction of asymmetries, which strengthens our internal capacity and projects our voice on the external plane. Thirdly, the network's strategic autonomy that allows the Union's global affirmation potential to result from multiple capacities and competences developed in a decentralized manner. Fourth, the commitment of all projects to the ethical code of protection of values ​​and shared rights in the European Union. Fifth, the contribution of projects to the fight against climate change. And finally, perhaps most importantly, placing people at the center of all research and innovation strategies. For all this, congratulations, Commissioner, congratulations to the rapporteurs. It is very important to vote on the programs under review.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, allow me straight away to say congratulations to both the rapporteurs and the Commissioner for adopting the new framework programme before the European elections, because this can now allow for the smooth implementation of the many funding instruments, processes and programmes involved. I am glad that this Parliament took the issue of the research and innovation divide in Europe seriously because for far too long we had closed clubs, and it’s high time that these closed networks opened up to the lower—performing Member States. I believe that this is the way forward if we honestly want to have a European Union that develops a modern, competitive, innovative and truly sustainable economy.  Specific initiatives need to be established so that we retain existing research talent and attract young promising talent. Helping out the lower—performing Member States when it comes to research and innovation is a matter of shared responsibility and ownership, and it is imperative that the EU take substantive action.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, the ‘elephant in the room’ during many of the discussions on this Horizon programme has been, of course, the position of many UK institutions that contribute in such a major way to the predecessor programmes. It’s not the fault of the rapporteurs or the negotiators that the situation over Brexit is yet to be resolved, but it is at last now clear that even this UK Government will seek closely to associate whatever the outcome of Brexit with this programme. The only remaining threat is the extreme Brexit sought by climate change deniers and anti-science populists.  I’m glad to see, however, scientific excellence maintained as a key criteria for Horizon Europe funding. Excellence is not enhanced by throwing money around, it is enhanced by collaboration with excellence. The contribution of the UK’s world-class research community makes Horizon Europe a bigger, better and more successful programme.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Honorable President, the establishment of Horizon Europe and additional investment in science and research can only be welcomed.Europe needs to invest more in scientific excellence and innovation to remain globally competitive, and the Union can really offer added value in this area.However, additional funding will not have the desired effect if scientific achievements are not equally valued across the Union.It is known that the vast majority of projects funded through the European Research Council go to the old members, while new and less developed ones get crumbs.That must change.Also, scientists within Horizon Europe should be treated equally, regardless of the Member State they come from.Only in this way can we attract young people to engage in science and innovation throughout Europe and create the preconditions for them to stay in their homeland and create prosperity there, which will then contribute to the growth of the whole Union.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen.In the document, we have the title of the chapter We need more energy.I would like the title of the chapter We need more health!Health trends in Europe are worrying: one in three citizens can count on cancer.And we cannot make more of Europe with less health and more cancer.Health is not a sector or aspect, but a dimension of our future, and health interests me much more than Brexit, which will somehow be regulated.Research shows that 70% of Europeans want the European Union to do more in health and prevention.And people are right.And we already know enough to be able to do more.As a former patient and chair of the Cancer Group, I am very pleased to welcome the ambition to include the fight against cancer among the five strategic priorities to be funded by Horizon Europe.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think that tomorrow after the vote we can start preparing, we can start working on the strategic planning on setting up the mission boards and the partnership initiatives to guarantee that in January 2021 the new Horizon Europe programme will be fully operational. That’s what we are doing today.  And let me tell you that I’m very proud to see – and this is the last part—session of this eighth legislature – that tonight, I will keep very fond memories, because from the left to the right to the middle, every one of you, with different ideas, every one of you converged, converged to this agreement, converged to the fact that we can really do something, that we can really change the lives of scientists, of researchers and the lives for the future of our children, so I will keep this amazing memory of tonight.  Thank you to all of you, thank you to the ones behind the scenes that have worked so hard for this to happen. Thank you very much from the bottom of my heart.

name: Dan NICA
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank once again all the colleagues who have spoken today and noted that we have been able to take all the proposals that have come from all the standing committees, and this has shown that there has been a absolutely remarkable unanimity. I would like to thank my colleague Christian Ehler for the remarkable, impeccable way in which we collaborated and worked together and for the openness he showed and I thank Ambassador Boiangiu for getting us out of a stalemate and we managed to have this project. Commissioner Moedas, the last words are for you. I know that the current Commission will remain in office - so to speak - until April next year. So the good news is you have one more year. And this year, I want to ask you a few things. Start by making sure that this Horizon Europe program will not be affected by bureaucracy - so reduce the administrative and bureaucratic burden for researchers to handle research and paperwork as little as possible - reduce the amount of time a researcher can access and to already put into practice the bottom-up mechanisms, which have been introduced in this Horizon Europe program and which will be highly appreciated, to start the information campaign from the technical assistance funds - countries like Romania and many others need this information campaign. Everyone needs to know how the Horizon Europe program applies, what the procedures are and who needs to do it, and the benefits will be ours, everyone's. And I confess to you that I will be in the future European Parliament and we will have the opportunity to work together, starting in the autumn, with great care to make all these things happen in reality, because your work, my work and that of my colleagues must to have a reflection in practice immediately, as you said, after tomorrow's vote. Thank you for all the support you have given me.

name: Christian EHLER
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! On the occasion of today's discussion and tomorrow's adoption of the research program, I would like to remind you again that, sadly, Europe is basically that island, probably the only place, where we can still be sure of the idea of ​​the European Enlightenment, namely the freedom of science . When you see the government decreeing not to research climate change in the United States, when you see that in China and in other parts of the world research is not so free, then we should agree to remind the program - also as a task for the future - that the fight for the freedom of science is one of the most important tasks for the European Union. And we should also see it in a global context that this European model is very important for many researchers in the world. I think it is important to re-emphasize - even in the days of Brexit - that whatever the decision in Great Britain will be - and we are very concerned about the decision in Great Britain - Great Britain naturally belongs to the European research community. We may, so to speak, portray a Great Britain of the 19th century, a political decision may have been made, but there is solidarity with the English researchers, with Oxford, with Cambridge, and we should do everything possible to keep the United Kingdom as close as possible to Europe . On the occasion of a debate in Parliament, Parliament and also the rapporteurs and also this rapporteur naturally tend to emphasize their own successes and efforts. But in those days when the Commission is often talked about as an abstract institution, as a bureaucracy, I would like to emphasize once again that Carlos Moedas, as Commissioner for Research, has honored the Commission and Europe. He presented an ambitious program. He was sometimes more ambitious than the actual stakeholders, so it was a pleasure - albeit a necessary task - to complement this ambitious program. But in principle it is a joint achievement that Europe has acted quickly and looks decisively and courageously into the future.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 April 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - Congratulating the rapporteurs on reaching an agreement on the Horizon Europe framework program, I would like to point out that for me, as a representative of Central and Eastern Europe and as a representative of the academic community, Parliament's text contained better solutions to the problem of closing the research and innovation gap in Europe . We have widening activities and activities under the Advancing Europe package. But we need solutions that will cause countries to leave this widening package. We need a bridge to guide them towards greater participation in cooperation projects, missions and partnerships. Otherwise, in 20 years, we will again be debating funds for the same section of widening for the same countries! As a result of negotiations, it was possible to introduce into the program a provision referring to the criterion of "geographical diversity" as a detailed evaluation criterion. However, it would be much more effective to write directly about "widening countries" rather than geographic diversity in general. This would ensure a real inclusion of units from the so-called EU thirteen to the closed cooperation clubs that we see over the years.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the debate on the report by Mr Nicola Danti, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down rules and procedures for compliance with EU harmonization legislation on products and its enforcement, as well as amending Regulations (EU) no. 305/2011, (EU) no. 528/2012, (EU) 2016/424, (EU) 2016/425, (EU) 2016/426 and (EU) 2017/1369 of the European Parliament and of the Council, as well as Directives 2004/42 / EC, 2009 / 48 / EC, 2010/35 / EU, 2013/29 / EU, 2013/53 / EU, 2014/28 / EU, 2014/29 / EU, 2014/30 / EU, 2014/31 / EU, 2014/32 / EU, 2014/33 / EU, 2014/34 / EU, 2014/35 / EU, 2014/53 / EU, 2014/68 / EU and 2014/90 / EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM (2017) 0795 - C8-0004 / 2018 - 2017/0353 (COD)) (A8-0277 / 2018).

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bieńkowska, after many years, and following the unjustifiable deadlock in the 2013 product safety legislative package, we are preparing to approve new rules for a more effective control system in the Union. Thanks to the agreement reached, we will make the European system more modern, more effective and more coordinated to ensure that only safe and compliant products and fair competition in the single market reach final consumers. Every day we come across dangerous, illegal, counterfeit products, growing numbers and which mainly affect sectors with a strong impact on daily life. 32% of toys, 58% of electronic devices, 47% of construction products do not meet the safety or consumer information requirements set by the legislation. To these data must be added the growing share of counterfeit products that affect the most manufacturing countries and which represent one of the main forms of unfair competition against many European companies. Behind these numbers and these initial considerations there is a market surveillance system that is still too inefficient, without adequate resources, without sufficient coordination at European level and not very responsive to changes in the global economy. A system where 500 national authorities operate and where there is not even a complete mapping of them, where efficient communication is lacking. In implementing the Commission proposal, we as Parliament have worked intensively on many fronts. Here I will limit myself to mentioning just a few of our priorities. One of the main added values ​​of the regulation is represented by the provisions on the so-called reference operator. For most of the products in circulation on the European market, including the most dangerous ones, there will be an obligation to have an economic operator who is able to respond in the event of non-compliance or defects in the product itself. It is no longer conceivable that there is no responsible person behind a dangerous, counterfeit or non-compliant product. We have also introduced more specific provisions to protect consumers who buy on the web, who must be guaranteed with the same level of product safety as those sold in traditional channels. We also believe that there must be greater cooperation at political and operational level between the authorities of the Member States to build common strategies and ensure a uniform and coherent system of controls. In particular, we want to eliminate the so-called “port shopping”, that is the existence of privileged entry points by dishonest operators due to the less rigidity or sometimes the total absence of customs controls. For this reason we have foreseen harmonized objectives and standards for border controls, common risk methodologies, greater coordination and mutual assistance between national authorities at the level of the European network. We have also demanded a supervisory system, where there is no longer any space for conflicts of interest between the controller and the subsidiary, nor for privileged treatment for incorrect operators. This is why we supported the European Commission's proposal to create a network of public laboratories in the European Union, which can increase the control capacity of individual Member States, based on specific competences and shared priorities. Finally, we have increased the powers available to national authorities, to carry out effective investigations and controls also in the world of the web, with reference to the most technologically sophisticated products. These are the main results achieved. I hope there is broad consensus on this proposal.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am really happy to see the successful outcome of the negotiations on the regulation on market surveillance and compliance. I would like to thank all of you, the Parliament, for the support for this initiative. It is an important delivery for the single market strategy. The regulation addresses a very important problem in the single market, which is that there are too many unsafe and non-compliant products on our EU market. It is also a major step forward. It will ensure better protection of consumers and lead to a fairer single market for products in the EU. Let me thank wholeheartedly the rapporteur, Mr Nicola Danti, and shadow rapporteurs Mr Karas, Mr Selimovic and Mr Dalton. I know that it was a huge effort and I know it has not been easy to finish this file ahead of the elections. As all of us know, there are things that we would have liked to see differently so, on the first point, we will prepare a declaration on the legal basis of this regulation. On the second one, more positive, we will commit to working towards more uniformity of controls at the external borders as they are very important elements of this regulation. We will have the unique opportunity to stop unsafe and non-compliant products before they are put on our European markets. The regulation will improve sharing of intelligence between national inspectors and customs authorities as well.  On several points, the proposal, let me also underline this, was even improved. I am thinking here especially of the addition of peer reviews. This regulation will make as well a fundamental difference for national inspectors. First of all, it will give authorities better tools and powers to investigate products sold online. The regulation gives inspectors the power to deal directly with the new business actors in digital supply chains, such as fulfilment centres and online market places. Further, for many product categories, there will be a business representative in the EU. This will make it easier for authorities to obtain the information they need to verify compliance and to resolve non-compliance cases. Secondly, the regulation will improve cooperation between authorities and businesses. Preventing non-compliance is even more important than policing the market – I think that we share this view – as some businesses act in good faith but they are ignorant about the rules. The regulation provides businesses with very clear channels for obtaining information on EU product rules. Thirdly, and perhaps more importantly, it will improve cooperation between all authorities in the European Union. As you know, there are currently more than 500 market surveillance authorities across the EU so the products flow freely across our internal borders but, unfortunately, enforcement does not. The regulation requires Member States to help each other in cross—border cases. It also requires national inspectors to work closer with customs authorities. There will be EU-wide cooperation through the EU product compliance network.  Only one element is missing – the money – especially for cooperation through the abovementioned product compliance network. The money needs to come from the single market programme. I am very pleased that you have been actively engaged in securing this and I count on Parliament’s further support in that respect. To conclude, let me say that I believe that we have reached a very good compromise, a balanced compromise, reflecting the different views and different concerns of all parties. I hope you will also endorse it tomorrow. Commission Statements (in writing) "On the legal base: The Commission takes note that the text agreed replaces the triple legal basis of the Commission proposal (Article 114 TFEU - internal market, Article 33 TFEU – customs cooperation, Article 207 – common commercial policy) by a double legal basis, through deletion of the common commercial policy legal basis. The Commission continues to consider that the triple legal basis is fully justified in relation to the provisions that regulate conditions for access to the EU market of products originating from third countries. Moreover, the common commercial policy legal basis is in line with the legal basis of Regulation (EC) 765/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 July 2008 setting the requirements for accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products and repealing Regulation (EEC) No 339/93. The Commission regrets the deletion of Article 207 TFEU as legal basis of the Regulation." "On the implementing act to set uniform conditions for customs controls (Article 25(8)): In order to strengthen controls on products at customs, the Regulation empowers the Commission to adopt implementing acts to determine benchmarks and techniques for checks on the basis of common risk analysis on the Union level. The Commission intends to make use of this empowerment."

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: ENVI rapporteur - Mr President, consumer safety and environmental protection are the cornerstones of the internal market for goods, which is one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. I welcome the proposal for a regulation aimed at strengthening compliance with and enforcement of Union harmonization legislation on products. It applies to toys, cosmetics and cleaning products, machinery, batteries and accumulators, chemicals, tires, construction and biocidal products, waste electrical equipment, medical devices and others. I consider it unacceptable for the harmonized rules to be circumvented today, as evidenced by the fact that, for example, up to 32% of toys, 58% of electronics and 47% of construction products that have passed inspections did not meet safety requirements. I therefore support an increase in the number of inspections and increased fines to deter dishonest producers and distributors. Newly established EU test centers must guarantee the reliability and consistency of testing and provide expertise at the highest possible level in complex areas, such as harmful chemicals, which all too often appear in toys or cosmetics when tested.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Rapporteur Danti, ladies and gentlemen! The first attempt at reform to update the market surveillance system failed in 2013. Today and now we are giving the new go-ahead for the new market surveillance system. This was urgently needed, also in the interests of consumers. We know that toys, pyrotechnics and machines in particular are the products with which we have found the greatest problems. We believe that whoever brings dangerous products to the internal market must also take responsibility for them. And so we need to monitor so that we know who is putting dangerous products on the market and can say who is taking responsibility for them. We also want the same rules of the game for everyone. All non-European companies must adhere to the same rules of the game as domestic companies if they want to operate in our market. We had the reality that logistics providers, large online retailers, have so far been able to pull themselves out of the affair. Not anymore! Anyone who considers it justified to do business with dangerous or non-compliant products can also pay the bill for the return campaigns for such products and must take responsibility for them. I would like to thank the rapporteur for a great cooperation and ask for the broad support on tomorrow that we also had between the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. - Sir. Chairman! It is a really happy day, but it is also time we did something by ensuring much better control over the products that enter the EU's internal market. I have been a Member of the European Parliament for 12 years and have worked on product safety for all those 12 years. That's why it's a big day. We have finally succeeded in getting new rules, which means that we get to control our products far more than before. It is necessary. One of the good things that has come with today is that it is now possible to control goods that come online from outside - from outside the EU into the EU, which is really important. A new study in Denmark shows that out of 12 toy products that were bought on an online platform outside the EU and brought in, none of the products complied with the rules. Here, with the enforcement regulation, the authorities have a much better opportunity to stop these products, check them and ensure that consumers do not have to be afraid to buy products. It's a big day, it's an important day, now we just need the money, and now the Member States have to deliver. Thanks to all of us.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club.- Honorable Chairman, the Internet has changed the way we function.Changes in human behavior are visible in all spheres of life, so, among other things, today we do shopping differently than before the Internet.With the growing share of online commerce, the number of frauds has increased dramatically, and in the new circumstances, effective consumer protection has become quite a challenge.Harmonizing products in the single market would reduce fraud and restore consumer confidence.Particular attention should be paid to products from third countries, which are often not in line with Union legislation.In doing so, care must be taken to strike a balance between protecting the interests and rights of consumers on the one hand and preserving advantages such as speed, lower costs and simplicity of e-commerce on the other.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, two months ago I bought a new iron, and at the first ironing it burnt my shirt. I have a colleague here who has kids, and she bought singing toys that were not able to stop singing: they starting singing in the middle of the night, and in order to stop them they had to take all the batteries out and throw them away. And the third one here is a dangerous hairdryer: it more or less takes your hair off and ages you 20 years in a matter of seconds. This is what this legislation is about: making sure that the goods sold on the internal market are safe and compliant with the rules adopted in this Parliament.  It is time to do something about it; we can improve consumer legislation every day, but if the rules are not obeyed, then there is no meaning in it. What we are doing here is actually strengthening the surveillance of the internal market. By that, we are making sure that consumers never again have to endure the warm wrath of the faulty hairdryer or the faulty batteries that are exploding in your bag. This is what we are required to do for the European citizens, and it is actually one good thing that we can give before the elections.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr Chairman!Reporting, new standards, regulations, bureaucracy, more controls, new supervisors, penalties, difficulties, complications, more surveillance - we find all this in this new report on market surveillance and product harmonization.I do not have the strength to explain to you again why this is a bad idea, why it will not work, so I thought that I would look for some positives.What good can you do with this report?And I made a dove, which I recommend to all of you.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you have heard the rapporteur list the percentages for products that are still unsafe. They are impressive, they worry. Think about 32% of the toys, they mostly concern children, and 40% of the personal protective equipment, are those that concern our body. Faced with a situation of this nature, with the growth of e-commerce it is inevitable that there are greater risks and it is equally necessary that we take the steps forward that we have tried to put together, with an important and positive result like the one we are arguing. Now, it is also important to define an economic operator that guarantees the conformity of all products. Things therefore positive and I still have the regret that we could have arrived earlier. In the previous legislature, Parliament had voted on a very ambitious text concerning product safety and which had been blocked in the Council due to the opposition against the introduction of the rules relating to "made in". Too bad, we could have reached this point well in advance. In any case, let us look at what has been and now it will be up to the future Commission to make what we are positively discussing and approving, I imagine, tomorrow, in all countries.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, the regulation was long overdue, because, yes, the single market and the free movement of goods are fundamental to the future of Europe. Obviously, we also had to have a surveillance, a better surveillance, because the entry of many imports into the internal market complicates the situation and we have to harmonize, as stated in the regulation. And I am glad that we have a European Union network and that we have benchmarks and that we will have common control rules. Just let's not forget that we have to link these regulations, we also have to know how to check at customs. For now, the report on the customs union is not finalized and then in vain we have common procedures if we do not have computerized customs, if we do not have this customs union regulation. I am convinced, however, that we will end them in the next term. I regret that I myself was the rapporteur for the customs union and we did not manage to reach the institutional negotiation. Today, however, I voted, and I hope, Commissioner, for the regulation to remain not only a theory, but also to be applied in practice, through collaboration between national authorities.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear Members, thank you very much for all your comments and contributions during this discussion, but first and foremost, I want to thank you for your engagement and for your devotion to this file, to this package. With tomorrow’s vote, you will be sending a very strong and clear message on the safety and compliance of products in the EU single market. I am convinced that this regulation, which we have achieved agreement on, is a balanced and comprehensive one. It will ensure, as I underlined before, a much better cooperation between all market surveillance and customs authorities in the EU. It will help market surveillance in the EU to really adapt to the challenges of the 21st century, and of course it will complete our Goods Package. So, I want to thank all of those involved in this effort. I want to thank Parliament, but of course also the Romanian Presidency for your support on this file. I am convinced that with this regulation we will have taken an important step towards a really true and fair Single Market in the EU.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me at the opening of this reply to thank, which I did not do at the beginning, the shadow rapporteurs for cooperation during the months we have been working on this regulation, which is a very substantial regulation. We had to deal with many issues, many points and the cooperation, I must say, of Parliament's negotiating team has been truly extraordinary. At the same time, let me also thank Commissioner Bieńkowska and the Commission, because in the difficult moments when cooperation was needed, she stood by us and tried to mediate our positions with those of the Council and I thank both the Presidency in this regard. Austrian, under which I started this path, and the Romanian Presidency which has finished the path. In the final reply, I would like to say two things, the first is about financial resources. This regulation is together with the project of the Single Market program, where we have inserted the financial resources, as the Commissioner said, which are used to guarantee the legs of this regulation, they serve to guarantee operations and we hope that with the next legislature, when we go to determine this program on the internal market, confirm the resources that Parliament has put in to ensure that what we foresee in the regulation is market surveillance, which is effective in practice and, to do this, resources are also needed. Let me tell you another element, what we want to do with this regulation and what we have achieved, is to have equal treatment between European companies and non-European companies. Too often non-European companies had an ease of access without demonstrating the necessary elements of conformity of the goods they placed on the European market. This is something that helps a greater and fairer internal market between European and non-European companies and the same goes for companies that market online and offline. Protecting the single market means guaranteeing consumers compliance with European regulations. Having a market surveillance, President, serves to guarantee effectiveness and demand from all economic operators and authorities full compliance with the system of laws and standards that we have set ourselves over time, to protect our safety and our social model.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Wednesday, April 17, 2019.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the debate on the report by Christel Schaldemose, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council promoting fair treatment and transparency forbusiness users of online mediation services (COM (2018) 0238 - C8-0165 / 2018 - 2018/0112 (COD)) (A8-0444 / 2018).

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Rapporteur. - Sir. Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! We consumers love them - the online brokerage services - when we book hotel rooms, airline tickets, buy clothes, shoes, books, music and much more. Then we check the selection and prices through the online brokerage services. They open up the market for us consumers and for the companies that use them to sell goods and services. So they are good in many ways, yet they are not really regulated today, it is a bit like the Wild West. In fact, companies today have only one choice. Either to accept the terms that the online brokerage services offer them, or not to be there at all. And many times the terms you get today are completely unequal, unreasonable terms and at least quite opaque. It is not good enough! Therefore, it is also gratifying that we have succeeded in reaching an agreement to have new rules made, which means that we get much more fairness and transparency for the online platforms and for the companies that use them. Ultimately, this also means that consumers can be much more confident when using the online brokerage services to purchase products. So what have we achieved? Yes, we have not fully come to terms with it all, but we will get started and lay a foundation for legislation that will enable us to have a more regulated online market. We create significantly more transparency, and we also create demands and more fairness for the companies that use the online services. It's really important, it's really good. More specifically, we have achieved that the terms that the companies that use the online services get should be much more fair. We have made a long list of requirements that a company using an online platform must have in mind in the contract it enters into. And this is very important, because it creates much more fairness, so the company knows what it is you are exposed to or face when using a service. We have managed to get through with a lot of things. The Commission proposed that the updating of terms should be notified by 15 days, we have ensured that you also have the right to terminate your contract if you do not think that the updated rules are good enough. We have implemented a large number of strict transparency requirements on a large number of matters. Including e.g. also what it is for some terms and main parameters that are used as a basis for the ranking that one makes on the online platforms. This is very important - it is important for the company that uses the online platforms that it knows what it is that is the basis for this ranking. Ranking is important when consumers need to choose the platform. We have also ensured that business users have a minimum 30 day notice period if the platform wants to terminate their contract. We have also ensured that many of these requirements apply to search engines. We have also placed great emphasis on the fact that once these rules are to be implemented and enforced, it will be done properly and efficiently. Member countries are the ones to enforce the rules, but we need to ensure that it happens better, because otherwise there is no point in using new rules. And then we have also chosen to say that since this is the first legislation in this area, it will not be long before we have to look more closely at whether there is a need to revise the rules. Therefore, we have also made a long list of requirements for what it is for some things to be checked when we get to where we need to re-evaluate the legislation. But overall, it can be said that the good thing about this proposal is that we simply create significantly more transparency for the companies that use the online dissemination services, and we also create more fairness. A more level playing field is being created for the companies that use them, and this ultimately means that our consumers, who buy goods and services on the platforms, can be more confident that they are getting that product. they expect. So this is an important step we are taking, and at the same time, we in the EU will also be the ones setting the global standards for these platforms.This is a really important day, so I thank you for the cooperation we have had and look forward to the debate we will have tonight.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the European Parliament and in particular the rapporteur, Mrs Schaldemose, but also the shadow rapporteurs, for all their efforts and for their cooperation with a view to achieving a agreement on this file, in such a short period of time. Indeed, Parliament has helped to strengthen and shape the text of the new regulation. Your amendments will help create a fairer environment for businesses in the online platform economy. This will benefit consumers who use these platforms. There will be a clear set of rules and a more predictable regulatory environment. This in turn will build trust across borders. We would obviously like this to help platforms to develop, invest and innovate. Some of these additional provisions proposed by the European Parliament will help more than one million European SMEs, which offer their goods and services through online platforms, to reach their customers. Let me highlight the operating systems, which Parliament has filled in a potential loophole. It has been clarified that online intermediation services cannot shirk their obligations when controlling the underlying operating systems. I also welcome the introduction of a list of specific contractual conditions aimed at ensuring fair treatment between online intermediation services and their business users, and at prohibiting certain harmful practices. This will make this new regulation a powerful instrument. Many of your proposals will contribute to our main objective of increasing transparency, in particular with regard to the essential question of ranking. For example, and this was also cited by the rapporteur, in addition to online intermediation services, search engines will have to provide information on any differential treatment they apply. Businesses will now be able to resolve disputes more easily - for example, all platforms, except the smallest, will need to have an internal complaints handling system in place and use ombudsmen that platforms must identify upstream to allow out-of-court settlement of disputes. This balance takes into account the expectations of companies. The final text also strengthened the role of Member States in implementing the regulation. Member States will have to put in place measures to ensure proper and effective application of the new rules. They will also need to work with us, the Commission, to monitor and assess the impact of the new rules and share relevant information. But, of course, our work does not end here. We will develop guidelines that will provide more clarity on what information online platforms and search engines should provide on how ranking works. We will obviously work with the industry to put in place codes of conduct to complement the new rules. I am glad that the compromise we have reached preserves the spirit, the objectives and the approach of our original proposal. It strikes the right balance and allows platforms, especially European ones, to establish and develop. This is only a first step. We are already taking the lead, on the one hand with the work of the observatory on the economy of platforms - I would remind you here that our independent experts are preparing a preliminary report expected in the course of the year -, on the other hand with the revision as provided for in the regulation - there will be a rigorous evaluation 18 months after entry into force.From our side, we count on your support to continue in this process.I also hope that Parliament will approve the regulation when it comes to the vote tomorrow.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy asked for an opinion - Mr President, internet platforms are a huge opportunity for startups, small guesthouses, family or local businesses.Thanks to them, they can start a business, employ people and provide quality services.We must ensure that the strong treat them fairly.The compromise reached goes, on some points, perhaps a little further than I originally suggested.In my draft opinion on behalf of the ITRE Committee, I have tried to keep regulation to a minimum.In my opinion, Parliament should not propose business models, but rather lay down clear rules.Nevertheless, I can support the compromise reached with a clear conscience.I thank the colleagues in the ITRE Committee who supported my vision and congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Schaldemos, as well as our shadow rapporteur, Mr Juvin.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, one of the great successes of the European Union is obviously the single market. Despite its flaws, I prefer that SMEs in my country can sell to 500 million Europeans rather than 66 million French people. Today, we are taking a further step, we are creating a digital single market and in this new digital economy which has no rules, we are giving the Union its own rules: not to submit to foreign legislation and not to suffer the law of the strongest economic powers. In particular, we now prevent platforms from imposing unfair conditions on European companies using their services and the relationship between platforms and SMEs must be balanced. So obviously, national law would be completely insufficient. If a French person books a room in a hotel in Italy through a platform that is based in Ireland, what national law would apply? Is it French law, Italian law or Irish law? We can see that this does not work and that we obviously need European rules. This is what we are doing, we are protecting European SMEs and in order to protect them, we must first offer them the protection of a harmonized and common European law in the 27 States. In this text, the Parliament has shown that it is a democratic tool, which does not obey lobbies or any particular interest. I had the honor of serving there for two terms and Mr. Speaker, as I leave this Parliament I have only one word: preserve it.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! I would like to congratulate Mrs Schaldemose on her really excellent job and, on behalf of the Socialist Group, the S&D Group, say that we fully support her work and recommend that the result be approved tomorrow. Online platforms such as the booking hotel reservation portal, the Apple Store or the eDreams travel platform are playing an increasingly important role in the digital world. The increasing market power of online platforms is, however, also associated with a weakening of the rights of commercial users vis-à-vis the platforms. The present regulation brings fairness into the platform economy through transparency requirements, through a ban on unfair trading practices, through appropriate complaint mechanisms through effective legal enforcement. And through the special observatory for online platforms, monitoring will also be more effective. I think that is a good thing for small and medium-sized businesses and for consumers.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the key to any business is honesty and transparency with your consumers, but also with your business partners.
