This regulation ensures this needed greater transparency, while not imposing unneeded over—regulation on platforms and traders. Online commerce is the future of our economy and we must not destroy our European players in a misguided attempt to attack the international ones. The path to hell is paved with good intentions. Some in this House saw this regulation as a political tool, as a way to change competition policy through the back door. I am pleased that in the end common sense has prevailed and I can only thank the rapporteur in this regard. She had the courage to seek a good and balanced agreement over fighting for one which would have had a negative effect on our economy and the digital single market. This is why the ALDE Group will support the trilogue outcome tomorrow at the votes, and I encourage both platforms and traders to use this new transparency to its greatest extent. It is only by adopting best practices and effective self-regulation that this market can continue to be fair to all. I fear if platforms don’t use this chance that they will not get another one.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in principle, platforms are a great opportunity for small European business. Whether it’s a person who works as a software developer or somebody selling their own products, platforms make it possible for the small players to compete with the big players and to reach customers that they would otherwise never have reached, which is sometimes perhaps also a reason why some big European companies wanted to extend this regulation more than is reasonable. But platforms do become a problem when network effects make them so large that they can dictate unfair terms to their business customers. We have achieved a regulation that provides transparency and fairness in the platform market, and I think it’s to a great extent testimony to the steady hand of the rapporteur, Mrs Schaldemose, who has ensured that there is no free ride for platforms but that there are also no unreasonable obligations that would kill the small players in the European market, who are very important for European businesses. So I would really like to thank all who have contributed on this work. It’s great to see that there can be such great consensus on the platforms file.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Gabriel, this regulation has the merit of rebalancing the economic relations between large platforms and over a million European companies operating through online intermediaries who are often dependent on them. Some examples above all: with the new rules we will have greater transparency on the products and services offered online, more information on the parameters that determine the positioning of an offer on the web page, more defenses against unilateral changes to the terms and conditions of contracts by platforms. These rules will bring consequent benefits to the millions of citizens who increasingly choose to buy online and who will be able to enjoy lower prices, greater choice and who will see an increase in the information available to them. In recent months, the European Parliament has shown that it does not bow to the interests of the digital giants, but that it protects European companies by writing new rules capable of better protecting the most disadvantaged contractual party.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, once again I would like to thank the Members of this Parliament for their comments and observations. I would like to stress once again, on behalf of the Commission, that we welcome the agreement reached on this regulation. As you have also rightly said, it reflects a good balance between different political points of view and between the interests of stakeholders. A vote in favor of this regulation will therefore send a strong and clear message to SMEs and European citizens that the European Union is capable of ensuring transparency and increased predictability in the environment of online platforms. Once again, thank you to Mrs Schaldemose, the rapporteur, and to all who have contributed to this dossier so that it can move forward quickly. In conclusion, we can say that through our common work we have taken an important step forward for the digital single market, businesses and citizens of the Union.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mayor. - Sir. Chairman! Thank you for the floor again, and also a thousand thanks to you colleagues for your comments. I share the views, I am glad that we have achieved this result, which is balanced both for the benefit of the companies, reasonably towards the platforms and especially also something that in the end which will be of great benefit to our many consumers. It was not a result we would have come through with if we had not cooperated so well. That is why I would also like to say a thousand thanks to the Romanian Presidency. We had some tough but also good negotiations and I think we got to the finish line in a really good way. Thank you very much for that. And also to the Commission and Commissioner - had it not been for the help we received from the Commission during the negotiations, we would not have come through with this result. So thank you so much for succeeding. It shows that when we collaborate and there is openness across, we can easily make something that is really good for our companies, so we can continue to have some good and usable platforms and at the same time benefit our consumers. I am proud of the result we have achieved here, and I am also aware that it is only a first step. I look forward to the continued work, not least the result of the observatory, and to seeing what can come out of it. In fact, I believe that with this legislation, we can become a leader in the platform market in Europe and in the world in the long run, because there is a need for it to be regulated, there is a need for it to be transparent, and there is also a need for , that it's fair. All this we have achieved in this legislation. Thank you very much.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 April 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - As rapporteur of the Committee on Transport and Tourism on the file on "Promoting equity and transparency between service providers and online platforms", my aim in this file was to ensure a transparent and fair environment for all actors involved in the digital economy: the provider services, online platforms and the consumer, who is in fact the European citizen. In the context of the rapid evolution of digital technologies, my vision is that digitalization is the future. For this, it is necessary to create a properly regulated digital environment, in which traditional business models do not suffer as a result of the digitization process. Given the very horizontal nature of the European Commission's proposal for a regulation, I am very pleased that we have managed to regulate a few aspects of the fundamentals of promoting and ensuring transparency and fairness. Specifically, we have introduced very clear provisions for online platforms to apply the criteria for prioritizing service providers in a non-discriminatory manner. From my point of view, it is essential to have a balance between traditional forms of business and those based exclusively on digital technologies, as is the case with the collaborative economy.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda was the debate on the report by Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 93/13 / EEC. Council Directive 98/6 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, Directive 2005/29 / EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2011/83 / EU of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning better enforcement and modernization of EU consumer protection rules (COM (2018) 0185 - C8-0143 / 2018 - 2018/0090 (COD)) (A8-0029 / 2019).

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. –Mr President, this package reboots consumer rights for the internet age, bringing new protections and empowering consumers with information whenever they buy. I’d like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the Romanian Presidency, and the European Commission for their hard work and commitment to achieve an agreement before the European elections. We had just three weeks from start to finish of the negotiations and we focused on a single trilogue. It turned into a very long day, but after ten hours of negotiation we got an agreement. Now as some of you will be aware, this agreement was subject to further adjustment from the Commission, which had made it clear in the talks that it needed to confirm its mandate. The final text addressing dual quality was therefore tweaked, but the crucial substance remains: consumers can no longer be misled by products made to different standards but marketed as the same in different Member States. It’s not right, and the agreement we vote on tomorrow will stop those egregious breaches of consumer trust. Now I know some colleagues feel that we should have gone further, and I have tabled amendments to that effect for tomorrow. But let me be clear: if any of these amendments pass, this will collapse the entire agreement. The Council and Commission have made it clear that they are already at the edge – they can’t give any more. So if they pass, there will be no deal at all. That means no provision at all on dual quality, and there will be no updated consumer law at all – just a few weeks before an election. This will not help consumers, who are currently being misled. There will be no law coming down the track for them. It will not help consumer authorities. They would not, for example, be able to give out penalties that they need to enforce all the other consumer laws. And it would not help producers, who would continue to be undercut by competitors who flout the rules. I struggle also to see how it would meet political reality. It would risk delaying efforts to tackle dual quality for years, if not for ever. But with the agreement we have found, there is a beginning. Dual-quality products now for the first time are addressed, and in the coming years, the Commission will have to review progress seriously. Those are concrete steps of progress rather than unrealistic amendments. And we should remember that this package is about more than dual quality. There are vital improvements to the consumer protections we cannot, in good conscience, delay. And the Parliament’s demands have been met in many areas. We have banned bulk-buying of event tickets following an earlier law in the UK. This practice penalises real fans, either unable to see their favourite team or artist or forced to pay touts many times the face-value price. And this will now stop, because it’s been cheating everyone and it’s good news that we are able to ban it here. We’ve also succeeded in introducing requirements to improve trust in online reviews, marketplace ranking and the pricing of discounts – all to the benefit of the consumer. I also believe that in the internet era we should trust the informed consumer. The online world contains a wealth of information that can empower the consumer, but it needs to be genuine to be useful. Our measures on online consumer trust will make sure that consumers know when they’re getting information that they can rely on, helping them find the product that they are looking for. I'm glad that we could also get support from the Commission and the Council for a tool to build consumer awareness and use of their rights. The European consumer rights – or, as I like to call it, the ‘ECR app’ – will give consumers a single identifiable point to know their rights and easy access to the complaints procedure that will help them solve their problems. We also ensured that changes to the right of withdrawal were rejected. This is an important right for consumers and for their trust in e-commerce, and if we can adopt this agreement tomorrow, it will be just over a year from the adoption of the proposal by the Commission to the conclusion of our work. So I would like to thank the shadows again, who all helped to ensure the compromise, also the IMCO Secretariat and the Legal Services for their hard work and dedication. These rules will make a real difference to consumers’ everyday life. They matter. So let’s not delay their implementation by one more day and let’s adopt the text tomorrow.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking rapporteur Mr Dalton, the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) for their hard work, which allowed for a swift agreement on this extremely important file. It goes well beyond the Commission’s proposal on many aspects. I would like to thank Parliament for its strong push to improve consumer rights, especially in relation to digital markets. But, in addition, this directive will strengthen the enforcement of consumer rights as we are providing more harmonised sanctions with teeth. Consumer authorities in all 28 Member States will be able to fine companies harming consumers in several or all Member States up to 4% of their annual turnover. Victims of unfair practices will be equipped to claim remedies from traders, such as terminating the contract or compensation of damages. This will also facilitate out—of—court and in—court disputes. The new directive will also introduce a number of new measures to avoid misleading consumers online and to improve online transparency. We prohibit the displaying of fake consumer reviews. We require a clear indication of commercial sponsoring when it is used in the ranking of goods in market places. There will be no more fake price reductions for goods fooling consumers, and there must be a clear indication that, even if a consumer agreed to a contract which does not entail money, he has rights.  Turning now to the issue of dual quality: I know that many people in this House have been fighting against this for years. This helped to draw more attention to the issue and to bring it onto the political agenda. I am therefore proud that the Commission, in the new deal for consumers, has, for the first time ever, proposed a legislative provision on this issue so that the dual treatment of consumers in the EU will stop, and so that the new rule is the same composition everywhere in the EU.  This has been a very sensitive issue in the negotiations, and the text which is now on the table is a compromise achieved by the Council and Parliament negotiators after – and I agree with Mr Dalton – very tough but, I would say, constructive talks. We want the private sector to take their responsibilities and to end dual quality. It is now absolutely clear that they cannot cheat on the quality and sell under identical packaging foods with a significantly different composition, and this is a huge step forward. I am glad that already now, under the pressure we have imposed on them, many manufacturers have adjusted their recipes to have a single one across the EU. With further steps we made with the Omnibus proposal and following exchanges of views on this issue, I know that many other companies are working on eliminating differences. What also helps is the permanent testing which we are now doing, and which shows that there is a significant number of cheated products on our markets which have to disappear.  I expect that producers will stop differentiation. Those who continue must have justified reasons for doing so. Such traders should be in a position to demonstrate their legitimate reasons. This is why we consider that blacklisting of any differentiation as a misleading practice is not the appropriate and workable solution.  The main mechanism of the Unfair Commercial Directive is set out in Article 6, not in the Annex blacklisting misleading practices. I think that it is not less effective. Article 6 of the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive (UCPD) is constantly used as a legal basis by national authorities across the EU. Most recently, for example, the Italian authorities used it to fine Wizz Air or Ryanair for misleading consumers on the real price of their tickets. The consumer protection authorities in the Member States base a lot of their cases on this article. Recently, they published the result of their action against five big car rental companies for not being clear on the real content of their services and preventing informed choices, and they will do so in the future on the illegal use of dual quality.  The Commission is going to closely monitor the implementation of this provision, and we will continue our efforts to improve the enforcement capacities of the Member States. This year again, we are proposing EUR 1 million in grants from the consumer programme on this. Furthermore, thanks to a pilot project from the European Parliament, we are going to implement EUR 1.66 million/EUR 1.2 million of grants for consumer associations to develop their testing capacities.  Finally, there is a clear revision clause in the text, and we commit to re—assessing the situation two years after the entry into force of the directive to see whether we should move to more stringent solutions. Allow me to express my sincere hope that this directive modernising and better enforcing European consumers’ rights will be adopted tomorrow.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Of course, this directive has good solutions for consumers, but it does not solve the basic problem of different quality when packaged in the same way. We have a non-exhaustive list of legitimate exceptions here, as the Commissioner herself said, that is, this directive does not actually prohibit unfair practices. A few examples, please - Almette cheese. This Almette I bought at Kehl is made of cottage cheese and is 100% natural, and this Almette from the store in Krakow is made of cottage cheese and powdered milk and contains citric acid E330. I also bought Philadelphia cheese. The one bought in Krakow contains the E410 stabilizer, which the one bought from Kehl does not. One more example - tea that also looks the same: the one bought in Krakow has 0.1% of peach juice, and the one bought here in Strasbourg has 50 times more. That is why over a hundred colleagues have signed the amendment which absolutely prohibits such unfair practices, and I am asking you for your support, because we do not have better and worse consumers in the European Union. The market is fair and it has to be fair to everyone equally.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! I must honestly say that in this package of measures that we have to vote on tomorrow, we have a whole host of very good proposals and enormous improvements for the citizens and for the consumers. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the good work, but also the Commissioner and the Council Presidency, who worked very hard to get this through. Among these positive actions is the modernization of the platform transparency. We have achieved that the rights also apply to the so-called free services. We have made sure that better remedies are provided for consumers. And we have introduced what has not been done before in this area: sanctions for violations of EU consumer protection regulations. Among other things, violations of consumer protection regulations can be punished with fines of a minimum amount of 4% of the annual turnover. We also prevented what the Commission had intended to worsen consumer law, namely a restriction of the right of withdrawal in the consumer rights directive. And we've blacklisted a number of unfair business practices. I can't list them all, I don't have the time. There is one downer, however: We did not succeed in getting the dual-quality products on this black list because a majority of states in the European Union simply refused. Now the question is: should we throw everything we have now achieved in the trash? My group nevertheless recommends agreeing and ensuring that the review clause that we have enforced is actually used in the next parliamentary term to ensure that the rights that consumers have are actually enforced, including against them dual quality, because we cannot accept that there are consumers of first and second quality. That is why we, as Social Democrats, as the S&D Group, will continue to work on it and fight to have this abolished because it is unacceptable. Nevertheless, tomorrow we will agree to the compromise that has been reached.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, for our generation, for my generation and for the people of Central and Eastern Europe, the symbol of a united Europe has been the fall of the Iron Curtain. But maybe it will be a year for our children when legislation comes into force that prevents the sale of foods that have different compositions under the same brand, because we have experienced this in Eastern Europe. People from Western Europe have better quality food than the same ones produced in our regions in Eastern Europe, in Eastern Europe. Therefore, I very much hope that the fight for the same quality of food goes to the finals. Despite the 20,000 apparatus, the European Commission did not notice this problem until 2017, when President Juncker said that I quote: "Slovaks do not deserve to have less fish in their fish fingers, Czechs less cocoa in their chocolate and Hungarians less meat in their meals." . Thanks to a political breakthrough of this type, however, it really belongs in particular to the active citizens who have pointed this out, and to all those who have shown by research that multinational food concerns have simply lied and been going through it for a long time. But such a change in food is only the first step in the same metro in the European Union. Other areas need to be followed, such as the adjustment of subsidies for farmers and so on.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, a couple of years ago, online, I booked a room in an amazing hotel for the price of nothing. The rooms were beautiful; the view was amazing; the furniture was just too good to be true. And when I got there, it turned out that it really was too good to be true. It was not beautiful, not amazing, not a hotel. It was actually a garage that somebody had transformed into a kind of room that I was supposed to live in. The purpose of this legislation is to avoid such scenarios in the future, because this is an experience that many European consumers have in everyday trade online.  The proposal that is on the table is actually defending that, and I think, in that way, it is a victory for consumers. It defends the right to withdrawal – which in my case would be very suitable, in that in that position. It actually took a very reasonable stance on the contentious issue of the dual quality of products. I do understand it’s very difficult, but it is a good point that we have, and it makes it more difficult for the unserious businesses to trick you. What we are doing, the new transparency requirements online, will make sure that the ranking criteria on your site is clearly visible. That you cannot cheat with that. The new provision will stop the fake reviews from taking place, and the ambition is that, in the future, the amazing view is just simply amazing. I think this is good legislation, and I hope that my colleagues will not fall into the trap of putting it back, sending it back to the committee because of this contentious issue of dual—quality products.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! It is good that the EU is devoting itself to consumer protection and defining uniform European standards. It is also good that Parliament, as the directly elected institution, can be relied on more than on the Commission, as we saw, among other things, in defending the right of withdrawal against the Commission's original plans to water down that right. But obviously there is a problem in this new deal for consumers that we are all aware of, namely that of double quality standards. For example, if someone from Germany goes on vacation with their child to Poland and buys their favorite butter biscuit there, it should contain as much butter instead of palm oil, as is the case with the same brand in Germany. But that's just not the case. Here, due to the profit-maximizing practices of companies, some Europeans - especially in Central and Eastern Europe - are turned into second-class consumers. It is time to put an end to this business practice in the interests of a united Europe based on solidarity.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, despite the many good provisions on transparency and consumer rights online, one crucial piece is missing from this legislation: a clear ban on the dual quality of products. I regret to see that this Parliament is divided not on ideological lines, but on geographical lines, where Members from the western states seem to think that this deal is good enough, even though Parliament has given up on its position of banning dual quality and the Central and Eastern European Members are asking for a better deal. The Greens/EFA Group is not divided on this. We consider this a matter of treating people equally in the EU, and this is at the core of what European citizens expect: that they will not be discriminated against because of where they live by being sold an inferior product. This is why we would rather take the time to do it right and not adopt a trilogue agreement that has been rushed through and where Parliament has given up on its promise to citizens to ban dual—quality products.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, it’s an eventful day that we cannot reach, despite everything, a normal agreement where we do not have discrimination. Discrimination week after week. Just last week we saw discrimination against the peripheral countries in the mobility package. Now we want to discriminate people by having second—hand products. I will call them second—hand. We’re giving people second—hand products to consume because we discriminate, and let’s own up to it. Do we want a fair Europe for everybody? Do we want the same quality of product for everybody? Yes we do. Let’s not give up. Let’s keep fighting. Let’s keep fighting and let’s win so we can all have a fair deal in Europe – that’s all we’re asking. Equal rights, equal Europe: everyone’s a winner.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr President, the negotiated agreement is justified by the fact that these are changes that improve the position of consumers and that if we do not approve it tomorrow, consumers will have to wait another year. This is also an example of a double standard, where the rights of some consumers are considered more important than the rights of others, such as those who rightly feel like second-class citizens. That is why I did not vote in favor of the agreement in committee and I tabled an amendment which, when approved, will return us to the negotiating table. Let us not leave it until we have in our hands a text with which we can present our citizens with a clear conscience and tell them that we have indeed outlawed the double quality. I suggested how to do it. Double quality must be an unfair practice. Let only what is really the same be labeled anyway, and let the consumer be clear at a glance what he is buying. No business spirits! Ladies and gentlemen, please do not change the pressure we have already expressed under pressure, namely to ban double quality. At stake is the credibility of the European institutions, of the European Union as a whole, and I think that is not enough.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: - Mr President, at this last sitting of ours, we were able and should have made the final point in the debate on the same amount of cocoa in chocolate - to borrow the example of the President of the European Commission. That was his clear message. For me, as an MEP elected for the Czech Republic, the result is disappointing. I don't want to look for the culprit here today, I don't want to say which lobby won. It could be the pressure of some states, it could have been the pressure of those who fill the shelves with lower quality goods. But we can say exactly who the losers are. He is a consumer, a customer from Eastern Europe. We have material on the table today that has shredded the tough and uncompromising approach to those who supply us in Eastern Europe, and now I apologize for the expression, shunts. It is good that, after many years of debate, we have new, concrete legislation on the table that is trying to do that. However, the list of possible exceptions for manufacturers makes it soft, symbolic, rather than a law that could really protect us from the unfair practices of traders. We give manufacturers the opportunity to once again defend the different composition and thus the different quality of products. This includes, for example, excuses for various taste preferences of customers. That is why I am asking colleagues to support our amendments tomorrow, ending the practice of having two types of consumer in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I finally gave this blue card and I want to ask my colleague a question.Don't you think you're using unnecessarily strong words?You know very well how many years it has been said here that the dual quality of food, but also of other goods, must become an unfair practice.And it was only this European Commission, this Commissioner, who pushed it as a topic of discussion, it was not President Juncker.They were deputies, they were activities that were here as well.I want to ask you if you are serious about the criticism you have made here.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Madam colleague, as I said, I am disappointed with that result.Yes, this Parliament has been fighting for several years for us to put a stopwatch forever on the double meter, the double customers, the consumers in Europe.What I see is not the text that the European Parliament wanted, it is not the position of my committee that I voted for and that I wanted to achieve.So I'm disappointed.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, a year ago, everyone here, starting with the Commission, promised to abolish the dual quality of things on the EU market. However, the resulting text indicates the opposite and maintains the current reprehensible state. In addition, under the pressure of the directly unelected Commission, the minimum requirement to indicate different composition has been dropped. I emphasize that this happened only after the final trialogue, in a non-transparent manner and behind the scenes. I must therefore warn you that if the directive as approved is approved, it will be perceived very negatively by the citizens of the Czech Republic. This is because, on the one hand, the EU is forcing us on a number of controversial obligations, but on the other hand, Western countries are turning us into a rubbish bin. There is a danger that the countries of Central and Eastern Europe will have no choice but to adopt their own national legislation, even at the cost of conflict with EU law. Therefore, please support our amendments, which return to the text the negotiated compromise that was originally negotiated and combat this shameful practice of dual quality. If the result is delayed by a few months, it doesn't matter at the moment. Because we will tell all the citizens of the European Union that they are equal. And that is what that amendment is about.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr President, I am glad that the topic of double product quality has been included in this debate on the European Union Directive on consumer protection. To several questions from the Commission about consumer discrimination and product differences in the West and East, and written statements about these differences, I received a response from the Commission that the differences are the result of consumer tastes and business strategies. Dissatisfied with such a position of the Commission, I launched, with the support of 44 MEPs, an interpellation on the differences in the declarations, composition and taste of products on the EU market. I also, with the support of colleagues, launched a proposal for a Union act requesting a revision of food legislation in the European Union and the elimination of discrimination. As a result of these activities, a discussion followed in the plenary session, which I supported together with my Czech colleague Šojdrova by organizing a tasting of Croatian, German and Czech products entitled "Taste the difference". I believe that the European Commission and Juncker himself, prompted by our pressures in April last year, proposed a new consumer agreement New Deal, with the aim of establishing equal standards for all consumers in accordance with European Union law. Parliament's position is clear, we showed that by voting back in September, but since the text reached in the trialogue is not satisfactory, I co-signed the amendments with which we want to improve the text and finally ensure equal quality for all citizens of the European Union. I appeal to all colleagues to accept these amendments because for me this is also a fight against a two-speed Europe. I will be sorry if the European Parliament does not endorse these amendments by a majority, because there will still be a bitter taste that not everyone wants a Europe of equal citizens. So I am against double standards, I oppose the differences in East and West, and I recall that Mr Juncker himself has said several times here that Europe should breathe with one lung, equally with the right and with the left, equally with both lungs. And please take care of that tomorrow, when voting.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we needed to change the directives. The current proposal also amends four directives: unfair commercial practices, consumer rights, unfair contract terms and price indication. Of course, most of the changes are in the first two directives. It is necessary, indeed, to have a quality of products unique in the internal market, to respect consumers, no matter where they live. We must say, at the same time, that, yes, some good changes have been made and we cannot ignore them. I am referring here to the consumer's right to withdraw from the contract, to the consumer's right to compensation. Obviously, in the compromise, we did not reach what many of us here wanted, namely, to be more clearly specified what happens to the dual quality. Because, yes, I was presented here with an amendment to Article 6 of the Directive, but by introducing those exceptions, it weakened a lot the power of this Article 6. Of course we have a review clause and it can be a solution too. I urge now - there are not many of us here - colleagues to ponder what is best: to reject or vote and wait for the review clause. We all want good quality for all consumers.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I believe that this directive as a whole is good for consumers. It will help protect them from the unfair practices they face in all Member States, including aggressive doorstep selling, false paid online reviews, surreptitious advertising in search of goods, misleading discounts or fraudulent ticket sales for cultural and sporting events. I consider the most important part to be the explicit inclusion of dual quality among unfair commercial practices. I am proud that this success is largely the Czech footprint. I thank my colleague Mrs Sehnalová for drawing attention to this problem for a long time and for these activities here in the European Parliament, Marian Jureček, the former Minister of Agriculture, who promoted this issue at the Council, and thank the Commissioner for preparing and submitting this proposal to the European Commission. This adjustment is not perfect. I agree with my colleagues that it would be necessary to move on to a more precise definition, but we have room here after two years of review, revision, implementation of this directive to return to it and those parts that do not work can be revised. This is explicitly stated in this directive. I think it is a step in the right direction. I will support the amendments, but if they do not pass, I will support the directive as a whole, because it is important that these practices finally begin to be combated.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Honorable Chairman, six years ago, when I started working on the problem of different product quality, it seemed quite incredible that today we will have a law banning this unjust practice.It is the result of six years of persuasion, reports, research, recommendations.Now no one will be able to claim that, for example, Croats or Bulgarians really want food that is less healthy, or they really want technical goods that are of poorer quality or detergent that washes less.For millions of EU citizens, this is an extremely emotional issue.We felt like second-class citizens because of this, and rightly so.With this law, the Parliament shows that there is no division into east and west and that we are one Europe.We must all be the same.We must not allow this practice in any way.Equality is extremely important.Today we are sending such a message to the whole of Europe.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I am also disappointed with the compromise reached at the trialogue. I am convinced that this compromise will not lead to combating the dual quality of food in practice. We will end with an interpretation of what is meant by a double, extensive or directly substantial distinction between composition and characters, we will end with a lawsuit, and those who produce double foods of different qualities under the same name will laugh at that. You will see that this will be the result. Commissioner, I am convinced that I will bet with you that the legislation, if it passes, will not really punish anyone and will end up interpreting the vague legal concepts that overwhelm the compromise definition. I have also been in favor of making it clear that dual quality food is an unfair commercial practice without further ado. Such disintegration will only lead to rich companies that practice this, with teams of lawyers, being able to find a way to resell their low-quality goods in Eastern Europe. I am sad about this, I do not agree with it, I can only state that, unfortunately, the Czech government supported this compromise material, thus driving the dagger a little in the back of its own citizens. I would very much like the material prepared by the ladies of Parliament, which I co-signed, to go through tomorrow, opening up a chance to say clearly that those who have and produce products under the same name of different qualities must not do such a thing. It is an unfair business practice without examining how large the differences are, where the degree of that substantial difference is and where it is not. So please support Mrs Sehnal's proposal.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, I know that the negotiations were difficult and it is not easy to find a good balance between the need to enforce better consumer rights and the need for businesses to be competitive and efficient. It is true that, for the first time, there are concrete references in the legislation regarding double standards and Member States can take coercive measures. But we should be more ambitious and double standards should be better addressed in our legislation as these practices are undermining the trust of European citizens, mainly from central and eastern European countries, in our common market.  So tomorrow we should support the amendment by my colleague, Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein, which is the same text that was voted initially in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and, with this, the legislation will be better improved.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the double standard exists and we must recognize this, do anything to eliminate it. No matter what arguments are made for the double standard, whether we consider or you consider that the tastes of Eastern Europeans differ from the tastes of Western Europeans, I tell you very clearly, Mr President, I tell you very clearly, Commissioner, Eastern Europeans have tired of having inferior products. We are tired of having lower quality food, we are tired of having lower quality clothing and we are tired of having lower quality cars, lower cars than those in the western market. I assure you that all Europeans in the former 30-year-old communist bloc have become accustomed to the quality, they have become accustomed to the taste of democracy, not by far inferior to Western Europeans. We can no longer afford to lie to ourselves and we can no longer allow anyone to lie to us. Products intended for the western market must have the same quality as products intended for the eastern market. We are not inferior, discrimination within the European Union must end.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, consumer protection requires that there be no double standards, that there be no concept of double quality, so that we do not discriminate against consumers, especially in Eastern Europe. At the same time, consumer protection means the protection of a trademark and a trade mark, in particular of undertakings within the European Union, against unfair practices by undertakings in third countries. This is especially true for Greek products, which are of high quality and use the distinctive title "Macedonian", such as e.g. "Macedonian wine" or "Macedonian halva", and today there is an unfair competition on the part of Skopje, which also uses the name "Macedonian", resulting in a huge challenge and - at the same time - confusion. That is why, Commissioner, Mrs Jourová, the European Commission is required to support Greek products, which have been patented for years, are of high quality and are entitled "Macedonian". This is a serious matter and the Commission must address it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, for Slovakia and other Eastern European countries, the issue of dual product quality is important.Tests have shown that many companies in our region offer products with a different composition and often of lower quality under the same name.I know that it is not easy to reach an agreement, but the draft interim agreement that we are to vote on tomorrow is not good.I must admit that I am very surprised that it is giving the European Commission two years later to just assess the current situation again.And only then - if at all - he proposes to ban the sale of products of different quality under one name.At the same time, we know that such practices are happening and people are not happy with them.Therefore, I will be voting in favor of the amendments that prohibit such practices.In the common European market, quality must not be measured by the double standard.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, for me as a citizen of a Member State that has joined relatively recently, it is extremely important that the issue of the double standard finds its fair end within this mandate. This is a huge success for my political group of socialists and democrats. In particular, I would like to congratulate my colleagues Olga Sehnalova and Biliana Borzan. Especially because of Olga, the battle against the double standard was fought in the European Parliament. It is not logical for the single market to apply in the form of obligations and requirements, but for there to be no single market for the supply of identical products. The very fact that there are proven cases of differences proves that in the European Union there is no free movement of goods and services, but a selective one. I call on the Bulgarian authorities to start the procedure of transposing the directive as soon as possible. After more than 10 years of EU membership, we cannot say that there is no two-speed Europe if there is no legislation to combat it.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certain provisions in Mr Dalton's report only wipe out all the work that I, together with our colleague Olga Sehnalová and Mrs Borzan, have done in the last two years on the report on double standard. Romanians and other consumers in Western Europe will ask themselves: what is Europe doing for me? Why does Europe treat its citizens differently? If the values ​​on which this Union is built are respected equally by all of us, why doesn't Europe treat us equally? It is not fair to the citizens who vote for us at home and send us here because they trust that we will defend their interests. Or do we just want to protect the interests of big business people? I am ashamed that under the presidency of my country it was agreed that Romanians should be treated as second-hand citizens, because it seems to me that they did not know what to put on paper. The right of the trader to adapt products of the same brand in different geographical markets due to legitimate factors seems to me a great insult.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, who among us would prefer ice cream that is made from a substitute but not cream when it is presented under the same packaging? These are real examples that we see in the single internal market in Europe. Or a cola drink that has the most inferior form of sweetener instead of another that is marketed in excellent quality. I think we have to fight these scandals, and I think we have gone in a very good direction thanks to my colleague Sehnalová and others. Equal rights cannot be just a vain concept. Double quality cannot exist in Europe. It goes against the rules of the internal market. We do not have Europeans of double standard, double quality or second category! I think it is good that we have reached this stage where we have to decide on the amendments. I signed them and I support them. I am sorry that the Czech Government has unfortunately supported the compromise, which, in my opinion, loosens those definitions and is undoubtedly a deterioration of consumer rights, and it is important to return to those amendments. I ask you for their support.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honorable Members, honorable Members, there is something for me to conclude in Czech. For good reasons, because I think that the way I approached the solution of double food quality stemmed a bit from the fact that I am a Czech citizen, who is also sincerely annoyed when she sees lower quality goods on the shelves in her country than somewhere abroad. . Where were we a year and a half ago? I went around a number of agricultural councils, the COMPET Council, a number of Member States, and I heard very great doubts about whether the problem even existed. At the same time, I have heard voices from the European Parliament, Mrs Sehnal, Mrs Borzan, other colleagues who have been loudly explaining for years that the problem exists, that it is not a quasi-invention of someone who has no other problems, and so on. We've heard a lot. The fact that we have a directive on the table today that recognizes that the problem exists, and it is a directive on unfair commercial practices, I think that is a shift. Where were we also a year and a half ago? I had tests on the table from eight member countries, which were done according to different methodologies. I have worked very hard with representatives of the industry, food and drink industry, representatives of associations of brands and I have heard arguments: Well, the tests are used in different ways, apples, pears and so on, it can not be compared, it is not relevant, we will not deal with it. . So we have done a methodology, we have invested in it, we are now testing the second line of selected products from the Member States and we find that about twenty to thirty percent of the products have the significant differences that we are aiming for in this directive. At the same time, the methodology we have set out how inspections are to be, whether food or commercial - we are not telling states to deal with the matter, so I will call inspections - how inspections are to be sampled from different countries and compared and subject those samples to testing. We are there today, we have the methodology ready and it can be said that it can be continued according to it. To your arguments: Almette, what else was here, chocolate, ice cream, but those are the things we focus on that bothers us so much, and where we should trust those inspections to collect samples, test them, and say clearly, that less cocoa in chocolate is a ripped food and it cannot continue that milk powder instead of cream is a ripped food that must disappear from the market and so on. After all, these are the things that can be solved under this directive, these are the things that bother people. Let us trust a little more for those who monitor the market that they will go on a case-by-case basis and be brave enough to apply this new directive. Dr. Pospíšil spoke about vague legal concepts, which is, of course, a risk in any legislation. Imagine if we characterized it as fighting different quality, but it was not possible to work with quality as a concept at all. Let us realize that this is not a directive that speaks only of food, but also of products as such. By pulling the matter together as a Commissioner for Consumer Affairs, I actually spread it out to all products. By the way, we will now start making a testing methodology for drugstore goods. So we also talk about cars, building materials, a number of other products. That's why we had to define in some way what an unfair business practice is. So let us trust our inspections, please, that they will go after those cases and measure case by case fairly and sanction those things. Of course, I also deal with what is happening in my country. I know that the Minister of Agriculture wants to take the lead. The market surveillance authorities are preparing to assist with the relevant national legislation so that the matter can be put into practice. There is one more thing where we were not a year and a half ago - awareness. Mr Škripek said here that more active citizens should be involved. That is exactly what cannot be done now, because not even the citizens who annoy it and who have it only suspicious, but they have no evidence, no chains, and retailers do not know that the producer has a different composition under the same brand. This directive forces them to inform about it, and if they allow themselves to do such a thing that there are different compositions, they will have to prove why. Cheating a product is not an objective and justifiable difference. It's just not like that for me. And I believe that will not be the case for those inspections either. So for me, as you know, I have proposed stricter regulation, and I take this as a compromise, as an art possible, because, as we have heard, most Member States have been against, there are two ways. Trying to help ensure that implementation in the Member States leads to the result of getting ripped food out of the market is one thing, that is, fair and bold market surveillance. Brave in the sense that he will go with the intentions of the directive, he will not go for it, but will be consistent. Second, of course, informing citizens and retailers to look at where there is what information relates to a particular product. Of course, the third thing is perhaps the revision that has gotten there, which will really make it possible to monitor whether it is legislation that is falling on fertile ground, yielding results. But that step is being made now. If we withdrew it, we would have nothing and we would be where we were a year and a half ago, which I described here a moment ago. The constellation that we would be working on the same issue in such a concentration, both the European Parliament and the Commission - I would like to make a personal remark here that I used all the creativity and annoyance of myself as a Czech consumer and that I came up with the proposal - was not it was absolutely clear that I should be in charge, but the constellation was here. Now we should give that thing a go and monitor it and possibly revise it. For me, these are ways to work with a compromise solution so that the consumer knows it. For me, there is no way to tell the media that this is further proof of the difference between West and East, another trench, another division, I am very opposed to this argument, just as I am opposed to the argument that Central and Eastern Europe is a cesspool or bin of Europe. I think we, ladies and gentlemen, could forgive this for our rhetoric. I am sorry, I have been very long, but I have had a lot on my mind and thank you for listening to me, and I believe that, although it is a compromise, that it will eventually be approved by the European Parliament.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, it is a big file, but 90% of the interventions have been on one issue, and I agree with what many of you have said on dual quality. That is why we managed to achieve a lot on it. This is a ground-breaking agreement for dual quality, but what I don’t understand is why colleagues want to kill the whole agreement, including everything, because we didn’t get an impossible demand through. It is simply not viable to demand the same in all countries; there are different taste preferences in different countries, different raw material availability, and it is not always worse because the ingredients are different. I’ll give you an example: Coca-Cola in the UK is made with cane sugar; in Belgium and France, it is made with beet sugar. Who is being discriminated against? Please tell me: who has to lose the product they like in the industry that they have? I understand that your worry is about Eastern Europe. Well, in the Coke case, it is isoglucose, which is produced in Eastern Europe and is also the same thing they use in the US. So I ask my question again: which is the best product? Who is being discriminated against? If we passed that amendment, you would have to do this for every single product in the EU – millions upon millions of them. It is just not possible. It is also not possible to pass this amendment and go back to the negotiating table; there will be no negotiating table. The Council and the Commission have made it clear that they have given all they can, and they’ve given a lot. The time has now gone. It will also be clear to them that there was no point the Commission proposing anything on this, because the EP will take an unrealistic position, which will mean that, in the end, we have no deal. And then we will lose all of the following: what we did achieve on dual quality, on ranking transparency, on the block to the changes to the right of withdrawal, on banning bot selling, on marketplace transparency, on banning fake reviews, on price comparison services, transparency, and on the ability to levy penalties. Let’s not throw all of that away.  Just before I finish, I want to thank the people in my office who worked on this: Cameron Smith, Alex Davis and Jonny Goff.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place on Wednesday, April 17, 2019.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Next on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mrs Pilar Ayuso, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transparency and sustainability of risk assessment in the food chain in the EU and amending Regulation (EC) No Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 [on general food law], Directive 2001/18 / EC [on the deliberate release of GMOs into the environment], Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 [on genetically modified food and feed]; Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003 [on feed additives]. Regulation (EC) No 2065/2003 [on flavorings for smoked foods] Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 [on materials in contact with foodstuffs]. Regulation (EC) No 1331/2008 [on the single authorization procedure for food additives, food enzymes and food flavorings] 1107/2009 [on plant protection products] and Regulation (EU) 2015/2283 [on novel foods] (COM (2018) 0179 - C8-0144 / 2018 - 2018/0088 (COD)) (A8-0417 / 2018).

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: speaker. - Mr President, Commissioner, today I am very pleased that, after twenty years in this Parliament, my last speech is as rapporteur for a report on the food chain, since I came here - twenty years ago, as I said - in full mad cow crisis and after having been responsible for food and agri-food industry in Spain. I actively intervened in the Regulation that gave rise to EFSA and during these years I have participated without interruption in all food legislation. Today I can say with knowledge of the facts that the European Union has the strictest food legislation in the world and that we are a benchmark in terms of food safety. I can say that our food industry is excellent, innovative and competitive, and I can say that EFSA, for which I am the contact person for this Parliament, has done a magnificent job since its creation in accordance with current legislation. However, it was necessary to update the Regulation that created it in 2002, not only because time has shown us the points that could be improved, but also because the citizens of the European Union are increasingly interested in the determination process. risk in the food chain and the transparency of scientific studies on which decision-making is based. I only have to regret that this legislation has been produced hastily, with little time to debate and under tremendous media pressure, which is not the best scenario. I think that calling this regulation "general food law" is a bit pretentious because it only addresses the question of transparency. We cannot forget that our food safety system, the responsibility for determining risk falls on the Authority, but risk management does not. However, I do not want to downplay the agreement we have reached; I sincerely believe that we have achieved our objective of ensuring a decision-making process, based on scientific evidence, that maintains a high level of public health and safety in the European Union. At the same time, I believe that we can generate increased public confidence in decision-making by making it more transparent. To guarantee greater transparency, citizens will have immediate access to scientific studies, support for authorization requests; that is, the non-confidential information will be published at the moment the application is considered valid or admissible. In connection with this spirit of transparency, a database will be created to ensure that companies submit all studies when they request authorization and do not leave those unfavorable to them without submitting. In addition, with this, companies that fail to comply with this obligation may be penalized. With this agreement, we have also managed to find a reasonable balance between transparency and the interests of the industry to continue promoting innovation in the food sector in the European Union; In other words, the information will be disclosed without prejudice to industrial or intellectual property rights. In addition, to prevent such information from being used for unfair commercial purposes, certain safeguards have been introduced at the time of disclosure of the information, such as traceability. With regard to the organization of EFSA, I can only be happy for two reasons: first, because from now on Parliament will have two representatives on its Board of Directors, and, second, because the participation of Member States in technical and scientific commissions. This will make scientists from all Member States more closely involved in authorization procedures. Regarding the list of confidential items, it is important that the process of manufacture or production is included as a confidential item.It is also necessary to keep innovative ideas included in confidential items.Lastly, the positive part of this agreement, which is the risk assessment, will continue to be based on scientific evidence, but, at the same time, it will improve transparency on decision-making.I only regret that the process has not been approved with those of the European Medicines Agency or the European Chemicals Agency.And I end by asking for a favorable vote for this agreement.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU prides itself on having the most robust and efficient food safety system in the world. At the same time, European citizens are more and more interested in the food they eat and where it comes from. Our citizens are understandably sensitive about risk-assessment and risk-management decisions in the food chain. So, it is not surprising that EU citizens have called for additional reassurances on the safety of their food. The findings of the recent fitness check of the General Food Law and the European citizens’ initiative in relation to glyphosate bear witness to that. But before going any further, let me first congratulate the European Parliament and the Council. The positive outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations on the Commission’s proposal for the regulation on the transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment in the food chain is an important step. Both co-legislators have shown a clear commitment to this important fight, following an open intense and constructive exchange. You have managed to reach a provisional agreement on this Commission proposal in a record time of 10 months. This provisional agreement on the EU transparency rules is a significant stepping stone to meeting citizens’ expectations for more transparency in the risk assessment of the food chain. Allow me to elaborate on the agreements’ main features and briefly explain its objectives. The provisional agreement is a revision of the EU food safety system, with the focus on transparency. Greater transparency of the risk assessment process will contribute to the legitimacy of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). It will increase consumer confidence in the risk assessment system and it will ensure that EFSA is more accountable to EU citizens. With this goal in mind, the provisional agreement provides for the pro-active public disclosure of all scientific studies and data supporting a request for a scientific output. This takes place early in the risk assessment process once an the application has been considered valid or admissible. This disclosure is more closely linked with two other proposed actions: public consultation on submitted studies and the notification of commissioned studies to support application for authorisation in a database that will be established and managed by EFSA. These measures will ensure that EFSA can access the relevant scientific evidence before it drafts its scientific opinion. Enhanced public scrutiny will also serve to strengthen consumer trust in the risk assessment process. At the same time, the original agreement bears in mind the need to maintain the competitiveness of the EU food and feed sector. In order to stimulate innovation, the provisional agreement sets out safeguards for the protection of justifiable confidential information. Similarly, the provisional agreement respects existing intellectual property rights, data exclusivity rules and the protection of personal data. Not only is this a crucial ingredient in stimulating innovation, but it is also essential for the global recognition of European product safety. Furthermore, to assist applicants and, most importantly, small and medium-sized enterprises the provisional agreement introduces the possibility for EFSA to provide pre-submission advice. This advice will facilitate the better understanding of the application process and make life easier for our innovators. In order to ensure trade transparency and EFSA’s long term sustainability, Member States will be represented on the EFSA management board. The management board of EFSA will also include two members appointed by the European Parliament. As the Honourable Members are aware, this deviates from the common approach of Parliament, the Council and the Commission on decentralised agencies of 19 July 2012. The Commission will be transmitting a statement to the European Parliament regretting this deviation. Similarly, and without jeopardising EFSA’s independence, Member States will be more actively involved in ensuring the presence of experts on EFSA’s scientific panels. It is important that strong, clear messaging on risks is available to our citizens. The provisional agreement recognises this and aims to improve our communication on risks. The agreement lays the foundation for a comprehensive and effective risk-communication strategy. This will ensure that the message will be clear, comprehensive and consistent regardless of whether it comes from the Commission, EFSA or Member States. I commend the House on for its active commitment, engagement and dedication in reaching the provisional agreement. I look forward to the positive outcome of the plenary vote. Commission statements (in writing) "The Commission welcomes the political agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council on the proposal for a Regulation on the transparency and sustainability of the EU risk assessment in the food chain.  However, the Commission regrets that the co-legislators have decided to deviate from the Common Approach of the Parliament, the Council and the Commission on decentralised agencies of 19 July 2012. In particular, the Commission regrets the deviation from the Common Approach with regard to the composition of the Management Board of the European Food Safety Authority (number of members designated by the European Parliament). This deviation should not be considered as a precedent for other agencies."

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. - Mr President, Commissioner, I want to thank and congratulate you for the excellent work done by everyone involved in the negotiations, in particular the different rapporteurs. I'm sorry to not focus on the many positive aspects, but I only have a minute. I must warn that the production of food from the sea and oceans is still not considered to be at the same level as agricultural or industrial production. Despite the changes made, the EFSA Board of Directors continues to have no representative of fisheries and aquaculture products. This issue is all the more important as almost 70% of these products that are consumed in the Union are imported from third countries, so we must ensure that they follow our high standards of production and food safety. In addition, the oceans are being called upon to contribute to healthier food on a planet where obesity and a range of associated diseases have become the new stigma, with high financial costs and responsible for more deaths than hunger and malnutrition at scale. planetary.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, throughout this term of office, we have seen to what extent the issue linked to pesticides, authorization procedures, food is more and more important in the news from our fellow citizens. They want to know how the European system works and it is our duty, as elected representatives and legislators, to respond to this request. The text we have on the table largely responds to this problem by making our procedures clearer and more transparent. It will also, I hope, restore the confidence of our fellow citizens in our agencies and in our decision-making. The central question is of course when the data is published. The balance between the search for transparency and the protection of research and innovation within the European Union is not that easy to find. Let’s not forget that our businesses and SMEs face global competition, so it is essential to enable them to stay ahead of the curve in terms of development and innovation. I would therefore like to salute the work of our rapporteur, Pilar Ayuso, and of all the shadow rapporteurs. Finally, I would like, one last time before the end of this mandate, to reiterate my attachment to the fact that the decisions we take are always based on solid scientific bases, the only ones capable of allowing us to have incontestable positions in order to avoid not accentuate food fears, which some use for political and electoral purposes. For this, the independence and proper functioning of our agencies, in particular the European Food Safety Authority, are fundamental.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we all remember the scandal around the chemical industries’ pressure to get glyphosate—based pesticides approved. It got a lot of coverage and a lot of discussions going on, and this legislation was the response to that scandal. I am glad to say that this was an initiative that shows that the European Union heard the citizens’ voice and Parliament is reacting to the European Citizens’ Initiative to ban glyphosate and protect people from toxic pesticides.  We have been calling for a more transparent and independent system. We have succeeded in promoting timely public access to information held by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). This will increase control over the process of authorising substances that we unwittingly consume in our diet, whether these be pesticides, GMOs, food additives, food contact materials or flavourings. Thanks to the new rules on the active and early disclosure of information during the risk assessment, EFSA opens its doors to citizens and their scrutiny of data provided by the industry. Any information relevant to safety assessment will always be disclosed to the public.  The S&D Group’s aim was to stop fraudulent practices such as concealing of unfavourable studies and data or buying favourable results, and we succeeded. We want no more glyphosate-type cases in the European Union; no more decisions behind closed doors and no more gambling with people’s health. In today’s world where the driving force is money, the only hope for citizens is to have a robust system of authorisation that will be sufficiently resistant to external pressure. I am glad that our Group has proved that we put consumers’ health and rights above any commercial interests.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (NL) Mr President, for decades companies such as Bayer, Monsanto and Syngenta have been determining how much of their agricultural poisons ends up on our fields, fields and food. The consequences are clearly visible: bee death, loss of biodiversity, soil and water pollution, health damage to humans and animals, and farmers who no longer even know how to produce food without chemicals. The agricultural poison mixers are getting away with this thanks to lax legislation, conflicts of interest at the European Food Safety Authority, procedures based on biased studies of industry and backroom politics. By making the industry studies public, we are making a small improvement, but it is still far from enough. Just yesterday, more than thirty proven dangerous pesticides were again allowed without evaluation or reassessment. That can't be true! Commissioner, when are you really going to apply the precautionary principle, instead of the Bayer and Syngenta share prices? I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Yes, today is a good day for Europe because we have the opportunity to regain confidence that was lost in the glyphosate approval process. I would like to thank the 1.3 million citizens who have signed up for a citizens' initiative “Stop Glyphosate”, who have made this process possible, so that the approval process for chemicals is now transparent, especially in Europe. We know that the subject of glyphosate is not over. That was the trigger, because glyphosate is still the subject of criticism today. We are seeing in the US right now that the concerns should be taken seriously, and we'll see what comes out of a new approval process. What we have now achieved is: There is access to all studies, everyone can look into them. All studies have to be published, including those that may not be in the interests of a company, and EFSA can check it itself. These are big steps forward, and it is a big step that citizens' interests, environmental interests, come before corporate interests. So we are delighted with this agreement that we have made and we agree to it.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - Mr President, innovation or trade secrets or research purchased by companies can never take precedence over public health. That is why this agreement reached on the transparency of food-related research is so essential. The more complex our food systems become and the more information we have about the components that affect food, such as endocrine disruptors, the transport mechanisms of various chemicals or even nanomaterials, the more we need multidisciplinary research, publicity and general assessment of what we can consider safe and healthy food. That is what this legislation is about, and in fact quite drastically, this case of glyphosate drove the European Union - the Council, Parliament and the Commission for their part - when information about new assessments, which were completely at odds with those of the International Health Organization, was kept secret. Now this thing is fine. The next steps relate to how EFSA will be required to make better use of the precautionary principle when assessing food risks and commissioning studies.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, I would like first to congratulate Commissioner Andriukaitis and the whole European Commission for the excellent proposal, and our colleague, Madam Pilar Ayuso, for the comprehensive report. It is extremely important for the European Union to regain citizens’ trust and maximise the transparency of scientific studies in the field of food safety, especially after the well-known controversies regarding and related to the authorisation of certain sensitive products such as genetically-modified organisms, or certain active substances such as neonicotinoids and the already-famous glyphosate. In the last trilogue, Parliament managed to reach a balanced, provisional agreement with the Council, establishing a process of evaluation which is independent, transparent and inclusive and involves the online publication of all studies by the European Food Safety Authority and a continuous dialogue with civil society in order to ensure the exclusive predominance of public interest. However, in order to ensure the full success of this legislative framework, it is of high importance, and I would like to take this opportunity to appeal to the vast majority of Member States to encourage their experts to become members of the scientific risk-assessment groups, for the reason that currently, only six Member States provide two-thirds of the total number of experts.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, on that last point, we talked about dual quality, and now we are also talking about quality, and that is food safety.I don't think it's less important than the double quality.This Directive addresses the authorization regime, which should be based on clear scientific conclusions.The new regulation should be a good compromise that will increase the transparency of the risk assessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority.At the same time, it should not jeopardize the competitiveness of European companies.Greater transparency of scientific studies on food is needed, because it is necessary to prevent misinformation or even conspiracy theories while maintaining a really high level of food safety.On the other hand, companies also need trade secrets, which must be observed.Therefore, a better outcome could also be achieved by giving EFSA more political oversight, including from the European Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, risk assessment in the food chain is very important, because there are really serious risks to the health of consumers and I think we need to be decisive on this. The key is labeling so we really know what the food contains. The second is to watch out, Mr Katainen, for imports from third countries, because they do not meet the conditions there. In Turkey, for example, tomatoes and other agricultural products are grown with fertilizers that are banned from the European Union. The third case is the illegal Hellenization of products, that is, the fact that products appear as supposedly Greek, while this is prohibited — I have repeatedly denounced it. We have illegal Greekization of milk imported through Albania and illegal Greekization of meat imported through Skopje. These issues are important both for consumer protection and for dealing with fraud and, in addition, for protection at the tariff level. Therefore, concrete measures must be taken. Big scandals are being revealed, as we have seen with glyphosate. The European Union must take decisive action.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, this proposal is a response to the European Citizens' Initiative against Glyphosate with very broad public support or to the Monsanto papers case, which reveals the unhealthy environment for scientific studies commissioned by the companies whose products are to be decided on their basis. The Commission has proposed to increase the transparency of the risk assessment process and to provide sufficient assurance as to the reliability, objectivity and independence of the studies used by EFSA in its risk assessment. I have to say, and you do not hear me say this often here, that the final text is a significant improvement on the current situation, because risk assessment and management should be more transparent and accountable. EFSA will be under constant review, and the studies should finally be published without hindrance and available to the general public and professionals, including manufacturers' applications and other supporting documentation. The regulation even contains certain penalties for manufacturers in the event of non-transparent behavior. This is the first very important step in regaining public confidence, which is why I am very happy to support it.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank the House very much for this very lively and good debate.  Just to conclude, I would like to reiterate that this provisional agreement, thanks to the co—legislators, will reinforce and legitimise the important role played by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).
