That is very crucial because our people want to trust the authorities and they want to apply – and EFSA has always wanted to apply – the precautionary principle and it is very important for our citizens to know this. Because if you don’t trust our authorities then we can always auction the truth, politically, which is not good for anybody. Also, this provisional agreement will increase transparency and will strengthen consumer confidence.  So I really want to thank you for a good job, for your decisiveness on this issue. I also want to mention or reply to some of the comments concerning the products sold on our market. All the products sold on the internal market, on the European market, have to fulfil the European food safety criteria, no matter where they come from. This is another point which is very important for our consumers: that the EU is the safest market and our rules, regulations and standards also apply to the products coming from outside of Europe.  So once more, thank you very much for your engagement on this very important topic.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: speaker.- Madam President, I just want to thank all the speakers and the shadow rapporteurs;and thank you very much, Mr. Katainen.And I would especially like to thank the Commission services, particularly Commissioner Andriukaitis - I beg you to pass it on - the Romanian Presidency and the wise men, as well as Mrs Sommer, who initiated this report as rapporteur.Due to the efforts that all of them have made during the negotiation, we have reached an agreement, as I have said, reasonably satisfactory.The services of the three institutions have worked very hard in recent months.It has really been done in record time, as you have rightly said, and I think it is important that we acknowledge the work that our officials have done on this report, and I would like to publicly thank them.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 17 April 2019.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The worrying revelations expressed about the transparency of the scientific studies used for the evaluation of glyphosate have led to the need to restore public confidence in the European risk assessment system. The "transparency package", which we will approve tomorrow, will result in citizens having automatic access to all scientific research and information submitted by industry in the pesticide risk assessment process. Stakeholders and the public will be consulted on the submitted studies. At the same time, when duly justified, confidentiality will be ensured, establishing the type of information that can be considered significantly harmful to commercial interests and therefore cannot be disclosed. A European database containing notifications of all commissioned studies will be set up in EFSA to ensure that companies applying for authorizations submit all relevant information, without omitting the unfavorable ones. Not everything requested in the dossier delivered by the PEST commission has yet been implemented, much work still needs to be done, but it is an important step forward for Europe, a world leader in high food safety standards.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - We have achieved a great result that will increase food safety. We have pushed for timely public access to European Food Safety Authority information. This will increase the control of the authorization process of substances that we unknowingly take into the body through our food. Whether it is pesticides, GMOs, dyes, flavorings and other additives, so-called éčka. The safety assessment will be based on the latest scientific knowledge. Consultation with third parties will ensure that no information and no data is hidden. We are introducing more frequent inspections of research institutions and mandatory registration of studies on the safety of substances. It is over to conceal inconvenient studies and buy favorable results. In some cases, this has been demonstrably done. A lawsuit concerning the herbicide glyphosate confirmed this. In addition, in my introductory statements, I managed to push for the public authorities to inform about cases where our health is endangered by deliberate deception of producers. It is not fair if we pay honestly for food and are crazy. And it's no longer fair to gamble with our lives for the profits of several companies. I am glad that the negotiations have shown that we Social Democrats are on the side of public health, not on the side of economic interests. It is now up to the Member States to increase transparency at their level as well. To finally find out how they make decisions about our health.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Luis de Grandes Pascual, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products (COM (2018) 0439 - C8-0257 / 2018 - 2018/0229 (COD)) (A8-0482/2018).

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: speaker. - Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission - thank you very much for your presence - ladies and gentlemen, when we approached the adventure of this report it did not seem possible: I found a territorial and political division that was unbridgeable. Then, in the area of ​​trilogues - Commission, Parliament and Council - after arduous negotiations we concluded a balanced agreement on 14 February. The compromise agreement, which modifies the Commission's initial proposal, was reached in a record time of two weeks, was approved by a majority of the Member States and was confirmed again in the Committee on Legal Affairs. And now the Plenary of the European Parliament has the floor. The European Union introduced the complementary protection certificate to bring and promote research in Europe. Approximately half of the patent life of a new treatment is lost during the research, development and regulatory processes, and the certificate helped to restore part of that patent life. But the market has evolved, ladies and gentlemen, and generics manufactured within Europe had been left defenseless because, during the patent period and during this complementary period of protection, they could neither produce nor store the protected products, even when it is exclusively for export purposes to third countries where protection does not exist or has expired. Meanwhile, in other third countries that do not have this additional period, they can. This means that those generic producers who decide to manufacture outside Europe have a competitive advantage in the rest of the world and, furthermore, their products will enter our market before European generics. The innovative industry, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe is key and when it comes to Europe's strategy we must inexcusably continue to defend a knowledge economy. Let's not forget that this part of our industry invests approximately € 35 billion in R&D in Europe, approves thousands of drugs and new active ingredients every year, so it is clear that our intellectual property incentive system exists, it is working to manufacture and deliver new, improved treatments to patients who need them. But the generic biopharmaceutical industry must play a key role in the performance of Europe's exports and be one of the most competitive pillars of the Union's economy, helping to restore European growth. The exception to the certificate represents an effort to achieve equity within the existing framework, to free the playing field between generic manufacturers in the Union and third countries. From now on, ladies and gentlemen, manufacturers of generics and biosimilars established in the Union will be able to manufacture these products for export purposes to third country markets where this protection does not exist or has expired, thereby helping those manufacturers to compete in effectively in third markets. This Regulation will also allow these same manufacturers established in the Union to store the products in the Member State where they have been manufactured during the last six months of protection. The aim is the entry into the market of any Member State, once the certificate has expired, thereby helping to compete effectively in the Union immediately after the protection expires. We have included appropriate safeguards so as not to weaken our commitment to intellectual property and innovation. In this sense, generic and biosimilar drug manufacturers will be required to publish and send information to the holder of the supplementary protection certificate, to prevent the industry from circumventing the exception rules, and at least three months in advance. The notification will ensure the transparency of the system and increase competition in European markets, but at the same time, the Regulation respects the maintenance of the confidentiality of particularly sensitive information. The approval of this Regulation will be of great benefit to European industry and to pharmaceutical savings. The Commission has calculated that in 2025 this will mean an increase in production of between 7.3 billion and 9.5 billion euros and the creation of between 20,000 and 25,000 jobs in the Union, as well as savings in pharmaceutical spending up to 4%. Ladies and gentlemen, this report has not been easy. We have all had to make an effort to understand the different positions until reaching a balance and a consensus. Really thanks to the shadow speakers and thanks to our collaborators, who have worked so hard. I especially want to remember my collaborator, Mercedes, who worked hard. Thanks to the Romanian Presidency for having risen to a great issue.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the supplementary protection certificate (SPC) waiver was an important element of the Commission’s single market strategy. This regulation is likewise an important deliverable for this Parliament. It was explicitly called for in the report by Ms Lara Comi in 2016 on the single market strategy. A positive vote tomorrow will send a strong and clear message to Europe’s citizens and to the business community, a positive message on EU competitiveness, a positive message on strong industrial property protection and a positive message on access to affordable medicines for citizens. Delivering for our citizens and being seen to do so is important. It is also important in the context of Europe’s rendezvous with its citizens next month. The Commission is therefore very happy with the outcome of your successful negotiations. Parliament and the Romanian Presidency did an excellent job. This has not been an easy fight, far from it. So I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr de Grandes Pascual, for his tireless work in difficult political circumstances and under severe time constraints. I would also like to mention the rapporteurs for the committee opinions, Mr Wölken and Ms Sánchez and the various rapporteurs. I say to Members: through your inputs you have contributed to an economically useful waiver and to a clear and balanced legal text. The robust text that you have agreed with the Council will allow EU companies to take part in, and become leaders of, the emerging global market in generic and biosimilar medicines on the basis of a level playing field with manufacturers based outside the EU, delivering upwards of 25 000 net new jobs in the pharmaceutical sector in the EU over the years ahead. And, ultimately, reaffirming Europe’s position as a hub for pharmaceutical R&D and manufacturing. I will now say a few words about the main elements of the regulation on which the plenary is due to vote tomorrow. Firstly, on stockpiling, a sensitive issue for Parliament. I welcome the flexibility shown by the Council, and also by the Commission, in accepting this inclusion. Stockpiling will be allowed during the final six months of the SPC in order to better ensure day-one entry of EU-produced generics and biosimilars after the expiry of SPC protection in the EU. In addition, every five years, an evaluation will take special account of whether the provisions on stockpiling are sufficient, specifically the review clause in Article 21A of the Regulation mandates the Commission to examine, inter alia, whether the six-month stockpiling period is sufficient to satisfy the objectives of the waiver. Secondly, on the date of application, all three institutions showed flexibility. The waiver will now become an effective reality by 1 July 2022 at the latest. This date respects the dual imperative of being both legally sound and economically useful. That being said, there will be no retroactive impact on acquired rights and, likewise, the core rights in the EU of SPC holders are not affected since market inclusivity in the EU remains intact during the SPC term. In addition, there will be a transitional regime so due account is taken of legitimate expectations of right-holders. Thirdly, on safeguards. The final compromise is robust and transparent. Exceptions will be accompanied by important but proportionate safeguards. These include appropriate notification rules which come on top of the new classified medicines rules that entered into force in February 2019. But, at same time, the regulation respect the needs of makers of generics and biosimilars to keep certain commercially sensitive information confidential and it complies with our obligation to promote healthy competition both in the EU and beyond. Because in the long run that means lower prices for patients. Let me conclude. I believe you have reached a good compromise. It reflects a good balance between the various political views and between the sometimes-competing interests of stakeholders. I hope that Parliament will endorse it in the vote tomorrow.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Rapporteur ENVI. - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for the good cooperation. It was a very demanding task in terms of time. What did we achieve with this report? I believe that with this report we are ensuring that patients in the European Union have better access to cheaper and safer medicines. We have thus finally fulfilled one of Parliament’s mandates from various reports. In doing so, we are ensuring that generics and biosimilars are manufactured in Europe that we cannot currently produce in the European Union because the legal requirements for this are not in place. We are thereby increasing the safety for the patients. Let us remember: there have been contaminated medicines in recent years, there has been a shortage of certain medicines. If we produce here in the European Union, we can assess the quality better, we can also ensure that the drugs are available here in the event of a shortage. So in that respect we have taken a real step forward. The sticking point of this regulation, however, was the so-called stockpiling, i.e. storage for the first day of the expiry of the supplementary protection certificate. And here, large parts of the company, but unfortunately also the European Commission, have tried to do everything possible to prevent this stockpiling - even though the impact assessment of the European Commission itself said that the greatest benefit is in manufacturing and exists with a stockpiling. If you don't believe that: page 42 of the impact assessment. In this respect, we argued for a long time about something that actually brought the best benefit for the patients. In the end we have been stockpiling for six months. This is a good first step, and the strong review clause gives us the opportunity to see in a timely manner whether that is really enough. I hope that we can then find really safe and good drugs for all patients in the long term. Finally, thank you to all employees who really worked under time pressure.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! Commissioner! Of course, I also join these thanks. This regulation is one of the few examples that European law can also be friendly to Polish entrepreneurs. In this term of the European Parliament, similar proposals rarely gained a majority. Fortunately, this was not the case with supplementary protection certificates for medicinal products. We managed to adopt and then negotiate with the Council and the European Commission a very good text that opens up new markets and broad prospects for European producers of generics and biosimilars. The amendment of this regulation is also very good news for patients, it means faster access to modern and affordable medicines. I am sure that Polish pharmaceutical companies will take full advantage of the opportunities that this project opens up for them. This is a great opportunity for new investments and jobs in a very innovative sector of the economy. Of course, our group will support this project tomorrow.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Mr President, in this speech I would like to underline that I remain skeptical about the possible positive impact of this proposal on the patient and the pharmaceutical sector. For me, the interests of the patient are central to the legislation. And as a cancer survivor, the patient remains the blue thread through my career. Nevertheless, I ask the Commission to keep an eye on this new measure and review it if necessary. The patents given to the pharmaceutical industry are not just there. This is a reward for the years of work that the company has put into it before a new drug can be launched on the market. I speak here of reward, where I should perhaps rather speak of insurance. The investments that companies are putting in new medicines are enormous. For example, in order to find a new antibiotic, only one in ten thousand molecules will lead to a successful drug. Yet you will also have to research and develop the 9,999 other molecules to a certain extent. To safeguard the innovation so much needed to offer new medicines to patients, we must be careful with patents and the protection of intellectual property. I therefore ask you not to be blind to the possible consequences that the sector may experience.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, EU-based manufacturers of generic and biosimilar medicines are currently not allowed to manufacture products protected by an additional protective measure for export to third countries, even if protection of the products has expired. It is clear that it is about big money, it is about jobs, but it is also about access to medicines and innovation. In the ENVI Committee, we have tried to find a balance between all these complex elements. However, as expected, the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations is mixed. The biggest problem that I see in the result of the text is the date of its entry into force, respectively. efficiency. In order for citizens and healthcare systems to benefit from this new regulation, it must enter into force as soon as possible. From this point of view, the 3-year transition period seems borderline. However, overall, the position of our generic manufacturers should gradually improve, which should benefit everyone. Therefore, I am able to support the result.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this is my last speech in this European Parliament. I am proud that it is on a file where the European Parliament has stood up to the so-called intellectual property industries, which are sometimes putting profits above access to medicines – which is, after all, a fundamental right. Supplementary Protection Certificates (SPCs) are not economically justified at all. They just prolong patents on medicines that are already too long. This proposal at least allows the manufacture of generic medicines for sale where they are already legal. This is a small step, but it’s a step in the right direction. It comes with an ambitious revision clause to investigate if this 6—month stockpiling waiver is enough to achieve public health or whether we need to question the SPC regime altogether and have a more fundamental reform. So long, and thanks for all the fish.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this new regulation is of paramount importance, as it provides for a derogation for our European companies through which they will be able to manufacture a generic or biosimilar version of a protected medicinal product if this version is exclusively intended forexport to third countries or to be stored pending entry into the Union market from the first day following the expiry of the corresponding additional certificate.This measure will allow our producers to be competitive in the market of third countries where complementary protection did not exist or has expired and will also give our citizens timely access to medicines at reduced prices, in particular in the Member States.where the prices of essential drugs are really too high.I would like to end by thanking the rapporteur, Luis de Grandes Pascual, for his excellent work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we must not forget that the main issue we are discussing and focusing on is the protection of public health. Second, the interest of the patients themselves, which presupposes their access to cheap medicines. Therefore, any arrangements made for patents and to support the competitiveness of the European pharmaceutical industry must serve these purposes. Because we do not have to go to the other extreme, that is, to have expensive drugs that patients can not access. We know that various pharmaceutical tricks have been done in Europe in order to raise the price of the drug. A classic case is the Novartis scandal, which has been revealed - especially in Greece - and for which we must go to the end, to reveal all the responsibilities and - of course - to impose penalties on this pharmaceutical industry as well. You must pay attention, Commissioner, Mr Katainen, to the issue of drug stocks, because it is key. As well as the fact that multinationals do not take advantage of the opportunity to export medicines, which leads to shortages within the European Union. If we comply with all this, then we can have competitiveness of the European pharmaceutical industry but, above all, patient protection.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President. I congratulate my colleague de Grandes on a job well done and I welcome the changes in European legislation in the field of the supplementary protection certificate for medicines. The compromise reached is a great success - we have ensured both the development of new medicines in Europe and a level playing field for manufacturers of generic and similar biologics based in Europe and those based elsewhere. We enabled European generic producers to export to third countries where there is no valid additional protection certificate, and we also significantly facilitated their entry into the European market on the first day after the expiry of the certificate. Ladies and gentlemen, the prices of medicines and the costs of treatments have risen so much in recent decades that they have become practically inaccessible to new patients. Faster entry of medicines into the European market therefore also means faster access to affordable medicines for our people. With this legislative proposal, we have once again proved that the European Union works, that it does not care about a sick person who needs our help.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, very briefly I want to thank you for this good debate and once more thank and congratulate the rapporteur on a very good job. It’s been politically a very sensitive file, but the solution is a showcase of pragmatism, a very practical solution, meaning that EU generic and biosimilar producers have a level playing field vis—à—vis the other producers. At the same time, the patent protection will cover all the innovators. This is a very simple description of the solution / compromise. We will show the innovators clearly that this continent is all in favour of new innovations. We want to protect you, and at the same time we have created a level playing field for those who are producing generics and biosimilars. So this is a very good decision for our patients, for our consumers and also a very good decision for producers, for industry and innovators. Thank you very much for your cooperation.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: speaker. - Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I thank you for your presence, your words and your rigor. I reiterate my thanks to the shadow rapporteurs. There have been times, throughout this work, when I have felt alone, because the shadow rapporteurs have been very demanding. And they have done very well. They have demanded that the balance be true. Sometimes, in the European Parliament, the need for consensus causes us to produce minor agreements simply to get ahead. It is the old tale of the birth of the mountains. With a lot of noise and sometimes delivery is a little mouse. This has not been the case. The resulting product is really rigorous and serious, and produces a balance and a position of equity. Innovators and generic manufacturers have fought in defense of their legitimate interests, but in the end the success has not been in favor of one or the other: it has been in favor of European health. For this reason, I bet and toast that this Regulation is efficient. And, as it has been said here, if it were not enough, for that we have established that review clause; to be able to analyze, and, if necessary, complete, rectify or modify something that I believe meets the objectives of this end of the legislature, in which I too am leaving, never to return. But it has been an honor working with all of you.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 17 April 2019.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - Given the particular importance of the availability and accessibility of medicines for public health and public spending, existing disparities in national legislation, which hinder the free movement of medicines on the internal market, must be eliminated. Investment in research and innovation needed to develop a new generation of medicines to support the treatment of new diseases or generate more therapeutic effects, as well as to prevent the relocation of pharmaceutical research outside the Union, must also be promoted at EU level, to countries that could provide better protection while ensuring access to medicines in the EU. Stimulating the competitiveness of regulated industries, such as the pharmaceutical industry, under the Single Market Strategy, can be achieved through patents and supplementary protection certificates (CSPs). Thus, a manufacturer with an export production line will be able to easily, after the expiry of the CSP, use the same line for the production of generic or biosimilar medicines in order to quickly supply the EU market.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - Europe is and should remain at the forefront of pharmaceutical research and manufacturing, and the SPC also supports Europe's pioneering role in pharmaceutical research and development. These laws foster creativity and maintain the world-class innovation potential of the pharmaceutical industry. I therefore fully support the proposed introduction of an exception for the protection of SPCs as a way of addressing the unintended legal obstacle that has prevented EU-based generic and biosimilar manufacturers from competing in export markets where competition is known to be fierce, and to re-establish a level playing field. activities for production in the EU and outside the EU. Supplementary Protection Certificates (SPC) extend the patent protection of medicinal products, which must undergo long-term trials and clinical trials prior to marketing authorization. With the exemption, EU-based companies will in the future be able to manufacture a generic or biosimilar version of a protected medicine during the period of validity of the protection certificate, if this is done solely for the purpose of exporting to a market outside the EU where the protection has expired or never existed.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. - The aim of the introduced regulations is to level the opportunities on the global market for small and medium-sized pharmaceutical producers from the EU, while maintaining the protection of original drug producers. These are extremely important changes for Polish pharmaceutical producers. So far, SPC protection has covered both the sale and production of a generic drug throughout the EU. On the other hand, pharmaceutical companies located outside the EU, after 20 years of patent protection expiration, can produce and sell a given drug worldwide outside the EU, and at the end of the 5-year protection period, they can also enter the EU market with a generic. This puts EU smaller companies at a disadvantage. Thanks to the leveling of opportunities in third markets, small and medium-sized EU pharmaceutical companies will be able to raise capital to not only produce in the generic and biosimilar drugs sector, but also build their own R & amp; D (research and development) facilities for the production of new drugs. In addition, they will not be forced to move their production outside the EU, which will of course create new jobs for highly qualified staff. Ultimately, the introduced changes are also intended to guarantee patients faster and wider access to safe generic drugs produced in the EU immediately after the end of SPC protection.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the possible extradition of Julian Assange (2019/2704 (RSP)).

name: Melania Gabriela Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the issue of the possible extradition of Julian Assange. We are all aware that, when acting for the purpose of protecting the general public interest, whistle—blowers play an essential role by disclosing wrongdoing and dangers to society. Therefore they deserve legal protection. I know you discussed this yesterday in the debate on the whistle—blowers’ directive. We have all been following recent events related to Mr Assange’s case. Julian Assange took refuge in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London in 2012 to avoid being taken to Sweden to be questioned on charges of rape, molestation and unlawful coercion. He argued that his asylum claim aimed to prevent his being ultimately extradited to the United States and put on trial for publishing thousands and thousands of classified US documents. As you all know, on 11 April, Ecuador withdrew Mr Assange’s asylum, which led to his arrest by the British police. Westminster Magistrates’ Court subsequently found him guilty on British charges of breaching bail. In addition to charges in the United Kingdom, Mr Assange currently faces charges in the United States, and the Swedish judicial authorities have indicated that investigations may be resumed into charges of rape against him. Let me clearly point out that the Council as such has not discussed the issue of Mr Assange’s possible extradition and does not have a position on it. As a matter of fact, extraditions are a matter of the exclusive competence of Member States. Therefore, the matter now lies in the hands of the British judiciary and of the UK Home Secretary. But let me take this opportunity to stress once more that the Council attaches very high importance to the protection of whistle—blowers. As a matter of fact, during the last month, Parliament and the Council focused their efforts on ensuring that an agreement on the whistle—blowers’ directive was reached before the end of the current legislative term. That objective was achieved and this plenary voted today on the text agreed by the negotiators of the two co—legislators.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Parliament asked the Commission to make a statement on the possible extradition of Julian Assange from the United Kingdom. We can inform you that extradition between the United Kingdom and the United States is governed by a bilateral treaty and a subsequent EU-US extradition agreement. The latter does not allow extradition in cases where there are reasons to believe it may lead to the application of the death penalty. In addition, the Court of Justice has also decided that a Member State must refrain from an extradition if there are serious risks that fundamental rights of the suspect are affected. If Sweden decides to issue a new European arrest warrant following the one that it had revoked in 2017, the UK court would have to consider whether to give precedence to this European arrest warrant over the US extradition request. There are no clear-cut EU rules in this respect but rather a list of factors to be taken into account by the court. As a general remark, I must note that the European Commission does not have the competence to intervene on judicial proceedings pending in front of the courts of Member States. We fully rely on the independence and professionalism of the UK courts to take the right decision, having in front of them the appropriate evidence.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, I want to confirm the words of the Commissioner, I do not understand, in principle, why we are discussing this point in Parliament. This is a specific criminal case, a specific extradition, which will be decided according to international extradition treaties. On the one hand, the British justice system will decide, on the other hand, the United States of America is the country requesting extradition. Both countries are rule of law, so there is no doubt that the process will take place properly, according to international treaties, while respecting the rule of law. We as politicians can think of something about Mr Assange's actions, we can either approve or condemn it. I personally disagree with his deeds. I believe that freedom of expression has its limits and cannot jeopardize state secrets. And in the case of Mr Assange's activities, then, soldiers who are fighting against international terrorism. But that is my political opinion. And whether Mr Assange has committed a crime must be decided only by the courts. That is our basic position. It is therefore right that the European Commission, as a political body, has no powers to interfere in any way with the judicial system of one of the Member States. So please: let it be left to the British courts to examine the case procedurally, to consider whether the grounds for extradition are met. If so, Mr Assange will be extradited to the United States. I fully believe in the American judiciary that it will assess whether Mr Assange's unacceptable conduct is a criminal offense.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Julian Assange's extradition to the United States must be prevented. Only in this way can we guarantee that Europe protects those who defend transparency and truth and those who want to express themselves in free and plural societies. With an administration like Trump's, which makes the media a target pet, Assange would never have a fair trial. The trial in the United States would be instrumental in destroying freedom of the press and expression, as organizations such as Human Rights Watch and ACLU say. Assange would be at risk of being sentenced to death. Just look at what today pity Assange's source, Chelsea Manning, under torture in prison confinement. Julian Assange made decisive contributions to reveal the truth. It revealed atrocities in Iraq and Afghanistan and other crimes in Guantanamo and secret prisons, and rot, hypocrisy and crime in successive American administrations and even in complicit governments, including in Europe. I myself benefited from WikiLeaks' revelations. The minister who accused me of cheating when I handed over to the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry the lists of torture flights committed by the CIA and the military that were authorized by Portugal to and from Guantanamo ended up being exposed as a liar by WikiLeaks. But if Julian Assange faces criminal charges brought against him in Sweden, he must answer for those charges in the Swedish court that offers guarantees of impartiality. It must be said that we trust the independence of the courts in the United Kingdom and Sweden, but at the same time, ask them not to give in to the pressures of extradition to the United States. I do not undervalue, and I must say I am concerned, that a Julian Assange, disturbed by seven years of confinement at the Ecuadorian embassy, ​​which ended up surrendering him, violating the right of asylum granted, may have collaborated with Putin's kleptocracy to interfere in American elections and attack the Democratic Party, as Special Prosecutor Muller might point out. But it is the European courts of the Member States of the European Union that have the responsibility to try Assange and guarantee him justice, and from now on the protection as a whistleblower in line with the directive that we have also just adopted today. To protect Assange is to affirm and protect European values ​​and principles, the guarantees of fundamental rights to those accused in justice, it is to give hope to all who risk their lives for the truth, for integrity and against crime that infiltrates and even captures governments. Julian Assange deserves this protection and deserves to benefit from all these fundamental rights in the European Union. The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question - Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam colleague, I listened with interest to your speech and, as a former Minister of Justice, I ask: how can Parliament, as a political body, intervene in a specific criminal case and a specific extradition?We may have a certain opinion on this act, I may have another one, but this is an extradition criminal case and we are politicians.After all, we cannot "protect" - you have used the term - and interfere in the legal proceedings in the country where the extradition is taking place.So my question is: How would you like to protect him?

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card answer. – (inaudible) … we know that no European country should extradite to a country that has the death penalty. That’s exactly the case of the United States, I’m very sorry. Indeed Assange, if extradited to the United States, could face an accusation of spying, which would entail the death penalty. That’s a very strong reason – political and juridical – why he shouldn’t be extradited by a court, be it in the UK, in Sweden or in your own country. (Applause)

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the arrest of Julian Assange marks a very dark moment for freedom of information: his arrest affects us all. The data that have been made public thanks to Julian Assange and WikiLeaks, have revealed war crimes, murders of journalists and numerous human rights violations in the world. The Working Group on Arbitrary Detention found Assange's detention illegal. Likewise, the United Nations special rapporteur on extrajudicial executions warned about the dangers of the extradition of Julian Assange to the United States. Today we have passed in this House a Directive for the protection of leakers like Julian Assange. Let us demand that it be fulfilled. The extradition of Julian Assange would send a very dangerous message. Those who face corruption, those who face abuses of power, pay dearly. If we allow Julian Assange to be extradited to the United States, we will be giving up a fundamental part of our democracy, we will be giving up the right to information. Let's not allow it, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, in debating the possible extradition of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to the United States, we are not only addressing the fate of a man, we are also sketching the future of our democracies. We need to stand up for freedom of information and transparency loud and clear, because that is what it is. Julian Assange has released disturbing information, including on war crimes perpetrated by the United States. Rather than being held accountable for their crimes, governments want to silence the voices that rise up. We must contrast this with our intact attachment to democracies that are open, transparent and accountable. It is his courage that is being judged today. If we agree to extradite Assange, tomorrow we will extradite anyone who publishes sensitive information: the Guardian, Le Monde, Spiegel journalists who published the material leaked by WikiLeaks. France must grant asylum to Julian Assange and defend the colors of transparency.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, let us start off with one proposition. It is not a good idea for politicians to seek to intervene in the legal process. In fact it’s a very bad idea. The separation of politics and law is central to western democracy. In the case of Mr Julian Assange, he was taken into custody, came before a court and sentenced, because he was found guilty of jumping bail. There are entirely separate charges of hacking and the like that have been filed against him in the United States. It is these charges that are to be the subject of an extradition hearing. The hearing will take place before an English judge, and what the Council said was factually wrong: the Home Secretary does not decide. Many people, including me, have disliked and disagreed with some rulings of judges in the UK, but no serious person doubts the objectivity and professionalism of the English judiciary. Nevertheless, Ms Gomes and other colleagues want the legal process to be subject to political interference. This is my last speech in the Parliament, but I have to disagree. To debase the legal process to politics is entirely contrary not just to Western values but, Ms Joly, to all the institutions of democracy. We as politicians should leave the legal matter of Julian Assange well alone. Now, what were the original legal proceedings that caused Mr Assange to jump bail? Well, it was the European arrest warrant, and this warrant was brought not by a Swedish judge but by the Swedish prosecutor. Despite this, with the European arrest warrant there is no real defence against extradition, and this is very worrying. We hear a lot in this place about human rights, but it is the S&D, the ALDE Group, the British Liberal Democrats – all the unthinking supporters of a European superstate – who are also the same people who are big supporters of the European arrest warrant. Their commitment to civil liberties and the European arrest warrant is highly flawed, as it probably was in the case of Mr Assange. Your commitment to civil liberties and legal due process comes to a grinding halt at Calais, and all in the name of yet more integration. If only these people would think again, and I beg you and urge you to do so.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: – Madam President, well I have listened to Pontius Pilate today. We are in favour of whistle—blowers but we have no competence at all – neither the Council nor the Commission. But here we are a political body, we can have our political opinion about the facts. Listen to what’s happening. Let’s say a European journalist writes something or makes a disclosure on Iran. If Assange is extradited then there is a precedent. Iran – or Turkey – will be able to demand the extradition of the European journalist, or capture or kidnap the European journalist!  What are you going to say? Because they will say that he or she violated the secrets of Iran or Turkey or whatever. So don’t play Pontius Pilate when freedom of information and whistle—blowers are crucified.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card question. – I agree with my colleague Kouloglou that, indeed, this is a political body and we are entitled to make a political judgment, and we are doing that, saying that there should be no extradition to the US. But, on the other hand, we are expecting that the courts – namely in the UK, that fortunately is still and will stay in the EU – are bound by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and by the European Union Treaties. Therefore, it’s on the basis of juridical legal grounds, and not political grounds, that a resolution is expected to prevent extradition to a country that still has capital punishment. Do you agree, Mr Kouloglou?

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: blue-card answer. – I fully agree. We have to make a statement. We have made statements and statements and statements, about Venezuela, Turkey, about everything. And you are talking my colleague about the legal procedure. Was the legal procedure respected in the case of other countries? We are making interventions. We are making statements. Why not now? Why? Because the British Government is in a mess because of Brexit, and now the government is trying to escape with an Assange exit. This is not fair. This is not right. You are a politician and you have to take a position. You are either against the extradition or for it.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, I very much appreciate you giving me the opportunity to respond. It is a legal matter; that is it. Period. It is a legal matter. Now if you’re an advocate of politicians’ interfering and intervening in legal due process that is a perfectly understandable and legitimate point of view, although one that I don’t happen to agree with, but that is your privilege. That is your privilege to argue that, but it is completely contrary to the way in which Western democracy and democratic institutions are organised. The separation of the executive and the judiciary is absolutely fundamental. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask this question of my colleague, William (The Earl of) Dartmouth. What about the processes in Turkey? Is Turkey right when it says that this is a legal action and you have to respect the legal procedure in Turkey and not interfere? Then why have we done so many statements against processes in Turkey? Why?

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card answer. – I’ll answer in just a few seconds. What colleagues are advocating is that the British government intervenes in the judicial process in England. What you’re advocating about Turkey is that we intervene or seek to intervene. I entirely agree with you on your criticisms of Turkey and I only wish my government and other governments would make it clear that Turkey will never become a Member of the European Union, irrespective of whether the UK is a Member or not.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: - Madam President, this Monday I had an appointment with Julian Assange at the Ecuadorian embassy in London. I didn't go, because he was arrested. But I also went to that city to report the violation of his right to asylum, in front of the Belmarsh prison. The right to asylum means protection from the death penalty and comprehensive protection of rights. The asylum granted by Ecuador to Assange is not only to save him from an electric chair, but to protect him from jail for exercising the right to freedom of the press in a country where he would not have a fair trial. The traitorous government of Lenin Moreno has been sold. And he has degraded the principle of asylum that protects the integrality of the rights of the asylee, accepting a life sentence or long decades of confinement in a North American jail for someone whose crime has been to publish abuses of power and violations against humanity. The British Government is not demanding guarantees from the United States on the final non-application of the death penalty, which is why the letters exhibited by the Foreign Ministry of Ecuador, in which they affirm that their British peers cite a stipulation on non-extradition in death penalty cases do not constitute a commitment or guarantee not to extradite Julian Assange to the United States. The UK never offered any guarantee of non-extradition, and we denounce in this Parliament that Ecuador, the UK and the US coordinated the handover of Assange. What is happening, Commissioner, is very serious. It attacks freedom of the press and of expression. Assange must not be extradited to the United States. If he is extradited, any reporting journalist is in danger. He in danger for denouncing injustices, corruption and abuse of power.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, today we voted in favor of a directive which states, among other things: 'Whistleblowers play a key role in detecting and preventing infringements of the public interest and in ensuring the well-being of society as a whole.' we voted today. In this context, I consider it necessary to emphasize that all the major scandals that have been uncovered by the public since 2014, such as Luxleaks or Panama Papers, have come to light through the actions of whistleblowers and were clearly in the public interest. I honestly don't care if Julian Assange is a hero or a deserter for you, a traitor or a freedom fighter. In the current situation, I consider this to be secondary. I consider the only really crucial thing that if we want to protect whistleblowers, we must protect Assange. He is to be extradited to a country whose crimes he has pointed out, and in which the president is currently someone who considers journalists to be the enemies of the people. I don't believe he could get a fair trial there.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this discussion. I would like to repeat that we fully rely on the independence and professionalism of the courts in the United Kingdom. And I remain convinced that the fundamental rights and the right to a fair trial will be fully respected in the decision of the court.

name: Melania Gabriela Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank you for the opportunity to debate this topical issue of high importance. We will all closely follow the developments of Mr Assange’s case. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.
